principles.name: Perceivable
principles.description: Information and user interface components must be presentable to users in ways they can perceive.

principles.name: Operable
principles.description: User interface components and navigation must be operable.

principles.name: Understandable
principles.description: Information and the operation of the user interface must be understandable.

principles.name: Robust
principles.description: Content must be robust enough that it can be interpreted by a wide variety of user agents, including assistive technologies.

guidelines.name: Text Alternatives
guidelines.description: Provide text alternatives for any non-text content so that it can be changed into other forms people need, such as large print, braille, speech, symbols or simpler language.

guidelines.name: Adaptable
guidelines.description: Create content that can be presented in different ways (for example simpler layout) without losing information or structure.

guidelines.name: Distinguishable
guidelines.description: Make it easier for users to see and hear content including separating foreground from background.

guidelines.name: Keyboard Accessible
guidelines.description: Make all functionality available from a keyboard.

guidelines.name: Enough Time
guidelines.description: Provide users enough time to read and use content.

guidelines.name: Seizures and Physical Reactions
guidelines.description: Do not design content in a way that is known to cause seizures or physical reactions.

guidelines.name: Navigable
guidelines.description: Provide ways to help users navigate, find content, and determine where they are.

guidelines.name: Input Modalities
guidelines.description: Make it easier for users to operate functionality through various inputs beyond keyboard.

guidelines.name: Readable
guidelines.description: Make text content readable and understandable.

guidelines.name: Predictable
guidelines.description: Make web pages appear and operate in predictable ways.

guidelines.name: Input Assistance
guidelines.description: Help users avoid and correct mistakes.

guidelines.name: Compatible
guidelines.description: Maximize compatibility with current and future user agents, including assistive technologies.

criteria.name: Non-text Content
criteria.description: All non-text content that is presented to the user has a text alternative that serves the equivalent purpose, except for the situations listed below.

criteria.name: Audio-only and Video-only (Prerecorded)
criteria.description:
For prerecorded
      audio-only and prerecorded video-only media, the following are true, except when the audio or video is a media alternative for text and is clearly labeled as such:

criteria.name: Captions (Prerecorded)
criteria.description:
Captions are provided for all prerecorded
      audio content in synchronized media, except when the media is a media alternative for text and is clearly labeled as such.

criteria.name: Audio Description or Media Alternative (Prerecorded)
criteria.description:
An alternative for time-based media or audio description of the prerecorded
      video content is provided for synchronized media, except when the media is a media alternative for text and is clearly labeled as such.

criteria.name: Captions (Live)
criteria.description:
Captions are provided for all live
      audio content in synchronized media.

criteria.name: Audio Description (Prerecorded)
criteria.description:
Audio description is provided for all prerecorded
      video content in synchronized media.

criteria.name: Sign Language (Prerecorded)
criteria.description:
Sign language interpretation is provided for all prerecorded
      audio content in synchronized media.

criteria.name: Extended Audio Description (Prerecorded)
criteria.description:
Where pauses in foreground audio are insufficient to allow audio descriptions to convey the sense of the video, extended audio description is provided for all prerecorded
      video content in synchronized media.

criteria.name: Media Alternative (Prerecorded)
criteria.description:
An alternative for time-based media is provided for all prerecorded
      synchronized media and for all prerecorded video-only media.

criteria.name: Audio-only (Live)
criteria.description:
An alternative for time-based media that presents equivalent information for live
      audio-only content is provided.

criteria.name: Info and Relationships
criteria.description: Information, structure, and relationships conveyed through presentation can be programmatically determined or are available in text.

criteria.name: Meaningful Sequence
criteria.description: When the sequence in which content is presented affects its meaning, a correct reading sequence can be programmatically determined.

criteria.name: Sensory Characteristics
criteria.description:
Instructions provided for understanding and operating content do not rely solely on
      sensory characteristics of components such as shape, color, size, visual location, orientation,
      or sound.

criteria.name: Orientation
criteria.description: Content does not restrict its view and operation to a single display orientation, such as portrait or landscape, unless a specific display orientation is essential.

criteria.name: Identify Input Purpose
criteria.description: The purpose of each input field collecting information about the user can be programmatically determined when:

criteria.name: Identify Purpose
criteria.description: In content implemented using markup languages, the purpose of user interface components, icons, and regions can be programmatically determined.

criteria.name: Use of Color
criteria.description:
Color is not used as the only visual means of conveying information, indicating an
      action, prompting a response, or distinguishing a visual element.

criteria.name: Audio Control
criteria.description:
If any audio on a web page plays automatically for more than 3 seconds, either a mechanism is available to pause or stop the audio, or a mechanism is available to control audio
      volume independently from the overall system volume level.

criteria.name: Contrast (Minimum)
criteria.description: The visual presentation of text and images of text has a contrast ratio of at least 4.5:1, except for the following:

criteria.name: Resize Text
criteria.description: Except for captions and images of text, text can be resized without assistive technology up to 200 percent without loss of content or functionality.

criteria.name: Images of Text
criteria.description: If the technologies being used can achieve the visual presentation, text is used to convey information rather than images of text except for the following:

criteria.name: Contrast (Enhanced)
criteria.description: The visual presentation of text and images of text has a contrast ratio of at least 7:1, except for the following:

criteria.name: Low or No Background Audio
criteria.description:
For prerecorded
      audio-only content that (1) contains primarily speech in the foreground, (2) is not an audio
      CAPTCHA or audio logo, and (3) is not vocalization intended to be primarily musical expression
      such as singing or rapping, at least one of the following is true:

criteria.name: Visual Presentation
criteria.description: For the visual presentation of blocks of text, a mechanism is available to achieve the following:

criteria.name: Images of Text (No Exception)
criteria.description: Images of text are only used for pure decoration or where a particular presentation of text is essential to the information being conveyed.

criteria.name: Reflow
criteria.description: Content can be presented without loss of information or functionality, and without requiring scrolling in two dimensions for:

criteria.name: Non-text Contrast
criteria.description: The visual presentation of the following have a contrast ratio of at least 3:1 against adjacent color(s):

criteria.name: Text Spacing
criteria.description: In content implemented using markup languages that support the following text style properties, no loss of content or functionality occurs by setting all of the following and by changing no other style property:

criteria.name: Content on Hover or Focus
criteria.description: Where receiving and then removing pointer hover or keyboard focus triggers additional content to become visible and then hidden, the following are true:

criteria.name: Keyboard
criteria.description:
All functionality of the content is operable through a keyboard interface without requiring specific timings for individual keystrokes, except where the underlying
      function requires input that depends on the path of the user's movement and not just
      the endpoints.

criteria.name: No Keyboard Trap
criteria.description:
If keyboard focus can be moved to a component of the page using a keyboard interface, then focus can be moved away from that component using only a keyboard interface,
      and, if it requires more than unmodified arrow or tab keys or other standard exit
      methods, the user is advised of the method for moving focus away.

criteria.name: Keyboard (No Exception)
criteria.description: All functionality of the content is operable through a keyboard interface without requiring specific timings for individual keystrokes.

criteria.name: Character Key Shortcuts
criteria.description: If a keyboard shortcut is implemented in content using only letter (including upper- and lower-case letters), punctuation, number, or symbol characters, then at least one of the following is true:

criteria.name: Timing Adjustable
criteria.description: For each time limit that is set by the content, at least one of the following is true:

criteria.name: Pause, Stop, Hide
criteria.description: For moving, blinking, scrolling, or auto-updating information, all of the following are true:

criteria.name: No Timing
criteria.description:
Timing is not an essential part of the event or activity presented by the content, except for non-interactive
      synchronized media and real-time events.

criteria.name: Interruptions
criteria.description:
Interruptions can be postponed or suppressed by the user, except interruptions involving
      an emergency.

criteria.name: Re-authenticating
criteria.description:
When an authenticated session expires, the user can continue the activity without
      loss of data after re-authenticating.

criteria.name: Timeouts
criteria.description: Users are warned of the duration of any user inactivity that could cause data loss, unless the data is preserved for more than 20 hours when the user does not take any actions.

criteria.name: Three Flashes or Below Threshold
criteria.description:
Web pages do not contain anything that flashes more than three times in any one second period,
      or the flash is below the general flash and red flash thresholds.

criteria.name: Three Flashes
criteria.description: Web pages do not contain anything that flashes more than three times in any one second period.

criteria.name: Animation from Interactions
criteria.description: Motion animation triggered by interaction can be disabled, unless the animation is essential to the functionality or the information being conveyed.

criteria.name: Bypass Blocks
criteria.description: A mechanism is available to bypass blocks of content that are repeated on multiple web pages.

criteria.name: Page Titled
criteria.description: Web pages have titles that describe topic or purpose.

criteria.name: Focus Order
criteria.description:
If a web page can be navigated sequentially and the navigation sequences affect meaning or operation, focusable components receive
      focus in an order that preserves meaning and operability.

criteria.name: Link Purpose (In Context)
criteria.description:
The purpose of each link can be determined from the link text alone or from the link text together with its
      programmatically determined link context, except where the purpose of the link would be ambiguous to users in general.

criteria.name: Multiple Ways
criteria.description: More than one way is available to locate a web page within a set of web pages except where the web page is the result of, or a step in, a process.

criteria.name: Headings and Labels
criteria.description: Headings and labels describe topic or purpose.

criteria.name: Focus Visible
criteria.description: Any keyboard operable user interface has a mode of operation where the keyboard focus indicator is visible.

criteria.name: Location
criteria.description: Information about the user's location within a set of web pages is available.

criteria.name: Link Purpose (Link Only)
criteria.description:
A mechanism is available to allow the purpose of each link to be identified from link text alone,
      except where the purpose of the link would be ambiguous to users in general.

criteria.name: Section Headings
criteria.description: Section headings are used to organize the content.

criteria.name: Focus Not Obscured (Minimum)
criteria.description: New

criteria.name: Focus Not Obscured (Enhanced)
criteria.description: New

criteria.name: Focus Appearance
criteria.description: New

criteria.name: Pointer Gestures
criteria.description: All functionality that uses multipoint or path-based gestures for operation can be operated with a single pointer without a path-based gesture, unless a multipoint or path-based gesture is essential.

criteria.name: Pointer Cancellation
criteria.description: For functionality that can be operated using a single pointer, at least one of the following is true:

criteria.name: Label in Name
criteria.description: For user interface components with labels that include text or images of text, the name contains the text that is presented visually.

criteria.name: Motion Actuation
criteria.description: Functionality that can be operated by device motion or user motion can also be operated by user interface components and responding to the motion can be disabled to prevent accidental actuation, except when:

criteria.name: Target Size (Enhanced)
criteria.description: The size of the target for pointer inputs is at least 44 by 44 CSS pixels except when:

criteria.name: Concurrent Input Mechanisms
criteria.description: Web content does not restrict use of input modalities available on a platform except where the restriction is essential, required to ensure the security of the content, or required to respect user settings.

criteria.name: Dragging Movements
criteria.description: New

criteria.name: Target Size (Minimum)
criteria.description: New

criteria.name: Language of Page
criteria.description: The default human language of each web page can be programmatically determined.

criteria.name: Language of Parts
criteria.description:
The human language of each passage or phrase in the content can be programmatically determined except for proper names, technical terms, words of indeterminate language, and words
      or phrases that have become part of the vernacular of the immediately surrounding
     text.

criteria.name: Unusual Words
criteria.description: A mechanism is available for identifying specific definitions of words or phrases used in an unusual or restricted way, including idioms and jargon.

criteria.name: Abbreviations
criteria.description: A mechanism for identifying the expanded form or meaning of abbreviations is available.

criteria.name: Reading Level
criteria.description:
When text requires reading ability more advanced than the lower secondary education level after removal of proper names and titles, supplemental content, or a version that does not require reading ability more advanced than the lower
      secondary education level, is available.

criteria.name: Pronunciation
criteria.description:
A mechanism is available for identifying specific pronunciation of words where meaning of the
      words, in context, is ambiguous without knowing the pronunciation.

criteria.name: On Focus
criteria.description: When any user interface component receives focus, it does not initiate a change of context.

criteria.name: On Input
criteria.description: Changing the setting of any user interface component does not automatically cause a change of context unless the user has been advised of the behavior before using the component.

criteria.name: Consistent Navigation
criteria.description: Navigational mechanisms that are repeated on multiple web pages within a set of web pages occur in the same relative order each time they are repeated, unless a change is initiated by the user.

criteria.name: Consistent Identification
criteria.description: Components that have the same functionality within a set of web pages are identified consistently.

criteria.name: Change on Request
criteria.description: Changes of context are initiated only by user request or a mechanism is available to turn off such changes.

criteria.name: Consistent Help
criteria.description: New

criteria.name: Error Identification
criteria.description:
If an input error is automatically detected, the item that is in error is identified and the error
      is described to the user in text.

criteria.name: Labels or Instructions
criteria.description: Labels or instructions are provided when content requires user input.

criteria.name: Error Suggestion
criteria.description:
If an input error is automatically detected and suggestions for correction are known, then the suggestions
      are provided to the user, unless it would jeopardize the security or purpose of the
      content.

criteria.name: Error Prevention (Legal, Financial, Data)
criteria.description:
For web pages that cause legal commitments or financial transactions for the user to occur, that modify or delete user-controllable data in data storage systems, or that submit user test responses, at least one of
      the following is true:

criteria.name: Help
criteria.description: Context-sensitive help is available.

criteria.name: Error Prevention (All)
criteria.description: For web pages that require the user to submit information, at least one of the following is true:

criteria.name: Redundant Entry
criteria.description: New

criteria.name: Accessible Authentication (Minimum)
criteria.description: New

criteria.name: Accessible Authentication (Enhanced)
criteria.description: New

criteria.name: Parsing
criteria.description:
In content implemented using markup languages, elements have complete start and end
      tags, elements are nested according to their specifications, elements do not contain
      duplicate attributes, and any IDs are unique, except where the specifications allow
      these features.

criteria.name: Name, Role, Value
criteria.description:
For all user interface components (including but not limited to: form elements, links and components generated by scripts),
     the name and role can be programmatically determined; states, properties, and values that can be set by the user can be programmatically set; and notification of changes to these items is available to user agents, including assistive technologies.

criteria.name: Status Messages
criteria.description: In content implemented using markup languages, status messages can be programmatically determined through role or properties such that they can be presented to the user by assistive technologies without receiving focus.

Failure of Success Criterion 3.2.2 due to launching a new window without prior warning when the selection of a radio button, check box or select list is changed

Failure of Success Criterion 1.1.1 due to providing a text alternative that is not null (e.g., alt="spacer" or alt="image") for images that should be ignored by assistive technology
Failure due to using meta redirect with a time limit
Failure of Success Criterion 2.2.1, 2.2.4, and 3.2.5 due to using meta refresh to reload the page

Failure of Success Criterion 1.3.1 due to using structural markup in a way that does not represent relationships in the content
Failure of Success Criterion 2.4.3 due to using tabindex to create a tab order that does not preserve meaning and operability
Failure of Success Criterion 1.3.1 due to using th elements,  layout tables
Failure of Success Criterion 1.3.1 due to using the pre element to markup tabular information
Failure of Success Criterion 1.3.2 due to using an HTML layout table that does not make sense when linearized
Failure of Success Criterion 2.2.2 due to a script that causes a blink effect without a mechanism to stop the blinking at 5 seconds or less
Failure of Success Criterion 3.2.5 due to opening a new window as soon as a new page is loaded
Failure of Success Criterion 2.1.1 due to using only pointing-device-specific event handlers (including gesture) for a function
Failure of Success Criteria 2.1.1, 2.4.7, 2.4.13, and 3.2.1 due to using script to remove focus when focus is received

Failure of Success Criterion 4.1.2 due to using script to make div or span a user interface control in HTML without providing a role for the control
Failure of Success Criterion 3.2.5 due to launching a new window when a user enters text into an input field
Failure of Success Criterion 3.2.5 due to complete change of main content through an automatic update that the user cannot disable from within the content
Failure of Success Criterion 2.4.4 due to providing link context only in content that is not related to the link
Failure of Success Criterion 1.1.1 due to omitting the alt attribute or text alternative on img elements, area elements, and input elements of type "image"
Failure of Success Criterion 3.2.3 due to presenting navigation links in a different relative order on different pages
Failure of Success Criterion 1.1.1 and 1.2.1 due to providing long descriptions for non-text content that does not serve the same purpose or does not present the same information
Failure of Success Criterion 4.1.2 due to a user interface control not having a programmatically determined name

Failure of Success Criterion 1.1.1 due to using ASCII art without providing a text alternative
Failure of Success Criterion 1.4.1 due to creating links that are not visually evident without color vision
Failure of Success Criterion 1.2.2 and 1.2.8 due to not labeling a synchronized media alternative to text as an alternative

Failure of Success Criterion 1.4.11, 2.4.7 and 2.4.13 due to styling element outlines and borders in a way that removes or renders non-visible the visual focus indicator
Failure of Success Criterion 4.1.2 due to the focus state of a user interface component not being programmatically determinable or no notification of change of focus state available

Failure due to the accessible name not containing the visible label text
Failure due to locking the orientation to landscape or portrait view
Failure due to interactions being limited to touch-only on touchscreen devices
Failure of Success Criterion 2.1.4 due to implementing character key shortcuts that cannot be turned off or remapped
Failure of Success Criterion 1.3.4 due to showing a message asking to reorient device
Failure of Success Criterion 2.5.2 due to activating a control on the down-event
Failure of Success Criterion 1.4.10 due to content disappearing and not being available when content has reflowed
Failure of Success Criterion 4.1.3 due to providing status messages that cannot be programmatically determined through role or properties
Failure of Success Criterion 1.4.12 due to clipped or overlapped content when text spacing is adjusted
Failure of Success Criterion 2.5.1 due to providing functionality via a path-based gesture without simple pointer alternative
Failure due to inability to deactivate motion actuation
Failure of Success Criterion 1.3.5 due to incorrect autocomplete attribute values
Failure of Success Criterion 2.5.7 Dragging Movements due to not providing a single pointer method that does not require a dragging movement
Failure of Success Criterion 3.3.8 and 3.3.9 due to preventing password or code re-entry in the same format

testCases.name: Structural markup, not CSS, should modify content layout
testCases.description: Occurs whenever CSS is used instead of structural markup to modify the visual layout, thus changing the meaning of the content. The positioning properties of CSS display content at any position on the user's viewport and items have their order changed. ATs rely on the source code (or other programmatically determined order) to render content in the correct sequence; therefore, do not rely on CSS to visually position content in a specific sequence if this sequence results in a meaning that is different from the programmatically determined reading order.
testCases.result: If check #2 is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
For content which uses CSS for positioning:
1. Remove the style information from the document or turn off use of style sheets in the user agent.
2. Check that the reading order of the content is correct and the meaning of the content is preserved.

testCases.name: Images and styled text should convey structural info
testCases.description:
Occurs when: 
- A change in the appearance of text conveys meaning without using appropriate semantic markup
- Images of text are not enclosed in the appropriate semantic markup.
testCases.result:
- If check #1.1 is true, then #1.2 is true.
- If check #2.1 is true, then #2.2 is true.
testCases.steps:
1. For images of text:
- Check if any images of text are used to convey structural information of the document.
- Check that the proper semantic structure (e.g., HTML headings) is used with the text to convey the information.
2. For styled text that conveys information:
- Check if there is any styled text that conveys structural information.
- Check that in addition to styling, the proper semantic structure is used with the text to convey the information.

testCases.name: Background images should not convey important info
testCases.description: The CSS background-image property (designed for decorative purposes) should not associate text alt to images included via CSS. Applies to both background images declared in the HTML style attributes, as well as in cases where the background image declaration was created dynamically in a client script.
testCases.result: If checks #2 and #3 are both false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
1. Examine all images added to the content via CSS, HTML style attributes, or dynamically in script as background images.
2. Check that the images do not convey important information.
3. If an image does convey important information, the information is provided to assistive technologies and is also available when the CSS image is not displayed.

testCases.name: User should be able to pause blinking in plug-in or applet
testCases.description: When content rendered by a plug-in or contained in an applet blinks, the user should be able to pause the blinking. The plug-in, applet, nor the content itself should provide a mechanism to pause the content.
testCases.result: If check #1 is true and check #2 is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
For each page that has blinking content in a plugin or applet:
1. Determine if the content continues to blink for longer than 5 seconds.
2. Determine if there is a means to pause the blinking content.

testCases.name: Captions should include all the dialogues and important sounds
testCases.description: The caption should include all of the dialogue (either verbatim or its essence) as well as all important sounds.
testCases.result: If check #2 and check #3 are false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
1. View the material with captioning turned on.
2. Check that all dialogue is accompanied by a caption.
3. Check that all important sounds are captioned.

testCases.name: Removing focus from form elements should not cause change of context
testCases.description: When removing focus from a form element (such as, by moving to the next element), no change of context should occur.
testCases.result: If check #3, step #4, or step #5 is true, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
1. Find all form elements.
2. Go through them in order.
3. Check if the form submits when you move from one field to the next.
4. Check if moving from one field to the next launches any new windows.
5. Check if moving from one field to the next navigates to another screen.

testCases.name: Keyboard navigation should not get stuck in content formats
testCases.description: Multiple content formats may require one or more UAs or plug-ins are to successfully present the content to users. For example, a page that includes HTML, SVG, SMIL and XForms may require the browser to load different plug-ins to successfully interact with the content. Some plug-ins can cause keyboard focus to become "stuck", leaving a keyboard-only user with no way to return to the other content.
testCases.result: If the keyboard focus becomes "trapped," then this test case fails and content fails Conformance Requirement 5.
testCases.steps:
1. Using a keyboard, navigate through the content.
2. Check to see that the keyboard focus is not "trapped" and it is possible to move keyboard focus out of the plug-in content without closing the user agent or restarting the system.

testCases.name: Authentication forms data should not become lost after expiration
testCases.description: User authentication usually times out after a period of inactivity, so users with disabilities may require extra time to log in. Upon re-authentication, the state of the user's session should be restored, including all data previously entered into forms.
testCases.result: If check #3 is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
On a site where authentication is required, user input is collected, and which ends the user's session after a known period of inactivity:
1. Provide user input as required but allow the session to timeout, then submit the form.
2. When requested, re-authenticate with the server.
3. Determine if the function is performed using the previously submitted data.

testCases.name: Text alt should convey info conveyed by color differences
testCases.description: When an image uses color differences to convey info, the text alt for the image should convey that info.
testCases.result: If check #1 is true, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
For all images in the content that convey information by way of color differences:
1. Check that the information conveyed by color differences is not included in the text alt for the image.

testCases.name: Content should be identifiable by more than visual shape/location
testCases.description: Make content identifiable to visually impaired users through other methods than visual appearance or location alone, especially since the location of the content can vary if page layout varies due to variations in font, window, or screen size.
testCases.result: If check #2 is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
1. Examine the web page for textual references to content within the web page.
2. Check that the references do not rely on only the visual shape or location of the content.

testCases.name: Controls should support the accessibility API
testCases.description: Standard controls from accessible technologies usually use and support the accessibility API, and so should custom controls. Failure to do so causes ATs to fail to understand what the control is or how to operate it or may not even know of its existence.
testCases.result: If check #1 is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps: 1. Using the accessibility checker for the technology (or if that is not available, inspect the code using a browser's developer tools, or test with an assistive technology), check the controls to see if they support the accessibility API.

testCases.name: Users should be able to pause/resume moving/scrolling content
testCases.description: Moving or scrolling content that cannot be paused and resumed by visually impaired or cognitively disabled users can cause them to fail to perceive the content.
testCases.result: If step #1, step #3, step #4, or step #6 are false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
On a page with moving or scrolling content:
1. Check that a mechanism is provided in the web page or user agent to pause moving or scrolling content.
2. Use the pause mechanism to pause the moving or scrolling content.
3. Check that the moving or scrolling has stopped and does not restart by itself.
4. Check that a mechanism is provided in the web page or user agent to restart the paused content.
5. Use the restart mechanism provided to restart the moving content.
6. Check that the movement or scrolling has resumed from the point where it was stopped.

testCases.name: Text alt should update with non-text content
testCases.description: Wherever non-text content is updated, the text alt should be updated at the same time.
testCases.result: If check #1 is true, then the text alt is not up to date with the current item and this test case fails.
testCases.steps: 1. Check each text alt to see if it is describing content other than the currently-displayed non-text content.

testCases.name: Pop-ups or windows should not appear unrequested
testCases.description:
New windows or pop-ups should not appear unexpectedly or without being solicited by the user as they take the focus away. 
This technique does not apply when the user has previously interacted with a piece of UI and expects to get a new window.
testCases.result:
If check #2 is true, then this test case fails.
If check #5 is true and check #6 is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
1. Load the web page.
2. Check if new (additional) windows open.
3. Find every actionable element, such as links and buttons, in the web page.
4. Activate each element.
5. Check if activating the element opens a new window.
6. Check if elements that open new windows have associated text saying that will happen. The text can be displayed in the link, or available through a hidden association such as an HTML title attribute.

testCases.name: Users can stop automatic sound that plays 3 sec or more
testCases.description: Automatic sound should either automatically stop after being played for 3 seconds, or the user should be able to stop it.
testCases.result: If check #1 is not true, then the content fails Success Criterion 1.4.2.
testCases.steps: 1. Check that there is a mechanism, independent from the overall system volume control, to turn off any sound that plays automatically for more than three seconds.

testCases.name: Web page background/foreground colors should be specified
testCases.description: The creator of a web page should specify both foreground and background colors, but not necessarily on the same CSS rule. Since CSS color properties inherit from ancestor elements, it is sufficient if both foreground and background colors are defined either directly or through inheritance by the time that color is applied to a given element.
testCases.result: If check #2 is true but step #3 is false, or if check #3 is true but step #2 is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
1. Examine the code of the web page.
2. Check to see if an author-specified foreground color is present.
3. Check to see if an author-specified background color is present.
Note: Color and background color may be specified at any level in the cascade of preceding selectors, by external stylesheets or through inheritance rules. 
Background color may also be specified using a background image with the CSS property 'background-image' or with the CSS property 'background' (with the URI of the image, e.g., 'background: url("images/bg.gif")'). With background images, it is still necessary to specify a background color, because users may have images turned off in their browser. But the background image and the background color need to be checked.

testCases.name: Web page should have a title
testCases.description: The web page should have a title.
testCases.result: If check #1 is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps: 1. Check whether or not the web page has a meaningful title.

testCases.name: Title should identify web page contents or purpose
testCases.description: The web page title should correctly identify the contents or purpose of the web page.
testCases.result: If check #1 is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps: 1. Check whether the title of each web page identifies the contents or purpose of the web page.

testCases.name: Graphical symbols do not make content hard to comprehend
testCases.description: Graphical symbols used to convey info should not make content more difficult to comprehend to AT users. Graphical symbols can be images, images of text, pictorial/decorative character symbols ("glyph", check marks, arrows, etc.), smiley faces and so on. If graphical symbols are used to convey info, provide an alternative - such as a text alt.
testCases.result: If #1 is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
For each instruction that refers to non-text marks that convey info:
1. Check whether there are other means to determine the info conveyed by the non-text marks.

testCases.name: Text alt should properly represent non-text content
testCases.description: The text alt should be successfully used in place of the non-text content without losing info or function.
testCases.result: If check #1 is true, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps: 1. Check each text alt to see if it is not actually a text alt for the non-text content.

testCases.name: Labels/names/text alts should be consistent
testCases.description: Components that share the same function in different web pages should be labeled consistently.
testCases.result: If check #2 is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
1. In a set of web pages, find components with the same function that are repeated in multiple web pages.
2. For each component with the same function found in step #1, check that the naming is consistent.

testCases.name: White space characters should not visually format individual words
testCases.description:
White space characters (space, tab, line break, carriage return) fail to present meaningful sequences properly and should not visually format individual words. They should not be inserted to control letter spacing within a word. 
This does not apply to white space characters inserted into an initialism or between words.
testCases.result: If check #1 is true, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
For each word that appears to have non-standard spacing between characters:
1. Check whether any words in the text of the content contain white space characters.

testCases.name: White space chars should not be used to create columns
testCases.description: White space characters (space, tab, line break, or carriage return) should not format columns of data in text content as they fail to provide the information in natural reading order. Content should present data in a different layout; also, technology that provides structural elements to represent columnar data should be provided.
testCases.result: If check #2 is true, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
1. Examine the document for data or information presented in columnar format.
2. Check whether the columns are created using white space characters to lay out the information.

testCases.name: White space chars should not format tables
testCases.description: White space characters (space, tab, line break, or carriage return) should not format tables in text content as they fail to indicate that a cell is intended to be a header cell, to associate the table header cells with the table data cells, or to navigate directly to a particular cell in a table. White spaces that organize data in a visual table does not provide the info in a natural reading order in the source of the document.
testCases.result: If check #2 is true, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
1. Examine the document for visually formatted tables.
2. Check whether the tables are created using white space characters to layout the tabular data.

testCases.name: Forms should have Submit button, actionable with Enter key
testCases.description: Forms should not be designed to submit data automatically after the user has filled in all the fields or when focus leaves the last field. Forms should rely on the standard form behavior of the Submit button and the Enter key.
testCases.result: If check #3 is true, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
1. Enter data in all fields on page starting at top.
2. Enter data in last field and exit from it (tab out of it).
3. Check whether leaving the last field causes change of context.

testCases.name: New window opening after selecting form elements should be announced
testCases.description: When changing the selection of a radio button, a check box or an item in a select list should announce the opening of a new window via the Submit button or otherwise, to clearly indicate the expected action.
testCases.result: If check #3 is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
1. Find each form in a page.
2. For each form control that is a radio button, check box or an item in a select list, check if changing the selection of the control launches a new window.
3. For each new window resulting from step 2, check if the user is warned in advance.

testCases.name: Text alt should be null for images that should be ignored by AT
testCases.description: Images that should be ignored by ATs (images used for decoration, spacing or other purpose that is not part of the meaningful content) should have a null text alt (i.e., alt="" ).
testCases.result: If check #2 is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
1. Identify any img elements that are used for decoration, spacing or other purpose that is not part of the meaningful content in the page
2. Check that the alt attribute for these elements is null.

testCases.name: Server-side methods should be used to automatically redirect users
testCases.description: Avoid using meta http-equiv redirects with time delays since they create unexpected context changes that can interrupt and disorient users, but accept instant redirects with zero timeout since they are not perceived as context changes. Use server-side redirect methods instead of client-side meta redirects when possible, as they provide better user experience and avoid the accessibility issues associated with timed page refreshes that users cannot control or anticipate.
testCases.result:
1. If checks #1-5 are false, then this test case fails and the content fails Success Criterion 2.2.1.
2. If checks #1, #2, #4, and #5 are false, then this test case fails and the content fails Success Criterion 2.2.4.
3. If checks #1, #4, and #5 are false, then this test case fails and the content fails Success Criterion 3.2.5.
testCases.steps:
For a page that uses meta http-equiv="refresh":
1. Check that the numerical value for seconds until refresh in the content attribute is present.
2. Check that the numerical value for seconds until refresh in the content attribute is less than one or greater than 72,000.
3. Check if the page qualifies for Real-time or Essential Exceptions in Success Criterion 2.2.1 Timing Adjustable.
4. Check if the user is provided an opportunity to turn off, extend, or adjust the timing of the page refresh.
5. Check if the page does not redirect after the duration specified in the content attribute.

testCases.name: Server-side methods should be used to automatically redirect users
testCases.description: When meta http-equiv of refresh is used to periodically refresh pages or to redirect users to another page, the time interval should not be too short, and there should be a way to turn auto-refresh off.
testCases.result:
1. If checks #1-5 are false, then this test case fails and content fails Success Criteria 2.2.1.
2. If checks #1, #2, #4, and #5 are false, then this test case fails and the content fails Success Criterion 2.2.4.
3. If checks #1 and #4 are false, then this test case fails and content fails Success Criterion 3.2.5.
testCases.steps:
For a page that uses meta http-equiv="refresh":
1. Check that the numerical value for seconds until refresh in the content attribute is present.
2. Check that the numerical value for seconds until refresh in the content attribute is less than one or greater than 72,000.
3. Check if the page qualifies for Real-time or Essential Exceptions in Success Criterion 2.2.1 Timing Adjustable.
4. Check if the user is provided an opportunity to turn off, extend, or adjust the timing of the page refresh.
5. Check if the page does not refresh after the duration specified in the content attribute.

testCases.name: JavaScript link event handlers have "link" role
testCases.description: Use proper a and area elements to create accessible links instead of attaching JavaScript event handlers to non-link elements, since scripted pseudo-links cannot receive keyboard focus, are not recognized as links by UAs and AT, and do not appear in link lists that help users navigate content. Ensure all link interactive elements use semantic link markup so they are properly identified, focusable via keyboard, and accessible to all users including those using AT.
testCases.result:
If check #1 is false, then this test case fails and the content fails Success Criteria 1.3.1 and 4.1.2. 
If check #2 is false, then this test case fails and the content fails Success Criteria 2.1.1 and 2.1.3.
testCases.steps:
For all elements presented as links which use JavaScript event handlers to make the element emulate a link:
1. Check if the programmatically determined role of the element is "link".
2. Check if the emulated link can be activated using the keyboard.

testCases.name: Structural markup should be used for presentational effect
testCases.description:
When structural markup is used to achieve a presentational effect, is should not indicate relationships that do not exist in the content. 
Note: The use of HTML tables for layout is not such an example as long as the layout table does not include improper structural markup such as <th> or <caption> elements.
testCases.result: If check #1 is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps: 1. Check that the element's semantic meaning is exposed to assistive technology and appropriate for the content of the element.

testCases.name: Tab order should follow logical relationships and sequences
testCases.description: Focusable elements (links, form elements, etc.) have a tabindex attribute and should receive focus in the ascending order of the value of this tabindex attribute. This issue frequently occurs  when editing a page where tabindex has been used.
testCases.result: If check #1 is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps: 1. If tabindex is used, check that the tab order specified by the tabindex attributes follows relationships in the content.

testCases.name: A layout table should include th elements, summary attribute, or caption element
testCases.description: Use CSS-based layouts to separate presentation from content while preserving semantic meaning of HTML table elements. Avoid using structural markup elements (th elements, summary attributes, or caption elements) in layout tables since these are intended for data presentation, not visual formatting. When AT encounters these elements in layout tables, it attempts to present non-existent data relationships in a logical manner, causing confusion for users who expect actual tabular data rather than visual positioning.
testCases.result: If any of the checks is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
1. Examine the source code of the HTML or XHTML document for the table element.
2. If the table is used only to visually lay out elements within the content:
 a. Check that the table does not contain any th elements.
 b. Check that the table element does not contain a non-empty summary attribute.
 c. Check that the table element does not contain a caption element.

testCases.name: HTML pre elements should not be used to mark up tabular info
testCases.description: The HTML table element should be used to present tabular data instead of the HTML pre element.
testCases.result: If check #2 is true, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
1. Check to see if the pre element is used.
2. For each occurrence of the pre element, check whether the enclosed information is tabular.

testCases.name: HTML that controls tables should linearize correctly
testCases.description: CSS-based layouts, not layout tables, should be used to retain the defined semantic meaning of the HTML table elements and to separate presentation from content. If a layout table is used, however, the content should make sense when linearized, even in the case of nested tables.
testCases.result: If check #2 is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
1. Linearize the content in either of the following ways:
 - Present the content in source code order;
 - Remove the table markup from around the content.
2. Check that the linear reading order matches any meaningful sequence conveyed through presentation.

testCases.name: Users should control blinking and stop it in five seconds or less
testCases.description: Scripts can manage blinking content by toggling the content's visibility on and off at regular intervals, but scripts should include a mechanism to stop the blinking at 5 seconds or earlier.
testCases.result: If check #1 is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
For each instance of blinking content:
1. Determine if the blinking stops in 5 seconds or less.

testCases.name: New windows opening after web page reload should not get focus
testCases.description: When opening a new window to advertise a product or service, websites should ensure these pages do not disorient users by opening up one or more new windows that automatically receive focus as soon as a page is loaded.
testCases.result: If check #2 and check #3 are true, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
1. Load a new page.
2. Check to see whether a new window has been opened as a result of loading the new page.
3. Check to see whether the new window is automatically given focus.

testCases.name: Content should be accessible to alternate keyboards/keyboard emulators
testCases.description: Make content available for navigation to alternate keyboards/keyboard emulators. If a website only responds to mouse clicks and does not work with keyboard controls, then visually impaired or users who use alternative input devices are not able to use those functions.
testCases.result:
1. If check #1 is true, then this test case fails and the content fails Success Criterion 2.1.3.
2. If check #1 is true and check #2 is false, then this test case fails and the content fails Success Criteria 2.1.1 and 2.1.3.
testCases.steps:
1. Check to see whether pointing-device-specific event handlers are the only means to invoke scripting functions.
2. Check if the function being invoked requires input information about a specific path for a pointing device.

testCases.name: Content should receive visible focus
testCases.description: Content that normally receives focus when accessed by keyboard should not have focus removed by scripting when the system focus indicator is considered "unattractive".
testCases.result: If #2 is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
1. Use the keyboard to verify that you can get to all interactive elements using the keyboard.
2. Check that when focus is placed on each element, focus remains there until user moves it.

testCases.name: Users can turn off/extend/adjust web page timeout before URI redirection
testCases.description:
The timeout of websites that get refreshed (using server-side scripting languages which set the non-standard HTTP header "Refresh" with a time-out in seconds) and redirected (to a URI) should have a specified, reasonable time-out. The HTTP header that is set is Refresh: {time in seconds}; url={URI of new location}. 
It is also possible to omit the URI and obtain a periodically refreshing page, which causes the same problem. The HTTP header that is set is Refresh: {time in seconds}.
testCases.result: If check #1 is true and checks #2-3 are false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
1. Check to see if the web page automatically redirects to another page after some period of time without the user taking any action.
2. Check if the page qualifies for Real-time or Essential Exceptions in Success Criterion 2.2.1 Timing Adjustable.
3. Check if the user is provided an opportunity to turn off, extend, or adjust the timing of the page refresh.

testCases.name: When filling in a form, only error reporting windows open
testCases.description: Any window that opens after the user has filled in the wrong values should contain an explanatory error message and a button that closes the window, returning the focus to the initiating form element.
testCases.result: If check #3 is true and check #4 is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
1. Find all text input form fields.
2. Change the value in each form field.
3. Check if new windows open.
4. For any new windows that open, check if they contain an error message and a button that closes the window returning focus to the initiating form element.

testCases.name: Users can deactivate automatically updated content
testCases.description: Enable users to deactivate the automatic update of content in the main viewport. Change the code that generates the viewport content and test extensively.
testCases.result: If you reach step 8, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
TEST CASE 1:
1. Open the source code in an appropriate editing tool.
2. Examine the source code thoroughly.
3. Confirm that content is dynamically generated or the code will trigger a change of context for the viewport on an event or after a time period.
4. Confirm that there does not exist an appropriate mechanism for users to disable this behavior.
Expected Results: If checks #3 and #4 are true, then this failure condition applies and the content fails this Success Criterion

TEST CASE 2:
1. Measure or estimate the amount of time that the average user spends on the page.
2. Go to the page.
3. Wait for 10 times the length of time the average user stays on the page. (From Step 1).
4. Check to see if there is a change in context during this time.
5. If there is no change of context STOP.
6. If there is a change in context, then check to see if there is any mechanism on the page that would have prevented that change of context.
7. If there IS a mechanism for preventing that change of context, use that mechanism to prevent that change of context and run the test over.
8. If there is a change of context and there are no mechanism to prevent that change in context then you have a failure.

Note: One way to measure or estimate the amount of time in step 1 would be to check a web site's analytics to see how long the average user looks at the page.
An example of step 6 would be a mechanism for turning off auto updates.

testCases.name: Link context should be understood from related content
testCases.description: Avoid placing link context in content that is not programmatically associated with the link, since users cannot easily determine the link's destination when context requires leaving the link to search for additional info. Ensure link context is provided through programmatically determined methods like link text itself, surrounding paragraph or list item content, table cell and header associations, or preceding headings rather than requiring users to navigate away from the link to understand its purpose.
testCases.result: If check #1 AND check #2 are false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
Locate links where some additional link context is needed to understand the purpose of the link. For each link:
1. Check whether the context is contained in the same sentence, paragraph, list item, table cell, or associated table headers.
2. Check whether the link context can be programmatically determined in some other way, for example, by using a WAI-ARIA property such as aria-label, aria-labelledby or aria-describedby on the link to provide sufficient context.

testCases.name: img+area+input elements should have alt attributes/text alt
testCases.description: Give text alt to meaningful images so that AT can identify the image or convey its purpose to the user. Use the alt attribute and the WAI-ARIA attributes.
testCases.result: If all of #1, #2, #3 and #4 are false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
Identify img, area, and input elements of type image. For each of these elements:
1. Check if the alt attribute is present.
2. Check if aria-labelledby attribute is present AND references one or more id attributes in the page AND check if aria-labelledby is accessibility supported.
3. Check if the aria-label attribute is present AND check if aria-label is accessibility supported.
4. Check if the title attribute is present AND check if title is accessibility supported.

testCases.name: Links should be presented in the same order across pages
testCases.description: Navigation mechanisms that are repeated on multiple web pages should preserve the same order of links across all pages.
testCases.result: If check #1 is true and check #2 is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
1. Check to see if a navigation mechanism is being used on more than one web page.
2. Check the default presentation of the navigation mechanism on each page to see if the list of links is in the same relative order on each web page.
Note: "Same relative order" means that secondary navigation items may be in between the link items on some pages. They can be present without affecting the outcome of this test.

testCases.name: Non-text content long desc serves purpose, presents info
testCases.description: Long desc for non-text content should serve the same purpose or present the same info as the non-text content itself.
testCases.result: If check #1 is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
For all non-text content that requires a long desc:
1. Check that the long desc serves the same purpose or presents the same information as the non-text content.

testCases.name: UI control should have programmatically determined name
testCases.description: The name of form controls should be exposed to AT in multiple ways, including the label element, by the use of the title attribute and aria-label/aria-labelledby. Button controls can have a name assigned in other ways, but in certain situations may require the use of label, title, aria-label, or aria-labelledby.
testCases.result: If all options of check #1 are false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
For all input, textarea, and select elements in the web page (except inputs of type hidden, submit, reset, or button:
1. Check that each element has a programmatically determined name using one of the following ways:
  a. The text label or labels are programmatically associated with the control element via the aria-labelledby attribute (each id given as a value in the aria-labelledby attribute matches the id of the text label element).
  b. The control is programmatically determined through the value of its aria-label attribute.
  c. The text label is contained in a label element that is correctly associated to the respective input element via the label's <for> attribute (the id given as value in the for attribute matches the is of the input element).
  d. The control is contained within a label element that also contains the label text.
  e. The control is an input of type image and the alt attribute provides a text label.
  f. The control is programmatically determined through the value of the title attribute.

testCases.name: Changing text size should not clip, truncate, or obscure text
testCases.description: Changing the size of text should not clip, truncate, or obscure the text (text should be responsive to resize).
testCases.result: If check #2 is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
The Working Group has discovered many misunderstandings about how to test this failure and they are planning to revise this failure in a future update. Until then, if the content passes the success criterion using any of the listed sufficient techniques, then it does not meet this failure.
1. Increase the text size of the content by 200%.
2. Check that no text is clipped, truncated, or obscured.

testCases.name: Look-alike glyphs that represent text should have text alt
testCases.description: Glyphs (visual representations, or shape of a character) of visually similar characters should not be used as replacements for the correct ones. For example, the Unicode characters U+0033 and U+04E0 both look like the number "3", yet the latter is actually a letter from the Cyrillic alphabet.
testCases.result: If look-alike glyphs are used, and there is not a text alt for any range of text that uses look-alike glyphs, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
1. Check the characters or character entities used to represent text.
2. If the characters used do not match the appropriate characters for the displayed glyphs in the human language of the content, then look-alike glyphs are being used.

testCases.name: ASCII art should have text alt
testCases.description: When text alt is not provided, ASCII art should not be used. Text alts, or links to them, should be placed near the ASCII art in order to be associated with it.
testCases.result: If check #2 is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
1. Access a page with ASCII art.
2. For each instance of ASCII art, check that it has a text alt.

testCases.name: Links should be identifiable by users with color vision deficiency
testCases.description: Links should be underlined or highlighted in other ways than just color differences to accommodate people who cannot perceive color differences.
testCases.result: If check #1 is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps: 1. Check that each link in the page that is identifiable by color (hue) is visually identifiable via some other means (e.g., underlined, bolded, italicized, sufficient difference in lightness, etc.).

testCases.name: Synchd media alt should be labeled with the text they are alternatives for
testCases.description: Synced media alts should be clearly labeled with the text for which they are alternatives so that users can find them easily.
testCases.result: If check #2 is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
1. Check pages that provide synced media alts to text.
2. Check that synced media is clearly labeled with the text for which it is an alternative.

testCases.name: Synced media alt should give extra info
testCases.description: Synced media alts should provide more info than the text for which they are alternatives and should also provide their own text alts to provide extra info.
testCases.result: If check #2 is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
1. Check for captions on synced media alts.
2. Check that the synced media alt does not provide more information than is presented on the page in text.
Note: Synced media alts often use different words to present what is on the page but it should not present new info on the topic of the page.

testCases.name: Visual focus should remain visible
testCases.description: Another visual focus indicator should be provided when turning off or rendering non-visible the UA's default visual indication of keyboard focus. Avoid styling that could make it difficult to see the focus indicator even though it is present.
testCases.result: If check #2 is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
1. Set the focus to all focusable elements on a page using the keyboard.
2. Check that the focus indicator is visible.

testCases.name: UI focus state should be PD, should notify of focus change
testCases.description: When navigating websites or apps, ATs such as screen readers and magnifiers need to know which element is currently selected so they can help users interact with the right component. While browsers automatically handle this for standard buttons and forms, it is recommended that you manually program custom-built components to communicate focus changes to ATs.
testCases.result: If either check #1 or check #2 is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
1. Using the accessibility checker for the technology (or if that is not available, inspect the code or test with an assistive technology), check the controls to see if they expose the focus state through the accessibility API.
2. Using the accessibility checker for the technology (or if that is not available, inspect the code or test with an assistive technology), check whether assistive technology is notified when focus moves from one control to another.

testCases.name: Text and forms should support 200% resize
testCases.description: Changing the size of text should cause text-based form controls to resize accordingly. Text-based form controls include input boxes (text and textarea), as well as buttons.
testCases.result: If check #3 is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
1. Enter some text into text-based form controls that receive user entered text.
2. Increase the text size of the content by 200%.
3. Check that the text in text-based form controls has increased by 200%.

testCases.name: Required/error fields marked with color differences should have alt
testCases.description: A required or error field should not be marked with color differences only. Alternatives should be provided to identify the required or error field to accommodate people who are blind or colorblind.
testCases.result: If check #1 is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
For all required fields or error fields in the web page that are identified using color differences:
1. Check that a non-color way to identify the required field or error field is provided.

testCases.name: Phone number fields should be understandable and intuitive
testCases.description: People with visual or cognitive disabilities should recognize phone number fields and understand what info to provide to fill in the fields. Even if all the fields have programmatically determined names, a text label must identify the set of fields as a phone number.
testCases.result: If both checks #1 and #2 are false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
1. For each set of phone number fields in the web page that represents a single phone number, check that the set of fields are labeled with a visible text label that is positioned near the set of phone number fields.
2. For each set of phone number fields in the web page that represent a single phone number, instructions are provided about how to fill in the fields.

testCases.name: Background images should provide sufficient contrast with foreground text
testCases.description: People with low vision should be able to read text displayed over a background image. There should be sufficient contrast between the background image and the text. Pictures need sufficient contrast between the text and those parts of the image that are most like the text and behind the text.
testCases.result: If the Quickcheck is false and #2 is false as well, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
1. Quickcheck: First do a quick check to see if the contrast between the text and the area of the image that is darkest (for dark text) or lightest (for light text) meets or exceeds that required by the Success Criterion (1.4.3 or 1.4.5). If the contrast meets or exceeds the specified contrast, then there is no failure.
2. If the Quickcheck is false, then check to see if the background behind each letter has sufficient contrast with the letter.

testCases.name: Certain links ("click here", "more") can change to specific text
testCases.description: Links should not use vague text like "click here" or "more" without any way to understand where they lead without reading the surrounding context. This creates problems for screen readers and users who tab through links, since they often navigate by jumping directly between links and will only hear the unhelpful repeated phrases like "click here, click here, click here" without knowing what each link actually does. Suggested fix: Click here for more information on the Rocky Mountains.
testCases.result: If check #2 is true AND #3 is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
1. Examine each link on the page.
2. Check to see if it has nondescript link text such as "click here" or "more" whose purpose can be determined from the surrounding text but not from the link text alone.
3. Check to see if there is a mechanism on the page which turns all nondescript links on the page into descriptive links.

testCases.name: Dialogs/menus are adjacent to their trigger control in navigation order
testCases.description: A dialog or menu interface component embedded on the page should open in a way that makes it easy for a keyboard user to operate, following the sequential navigation order. When opening the dialog or menu, the next action should be to interact with the dialog or menu.
testCases.result:
1. If both points under step 1 are false, then this test case fails.
2. If both points under step 2 are false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
Steps: For each menu or dialog embedded on a web page that is opened via a trigger control:
1. Activate the trigger control via the keyboard.
 - Check whether focus is in the menu or dialog.
 - Check whether advancing the focus in the sequential navigation order puts focus in the menu or dialog.
2. Dismiss the menu or dialog.
 - Check whether focus is on the trigger control.
 - Check whether advancing the focus backwards in the sequential navigation order puts focus in the trigger control.

testCases.name: Each part (subfield) of a multi-part form should have a name
testCases.description: The parts of multi-part form fields should have individual names.
testCases.result: If check #1 is false for any subfield, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
For each subfield in the multi-part form field:
1. Check that there is a programmatically determined name for the field.

testCases.name: Content should not be justified (aligned both left and right)
testCases.description: Content should not be fully justified (aligned to both the left and the right margins) as it becomes more difficult to read.
testCases.result: If check #2 is false, then this test case fails and the content fails to meet Success Criterion 1.4.8.
testCases.steps:
1. Open the page in a common browser.
2. Verify that content is not justified (aligned to both the left and the right margins).

testCases.name: Image link should have accessible name
testCases.description: When a link contains only non-text content (e.g., an image), that link should be identifiable by an accessible name, defined according to the Accessible Name and Description Computation. When both text and images are used separately on a page to link to the same target, they should be combined to reduce the number of separate links and the undesirable redundancy.
testCases.result: If all checks are true, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
1. Check whether the link contains only non-text content.
2. Check whether the non-text content has been implemented in a way that it can be ignored by assistive technologies, such as using role="presentation" or alt="" .
3. Check that the link does not have an accessible name provided in another way such as aria-label or aria-labelledby.

testCases.name: Data + header cells should be correctly determined
testCases.description: Link data cells to their header cells in complex tables using the id and headers attributes, especially important for tables with multiple levels of headings. When these attributes are set up incorrectly (often due to copying code without updating the IDs), AT cannot determine which headers belong to which data.
testCases.result: If check #1 is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps: 1. For tables that associate data cells to header cells via the id and headers attributes, check that the programmatic association is correct.

testCases.name: Table headers should be properly marked up
testCases.description: Data tables should use header elements (th) or other appropriate table mark-up (the scope attribute, headers and ID, ARIA columnheader and rowheader) roles to make the headers programmatically determinable from within table content. Screen readers navigate through the table content horizontally or vertically, so the headers that change can be read out.
testCases.result: If all checks are false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
For all data tables, check if table headers can be correctly programmatically determined by use of one of the following mechanisms:
 1. headers marked up with table header (th) elements.
 2. scope attributes on th for tables with more than a single row or column of table headers.
 3. headers and data cells associated using headers and id attributes.
 4. headers marked up as td elements with the scope attribute.
 5. headers marked up with ARIA role attributes rowheader or columnheader.

testCases.name: Presentation role is applied to info/relationship elements
testCases.description: Avoid applying role="presentation" to an element whose purpose is to convey information, such as a data table or an image. role="presentation" hides the element's meaning from ATs, preventing users from understanding the content as it removes crucial information from the content.
testCases.result: If true, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps: 1. Check if an element which conveys information, structure, or relationships through its semantic markup has the attribute role="presentation".

testCases.name: User should be able to stop HTML media that plays 3 sec or more
testCases.description: When using the autoplay attribute on audio or video elements with audio tracks, also use the muted attribute and provide controls or commands to pause or stop media resources. Automatic playback without user control can disorient users, particularly those using AT.
testCases.result: If checks #1-5 are true, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
1. Check if an audio or video element has an active audio track.
2. Check if the audio or video lasts longer than 3 seconds.
3. Check if the element has an autoplay attribute.
4. Check if the element does not have a muted attribute.
5. Check if no command or control has been provided to stop or pause the media element.

testCases.name: Text should rescale when viewport units are used on text
testCases.description: Viewport units (vw, vh, vmin, vmax) should not be used as the primary method for setting font-size in CSS. These units are relative to the viewport and prevent resizing text through browser zoom or text-size controls. Limited uses of viewport units are acceptable, but not on text sizing, because only methods that completely override the CSS will work, potentially causing layout collapse or text overlap. Instead, use relative units like em, rem, or percentages that respect user preferences for text sizing.
testCases.result: If the last step is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
1. Visit the page to be tested.
2. Use any of the following methods to resize text when available:
 - the zoom feature of the browser,
 - the text-sizing feature of the browser,
 - on-page controls for resizing text.
3. Check that the text resizes by one of the methods above, and can be resized up to 200% of the default.

testCases.name: Content should be hoverable
testCases.description: The user should be able to move the pointer over the additional content that appears on hover. For users of screen magnification software, the new content is often not fully visible in the current magnified section; in order to perceive it, users should be able to move the pointer away from the trigger and over the additional content, and thereby change the position of the magnified section, without this content disappearing.
testCases.result: If #1 and #2 are false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
For each area of additional content that appears on pointer hover:
1. The pointer can be moved over the new content without the additional content disappearing.
2. The appearance of the additional content is controlled by the user agent, not the author.

testCases.name: The name of a control should match the visible label
testCases.description: The visible label text of controls should appear exactly within their accessible name. Techniques like aria-label, aria-labelledby, or offscreen text can provide additional context for screen readers, but they must not completely replace or override the visible label, but supplement it so the visible text remains part of the accessible name. Follow the Accessible Name and Description Computation algorithm to verify that your implementation preserves the visible label within the accessible name, allowing speech input users to reliably activate controls.
testCases.result: If checks #1 and #2 are false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
For all controls with a visible label (e.g., link text, button text, programmatically linked label, images in links with text), check that:
1. The accessible name is the same as the visible label.
2. The accessible name contains a match for the string of the visible label.

testCases.name: Content is not restricted to single orientation (portrait/landscape)
testCases.description: Content should support both portrait and landscape reorientations. However, if a specific orientation is determined to be essential to operate and view the content, then this technique does not apply.
testCases.result: If check #1 or check #2 is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
1. Open the content in landscape view. Check that the content is oriented for this view.
2. Open the content in portrait view. Check that the content is oriented for this view.
3. Check if portrait or landscape view is essential for the viewing and operation of the content.
4. If there are any controls in the content, user agent, operating system, or device that restrict or allow orientation changes, check that the controls can be set to allow checks #1 and #2 to be true.

testCases.name: Touchscreen devices should be able to use other input modalities
testCases.description: Users of touchscreen devices should be able to use other input modalities (such as an additional/external mouse or keyboard) to interact with the web content. Touchscreens should allow users to operate the content using their other (possibly preferred) input mechanisms.
testCases.result: If checks #2 or #3 are false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
1. Open the content on a device with a touchscreen and at least one additional input modality - this includes touch-enabled laptops and touchscreen devices (smartphones or tablets) with a paired external keyboard and mouse.
2. Check that all interactive controls can be operated using not only the touchscreen, but also the additional input mechanisms (keyboard and mouse).
3. If the presence of the touchscreen caused interactive controls not to be displayed (compared to the same content when viewed on a device without a touchscreen), check that there are alternative controls/ways for users of other additional input mechanisms to operate the content.

testCases.name: Single character key shortcuts should support turn off
testCases.description: Avoid keyboard shortcuts that use only single keys (letters, punctuation, numbers, or symbols) without modifier keys, as these can be inadvertently triggered by voice command users when speaking.
