If single character shortcuts must be implemented, enable users to either turn them off or remap them to combinations that include modifier keys like Alt or Ctrl. However, this requirement does not apply when shortcuts are only active while UI elements like select menus have focus, where single keys are appropriately used for navigation within the focused element.
testCases.result: If check #4 is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
If the site does not provide settings to disable or remap keyboard shortcuts:
1. If loading the page sets focus to an input, click on an empty part of the page to ensure that no inputs are in focus.
2. Press keys identified by the author as shortcut keys, or if this information is not available, press all printing characters (i.e., all number, letter, sign and punctuation keys). Do not press non-printing modifier and control keys such as Ctrl, Alt, Esc, Arrow keys and (where present) the function keys F1-F12. Also exempt are Space, Enter, Return, Tab, and the Delete key.
3, Hold the Shift key and press the same keys again.
4. Check whether a function has been triggered by pressing the keys.

testCases.name: Content orientation should adjust automatically
testCases.description: When a device is reoriented in a manner considered undesirable, the content should reorient itself automatically instead of displaying a message telling the user to reorient the device.
testCases.result: If check #1 or #2 is true, and check #3 is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
1. Open the content in landscape view. Check if a message appears asking to reorient the device.
2. Open the content in portrait view. Check if a message appears asking to reorient the device.
3. Check if portrait or landscape view is essential for the viewing and operation of the content.

testCases.name: Down-events should execute functionality
testCases.description: Authors should use click short events rather than down-events (mousedown, touchstart, or pointerdown) for triggering functionality, as down-events run immediately when a user presses but has not yet released a mouse button or touches a screen, preventing users from canceling accidental activation. If down-events must be used, provide mechanisms to undo, cancel, or reverse the action on the corresponding up-event, unless the immediate response is essential for functionality (such as musical instrument simulations or gaming controls). This ensures users can recover from unintended interactions and meets the requirements for pointer cancellation.
testCases.result: If #1 is true, and #2 and #3 are false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
Open the content on a device with pointer inputs (mouse, touchscreen, stylus) and for all available controls (buttons, links, complex widgets):
1. Trigger down-events (e.g. by pressing but not releasing the mouse button, or placing a finger or stylus on the touchscreen) and check if functionality is executed prior to the up-event (e.g. releasing the mouse button or lifting the finger/stylus).
2. If functionality was executed on the down-event, check if triggering the up-event (releasing the pressed mouse button, or lifting the finger or stylus from the touchscreen) reverses the outcome.
3. Evaluate if it could be deemed essential for the controls to execute and complete functionality on the down-event.

testCases.name: When reflowed, content should remain visible
testCases.description: When a link contains only non-text content (e.g., an image), that link should be identifiable by an accessible name, defined according to the Accessible Name and Description Computation. When both text and images are used separately on a page to link to the same target, they should be combined to reduce the number of separate links and the undesirable redundancy.
testCases.result: If #3 is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
1. Check visible content elements at a desktop viewport width such as 1280px.
2. Set the viewport width to 320px by narrowing the browser window, or by zooming in so that the viewport width is now 320px (when starting with a 1280px viewport width at 100% browser zoom, this can be done by zooming in to 400%).
3. For each content element that is not provided at the viewport width of 320px, check that there is a way to reach the same or equivalent content via disclosure widgets, pop-ups, or links to other views.

testCases.name: Status messages should be PD through role or properties
testCases.description: Status messages should be communicated to ATs by applying appropriate WAI-ARIA roles/properties, such as role="status", role="alert", aria-live="polite", or aria-live="assertive". First verify that dynamic content meets the definition of a status message, then implement the appropriate ARIA markup and test with AT like screen readers.
testCases.result: If #1 through #4 are all true, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
For content that is dynamically added to the page:
1. Check that the element containing the updated content does not take focus
2. Check that the new content provides information to the user on one of the following:
- the success or result of an action
- the waiting state of an application
- the progress of a process
- the existence of errors
3. Check that the element containing the new content does not have a pre-existing aria role of status, alert, or log, or an aria-live attribute.
4. Check that the status message is not surfaced (i.e., announced) by AT.

testCases.name: User should be able to override text spacing
testCases.description: Parts of the content should not be clipped and become unreadable when the user overrides the spacing of the text within the boundaries set out in the Text Spacing success criterion. In general, this situation occurs when text is presented in a size-constrained block which does not expand if the size of the content increases.
testCases.result: If check #3 is true, then this test case fails.

testCases.name: Path-based gesture should have simple pointer alternative
testCases.description: Functions operated via path-based gestures should have alternative ways of operating via simple pointer gestures. Path-based gestures are discoverable by exploring the content on a touch screen, or checking the page code for the existence of specific event handlers such as touchstart or touchend.
testCases.result: If check #1 is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
For each part of the content that implements a function that can be activated by a path-based gesture:
1. Check that controls are available through which the same function can be carried out via simple taps or clicks.

testCases.name: Motion actuation can be deactivated
testCases.description: Users should have the capability to deactivate motion actuation so that, when accidentally activating sensors due to tremors or other motor impairments, users can prevent accidental triggering of functions.
testCases.result: If checks #1 and #2 are false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
For each function that is triggered by a motion sensor:
1. Check if the use of a motion sensor is essential or required to make the function accessibility supported.
2. Check if there is a user setting which disables the motion detection.

testCases.name: Autocomplete forms should have correct inputs
testCases.description: Form inputs should have the correct autocomplete attribute values for inputs that request information about the user of the form.
testCases.result: If checks #1 and #2 are false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
For each form field which collects information about the user of the form:
1. Check that the form field has an autocomplete attribute and value pair that does not match the purpose of the input.
2. Check that the input purpose is not communicated programmatically through any other method.

testCases.name: Users should be able to use other functions than drag-and-drop
testCases.description: Alternative single pointer input methods should be provided for any functionality that requires dragging. Acceptable alternatives include single pointer interactions (such as clicking to select an item, opening a dropdown menu, and selecting the destination) or providing buttons to move items between positions.
testCases.result: If #2 is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
1. Check the interface for the presence of functions triggered by dragging movements.
2. Check that there is a single pointer input alternative to operate the same function.

testCases.name: Login passwords or codes should preserve the initial format
testCases.description: Users should not be required to authenticate by entering a password or code in a different format from what was originally created unless alternative authentication methods are available. The string to be entered could include a password, verification code, or any string of characters the user has to remember or record to authenticate.
testCases.result: If checks #1 and #2 are true, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
For each form field which accepts password or code entry:
1. Check if the structure of the input field(s) prevents the user from pasting or auto-filling the entire password or code in the format in which it was originally created.
2. Confirm that no other acceptable authentication methods are present that satisfy Success Criteria 3.3.8 or 3.3.9 (such as an authentication method that does not rely on a cognitive function test).

testCases.name: Sticky content should not hide focus elements
testCases.description: Keyboard users who tab through links and controls should be able to see where the indicator is at. 'Sticky' content that moves with the viewport should not obscure other elements on the page, including controls the user may tab to.
testCases.result: If #1 is true, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
Tab through the links and controls on the page. Both progressing down through the page, and back up:
1. Check whether the focused element is completely obscured by other content.

testCases.name: Web page has audio desc or media alt
testCases.description: An alternative for time-based media or audio desc of the prerecorded video content is provided for synced media, except when the media is a media alt for text and is clearly labeled as such.
testCases.result: If check #1 is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
For each time-based media:
1. Check that time-based media has text alt or (for video content) audio desc.
Note: This case does not apply to audio files that work as descriptions of text, clearly marked as such.

testCases.name: Live media has captions
testCases.description: All live audio content in synced media is provided with captions.
testCases.result: If check #1 is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
For each time-based media:
1. Check that time-based media has text alt or (for video content) audio desc.
Note: This case does not apply to audio files that work as descriptions of text, clearly marked as such.

testCases.name: Prerecorded video content has audio desc in synced media
testCases.description: Prerecorded video content has audio desc in synced media.
testCases.result: If check #1 is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
For each video content:
1. Check that each video content has audio desc.

testCases.name: Audio content has sign language interpretation
testCases.description: Sign language interpretation is provided for all prerecorded audio content in synced media.
testCases.result: If check #1 is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
For each prerecorded audio content: 
1. Check that sign language interpretation is provided.

testCases.name: Prerecorded video content has extended audio desc
testCases.description: Wherever pauses in foreground audio are insufficient to allow audio descs to convey the sense of the video, extended audio desc is provided for all prerecorded video content in synced media.
testCases.result: If check #1 is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
For each prerecorded video content: 
1. Check that extended audio description is provided whenever pauses in foreground audio are insufficient to allow audio descs to convey the sense of the video.

testCases.name: Audio content has alt
testCases.description: An alt for time-based media that presents equivalent info for live audio-only content is provided.
testCases.result: If check #1 is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
For each live audio-only content: 
1. Check that an alt for time-based media that presents equivalent info is provided.

testCases.name: Purpose of UI components is programmatically determined
testCases.description: In content implemented using markup languages, the purpose of user interface components, icons, and regions can be programmatically determined.
testCases.result: If check #1 is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
For content implemented using mark-up languages: 
1. Make sure the purpose of icons, regions and UI components has been programmatically determined.

testCases.name: Text, not images of text, conveys important info
testCases.description:
Text is used to convey information rather than images of text except for the following:
- Customizable: The image of text can be visually customized to the user's requirements;
- Essential: A particular presentation of text is essential to the information being conveyed.
Note: Logotypes (text that is part of a logo or brand name) are considered essential.
testCases.result: If check #2 is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
1. Locate images of text.
2. If the image of text is not customizable by the user and not essential to the information being conveyed, it should be replaced by regular text.

testCases.name: Audio has low or no background sound
testCases.description:
Prerecorded audio-only content that contains primarily speech in the foreground, is not an audio CAPTCHA or audio logo, and is not vocalization intended to be primarily musical expression such as singing or rapping, has either no background noise or has sound turn off button.
20 dB: The background sounds are at least 20 decibels lower than the foreground speech content, with the exception of occasional sounds that last for only one or two seconds.
Note: Per the definition of "decibel," background sound that meets this requirement will be approximately four times quieter than the foreground speech content.
testCases.result: If checks #2 and #3 are false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
1. Locate prerecorded audio-only content. 
2. Make sure the audio content has either no background noise or has sound turn off button.
3. Make sure the background sounds are at least 20 decibels lower than the foreground speech content, except for occasional sounds that last for only one or two seconds.

testCases.name: Images of text are purely decorative unless essential
testCases.description:
Images of text are only used for pure decoration or where a particular presentation of text is essential to the information being conveyed.
Note: Logotypes (text that is part of a logo or brand name) are considered essential.
testCases.result: If check #2 is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
1. Locate images of text.
2. Make sure images of text are used only for purely decorative purposes.

testCases.name: All content is operable through keyboard
testCases.description: All functionality of the content is operable through a keyboard interface without requiring specific timings for individual keystrokes.
testCases.result: If check #1 is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps: 1. Make sure the entire web page content is keyboard navigation friendly.

testCases.name: With exceptions, website has no timing
testCases.description: Timing is not an essential part of the event or activity presented by the content, except for non-interactive synced media and real-time events.
testCases.result: If check #2 is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
1. Identify web page timers and timing-dependent features. 
2. Make sure that, except for non-interactive synced media and real-time events, timing is not an essential part of the event or activity presented by the content.

testCases.name: Users are warned inactivity could cause data loss
testCases.description:
Users are warned of the duration of any user inactivity that could cause data loss, unless the data is preserved for more than 20 hours when the user does not take any actions.
Note: Privacy regulations may require explicit user consent before user identification has been authenticated and before user data is preserved. In cases where the user is a minor, explicit consent may not be solicited in most jurisdictions, countries or regions. Consultation with privacy professionals and legal counsel is advised when considering data preservation as an approach to satisfy this success criterion.
testCases.result: If check #1 is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps: 1. Make sure users are warned that inactivity could cause loss of data entered on the web page.

testCases.name: Flashing content observes parameters
testCases.description:
Web pages should not contain anything that flashes more than three times in any one second period, or the flash is below the general flash and red flash thresholds.
Note: Since any content that does not meet this success criterion can interfere with a user's ability to use the whole page, all content on the web page (whether it is used to meet other success criteria or not) must meet this success criterion. See Conformance Requirement 5: Non-Interference.
testCases.result: If check #1 is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps: 1. Make sure flashing web page content flashes three times or less within a second, or the flash is below the general flash and red flash thresholds.

testCases.name: Web page content flashes three times or less
testCases.description: Web pages do not contain anything that flashes more than three times in any one second period.
testCases.result: If check #1 is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps: 1. Make sure flashing web page content flashes three times or less within a second.

testCases.name: Non-essential motion animation can be deactivated
testCases.description: Motion animation triggered by interaction can be disabled, unless the animation is essential to the functionality or the information being conveyed.
testCases.result: If check #1 is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps: 1. Make sure non-essential motion animation triggered by interaction can be disabled.

testCases.name: Mechanism bypasses repeating blocks of content
testCases.description: A mechanism is available to bypass blocks of content that are repeated on multiple web pages.
testCases.result: If check #6 is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
1. Identify content blocks that repeat across pages (such as navigation menus, headers, sidebars, or promotional content). 
2. On the first page, use keyboard navigation to locate any skip links or bypass mechanisms.
3. Activate the bypass mechanism (such as "Skip to main content" link) and verify that focus moves appropriately to the main content area, effectively bypassing the repeated content blocks.
4. Count the number of tab stops required to reach the main content both with and without using the bypass mechanism
5. Repeat this test on the other pages to ensure the bypass mechanism works consistently across different pages with the same repeated content.
6. Verify that the bypass mechanism is present and functional, allowing users to skip repeated content blocks and jump directly to unique page content with fewer navigation steps.

testCases.name: Web page can be located by more than one way
testCases.description: More than one way is available to locate a web page within a set of web pages except where the web page is the result of, or a step in, a process.
testCases.result: If check #3 is false, then this test case fails.

testCases.name: Headings and labels are semantically correct
testCases.description: Headings and labels are used in a semantically correct way.
testCases.result: If checks #2 and #3 are false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
1. Find all the headings and labels.
2. Make sure that headings have text and are used in a hierarchical way that is readable by AT.
3. Make sure labels have text and are assigned to fields.

testCases.name: Headings and labels describe topic or function
testCases.description: Topics or functions are described by headings and labels.
testCases.result: If checks #1 and #2 are false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
1. Check that all headings accurately describe the content that follows in their sections.
2. Check that all labels (form labels, button text, link text, etc.) clearly indicate the purpose or function of their associated control or content.

testCases.name: Users are notified of their location on web page
testCases.description: Information about the user's location within a set of web pages is available.
testCases.result: If check #2 is false, then this test case fails.

testCases.name: Web page has section headings
testCases.description:
Section headings are used to organize the content. 
Note 1: "Heading" is used in its general sense and includes titles and other ways to add a heading to different types of content.
Note 2: This success criterion covers sections within writing, not user interface components. User interface components are covered under Success Criterion 4.1.2.
testCases.result: If check #1 is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps: 1. Make sure each web page section is provided with a heading.

testCases.name: Focused UI components are not obscured
testCases.description: When a user interface component receives keyboard focus, no part of the component is hidden by author-created content.
testCases.result: If check #6 is false, then this test case fails.

testCases.name: Size of pointer is at least 44 by 44 CSS pixels
testCases.result: If check #1 is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps: 1. Make sure the size of the target for pointer inputs is at least 44 by 44 CSS pixels (not including the exceptions).

testCases.name: Size of pointer target is at least 24 by 24 CSS pixels
testCases.result: If check #1 is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps: 1. Make sure the size of the target for pointer inputs is at least 24 by 24 CSS pixels (not including the exceptions).

testCases.name: Default language of each web page can be PD
testCases.description: The default human language of each web page can be programmatically determined.
testCases.result: If check #1 is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
1. Examine the HTML source code of the web page to locate language declarations.
2. Check for the presence of the lang attribute on the <html> element (e.g., <html lang="en"> for English).

testCases.name: Language of passages/phrases can be PD
testCases.description: The human language of each passage or phrase in the content can be programmatically determined except for proper names, technical terms, words of indeterminate language, and words or phrases that have become part of the vernacular of the immediately surrounding text.
testCases.result: If check #5 is false, then this test case fails.

testCases.name: Mechanism identifies definitions
testCases.description: A mechanism is available for identifying specific definitions of words or phrases used in an unusual or restricted way, including idioms and jargon.
testCases.result: If checks #2, #3, #4 and #5 are false, then this test case fails.

testCases.name: Mechanism identifies meaning of abbreviations
testCases.description: A mechanism for identifying the expanded form or meaning of abbreviations is available.
testCases.result: If checks #2, #3, and #4 are false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
1. Scan the page content for abbreviations.
2. Check for mechanisms to identify the expanded form or meaning of abbreviation.
3. Test that the mechanism is functional and accessible via keyboard navigation.
4. Confirm that the mechanism is consistently available throughout the site for similar specialized terms.

testCases.name: Web page has simplified version
testCases.description: When text requires reading ability more advanced than the lower secondary education level after removal of proper names and titles, supplemental content, or a version that does not require reading ability more advanced than the lower secondary education level, is available.
testCases.result: If checks #2 and #3 are false, then this test case fails.

testCases.name: Mechanism identifies specific pronunciation
testCases.description: A mechanism is available for identifying specific pronunciation of words wherever the meaning of the words, in context, is ambiguous without knowing the pronunciation.
testCases.result: If check #2 is false, then this test case fails.

testCases.name: Help mechanisms occur in identical order across web pages
testCases.result: If check #2 is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
1. Identify the presence of any help mechanisms (human contact mechanisms, FAQ sections, help documentation, tutorials, chatbots) across multiple pages.
2. Make sure help mechanisms appear in the same relative order across multiple pages within the same page variation, unless changes are user-initiated.

testCases.name: Input error is described
testCases.description: If an input error is automatically detected, the item that is in error is identified and the error is described to the user in text.
testCases.result: If check #2 is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
1. Locate forms that perform automatic validation and trigger input errors (e.g., by leaving fields empty, entering wrong formats, etc.).
2. Check that each field with an error is clearly identified and the error info is accessible via keyboard navigation and screen readers.

testCases.name: Input correction is suggested
testCases.description: If an input error is automatically detected and suggestions for correction are known, then the suggestions are provided to the user, unless it would jeopardize the security or purpose of the content.
testCases.result: If check #2 is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
1. Locate forms that perform automatic validation and trigger input errors (e.g., by leaving fields empty, entering wrong formats, etc.).
2. Check that each field with an error provides appropriate suggestions on how to successfully fill in the forms.

testCases.name: Web pages have error prevention mechanisms
testCases.result: If check #1 is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
On pages that involve critical actions (e.g., legal agreements, binding commitments, financial transactions): 
1. Make sure at least one error prevention mechanism exists (operations are reversible, checked, confirmed).

testCases.name: Web page has context-sensitive help
testCases.description: Context-sensitive help is available whenever the web page contains complex processes, irreversible actions, specialized terminology, complex UI or error-prone scenarios.
testCases.result: If check #1 is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps: 1. Identify the presence of context-sensitive help.

testCases.name: Web pages have input error prevention mechanisms
testCases.result: If check #1 is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
On pages that require the user to submit info (e.g., legal agreements, binding commitments, financial transactions) 
1. Make sure at least one error prevention mechanism exists (operations are reversible, checked, confirmed).

testCases.name: Web page handles redundant entries
testCases.description:
Info previously entered by or provided to the user that is required to be entered again in the same process is either:
- Auto-populated, or
- Available for the user to select.
Except when:
- Re-entering the information is essential;
- The information is required to ensure the security of the content, or
- Previously entered information is no longer valid.
testCases.result: If check #2 is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
On multi-step processes where users enter info that might be needed again later:
1. Complete the initial steps of the process, entering info (such as  name, address, shipping addresses). 
2. Check that wherever subsequent steps in the same process require the same info the previously entered info is either auto-populated or available for selection (from dropdowns, radio buttons, or selectable options).

testCases.name: ARIA attributes are valid
testCases.description: The ARIA attributes used are valid for each element. No deprecated or incorrect aria rules are applied to any element
testCases.result: If any of the checks are false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
For all elements on a page, check that:
1. The aria attributes used are valid for the element.
2. The aria attributes used are not deprecated.
3. The id attribute used in aria and in labels is unique.

For all elements with an aria role attribute, check that:
1. The aria attributes used are not prohibited.
2. All required aria attributes are used.
3. The role value used is valid.
4. The role value used is appropriate for the element.
5. If role='text' is used, the element should not have focusable descendants.

testCases.name: Elements have accessible names
testCases.description: Ensure all elements have an accessible name.
testCases.result: If any of the checks are false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
Ensure that:
1. Every ARIA button, link and menuitem has an accessible name.
2. Every ARIA input field has an accessible name.
3. Every ARIA meter node has an accessible name.
4. Every ARIA progressbar node has an accessible name.
5. Every ARIA toggle field has an accessible name.
6. Every ARIA tooltip node has an accessible name.
7. Buttons have discernible text.
8. <iframe> and <frame> elements have an accessible name.
9. <iframe> and <frame> elements contain a unique title attribute.
10. Input buttons have discernible text.
11. Links have discernible text.
12. The select element has an accessible name.
13. Summary elements have discernible text.
14. Every ARIA dialog and alertdialog node has an accessible name.
15. Every ARIA treeitem node has an accessible name.

testCases.name: ARIA roles with required children on parent elements
testCases.description: If an element has an ARIA role that requires chidren nodes or parent nodes, then these nodes are present for that element.
testCases.result: If checks #1 or #2 are false, then this test case fails.

testCases.name: Form field labels are visible and unique
testCases.description: All form field elements should have a label that is visible. There must not be multiple labels for the same element.
testCases.result: If check #1 is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
For all form field elements:
1. Each element must have only one label associated to it that is visible, and not solely labeled via an invisible label.

testCases.name: No forced inline spacing
testCases.description:
Ensure that text spacing set through style attributes can be adjusted with custom stylesheets. Inline spacing style attribute include:
  - line-height
  - letter-spacing
  - word-spacing.
testCases.result: If check #1 is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
For all elements that use the inline style attribute:
1. The inline style attribute that controls spacing must not be forced using '!important;'.

testCases.name: Text scaling and zooming should not be deactivated
testCases.description: Users should be allowed to scale and zoom the contents on the page up to 200%.
testCases.result: If check #1 is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps: 1. Zoom in on the page and check that zooming till atleast 200% is possible.

testCases.name: Scrollable elements should be focusable
testCases.description: Elements on a page that are scrollable should be focusable via a keyboard.
testCases.result: If check #2 is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
1. Find all elements on a page that are scrollable.
2. For each element, use the keyboard to see if the element can be focused through tabbing.

testCases.name: Client-side, not server-side image maps should be used
testCases.description: Server-side image maps are not keyboard accessible, and should not be used. Server side image maps pass the coordinates of the mouse click to the server-side script used to process the image map. Because they rely on mouse clicks, they are not keyboard accessible, whereas client-side image maps are keyboard accessible.
testCases.result: If check #2 is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
1. Find all image elements.
2. Check to make sure that server-side image maps are not used, and only client-side image maps are present.

testCases.name: aria-braille elements must have non-braille equivalent
testCases.description: If an element uses an aria-braille attribute, it must also have a non-braille equivalent of that attribute.
testCases.result: If check #2 is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
1. Find all elements that use an aria-braille attribute.
2. Check to make sure that those elements also use a non-braille aria attribute equivalent to the braille attribute.

testCases.name: Interactive controls must not be nested
testCases.description: Nested interactive controls can cause issues as they are not always announced by screen readers or they can cause focus problems for AT.
testCases.result: If check #2 is false, then this test case fails.
testCases.steps:
1. Find all interactive controls on the web page.
2. Check to make sure that they do not have focusable descendants.

remediations.name: The aria-describedby provides PD, descriptive info about UI elements
remediations.description:
WAI-ARIA aria-describedby property should provide programmatically determined, descriptive information about a UI element using an ID reference list containing one or more unique element IDs. 
Refer to ARIA in HTML for more info on providing WAI-ARIA States and Properties with HTML.

examples.name: Example 1: Using aria-describedby to associate instructions with form fields
examples.description: Sample form field using aria-describedby to associate instructions with form fields while there is a form label.
examples.code: Your first name is sometimes called your "given name".

examples.name: Example 2: Using aria-describedby to provide detailed info about the button
examples.code:
Select the font faces and sizes to be used on this page
Select the colors to be used on this page
Customize the layout and styles used on this page

remediations.name: Mandatory field marked with aria-required provides descriptive info
remediations.description: Mandatory elements are often marked visually (via text or non-text symbol, color/styling) but they should also be programmatically determinable as part of the field's name using the WAI-ARIA aria-required property, which can have values of true or false. For example, if a user must fill in an address field, then aria-required should be set to true.

examples.name: Example 1: The required property is indicated by an asterisk placed in the label element
examples.code: Note: * denotes a required field

examples.name: Example 2: The required property is indicated by the word "required" placed next to the label element
examples.code:
(required)
(required)
(required)
(required)
(required)

examples.name: Example 3: Required fields are indicated by a red border around the fields and a star icon rendered via CSS using ::after
examples.description: This example uses custom radio buttons with role=radio. The CSS properties are available below the form.
examples.code:
Please send an alert when balance exceeds $3,000.

  • Yes
  • No

remediations.name: WAI-ARIA role exposes the role of UI components
remediations.description: To define the role of an element, use the role attribute with one of the non-abstract values defined in the WAI-ARIA Definition of Roles. When rich internet applications define new UI widgets, exposing the roles enables users to understand the widget and how to interact with it.

examples.name: Example 1: A simple toolbar
examples.description: A toolbar containing three buttons. The div element has the role of "toolbar", and the img elements have "button" roles:

examples.name: Example 2: A Tree Widget
examples.description: A basic tree widget. Note the use of the roles "tree", "treeitem", and "group" to identify the tree and its structure. Here is a simplified excerpt from the code:
examples.code:
• Birds
  • Cats
    • Siamese
    • Tabby
  • Dogs
    • Small Breeds
      • Chihuahua
      • Italian Greyhound
      • Japanese Chin
    • Medium Breeds
      • Beagle
      • Cocker Spaniel
      • Pit Bull
    • Large Breeds
      • Afghan
      • Great Dane
      • Mastiff

remediations.name: WAI-ARIA state and property attributes expose the state of UI components
remediations.description:
Use WAI-ARIA state and property attributes to expose the state, properties, and values of UI components, so that they can be read and set by AT. Exposing the state and property attributes enables users to understand the widget and how to interact with it. 
For more information, see the WAI-ARIA specifications.

examples.name: Example 1: A toggle button
examples.description: A widget with role button acts as a toggle button when it implements the attribute aria-pressed. When aria-pressed is true, the button is in a "pressed" state. When aria-pressed is false, it is not pressed. If the attribute is not present, the button is a simple command button.
examples.code: Mute ...

examples.name: Example 2: A slider
examples.description: A widget with the role "slider" lets a user select a value from within a given range. The slider represents the current value and the range of possible values via the size of the slider and the position of the handle. These properties of the slider are represented by the attributes aria-valuemin, aria-valuemax, and aria-valuenow.
examples.code:
Red
...

remediations.name: Objects readable by AT have aria-label tag
remediations.description:
Provide labels for objects that can be read by AT, such as the aria-label attribute; However, aria-label may be disregarded by AT when aria-labelledby is used for the same object. Moreover, aria-label will override any native naming such as alt on images or labels associated with a form field using the for attribute. 
For more information on the naming hierarchy, see the accessible name and description computation section of the Accessible Name and Description Computation recommendation.

examples.name: Example 1: Distinguishing navigation landmarks
examples.description: The following example shows how aria-label can be used to distinguish two navigation landmarks in an HTML document, where there are more than two of the same type of landmark on the same page, and there is no existing text on the page that can be referenced as the label.
examples.code:
• ...a list of links here ...
  • ...a list of links here ...

examples.name: Example 2: Identifying region landmarks
examples.description: The following example shows how a generic "region" landmark might be added to a weather portlet. There is no existing text on the page that can be referenced as the label, so it is labelled with aria-label.
examples.code: ...

examples.name: Example 3: Providing a label for Math
examples.description: Below is an example of a MathML function, using the math role, appropriate label, and MathML rendering:
examples.code: 6 4 = 1.5

remediations.name: The purpose of focusable elements is described using aria-labelledby
remediations.description: The aria-labelledby attribute uses visible text on the page as a label for interactive elements (like links or form controls) by referencing the text element's ID. You can combine multiple text elements by listing their IDs in the aria-labelledby value, and the text will be joined together in this order. This technique replaces the element's original text completely, so if you want to keep the original text too, include the element's own ID in the list.

examples.name: Example 1: Providing additional information for links
examples.description: This example will mean that the link text as shown on screen is then used as the start of the accessible name for the link. Screen readers will announce this as: "Read more ...Storms hit east coast" and will display that same text in the links list which is very useful for screen reader users who may browse by links.
examples.code:
Storms hit east coast

Torrential rain and gale force winds have struck the east coast, causing flooding in many coastal towns. Read more...

examples.name: Example 2: Concatenating link text from multiple sources
examples.description: There may be cases where an author will place a tag around a section of code that will be referenced.
examples.code: Download 2012 Sales Report: PDF | Word | PowerPoint

remediations.name: The purpose of a link is described using aria-label
remediations.description:
Describe the purpose of a link using the aria-label attribute, which can place a descriptive text label on an object, such as a link, when there are no elements visible on the page that describe the object. If descriptive elements are visible on the page, then use aria-labelledby instead of aria-label. 
Per the Accessible Name and Description Computation and the Accessible Name and Description Computation in the HTML Accessibility API Mappings 1.0, the aria-label text will override the text supplied within the link.

examples.name: Example 1: Describing the purpose of a link in HTML using aria-label.
examples.description: In some situations, designers may choose to lessen the visual appearance of links on a page by using shorter, repeated link text such as "read more". These situations provide a good use case for aria-label in that the simpler, non-descriptive "read more" text on the page can be replaced with a more descriptive label of the link. The words 'read more' are repeated in the aria-label (which replaces the original anchor text of "[Read more...]") to allow consistent communication between users.
examples.code:
Neighborhood News

Seminole tax hike: Seminole city managers are proposing a 75% increase in property taxes for the coming fiscal year. [Read more...]

Baby Mayor: Seminole voters elect the city's youngest mayor ever by voting in 3 year old Willy "Dusty" Williams in yesterday's mayoral election. [Read more...]

remediations.name: All visual objects in text nodes are defined by aria-labelledby
remediations.description: Provide a name for all visual objects using the aria-labelledby property for native and non-native elements, such as custom text inputs constructed with div contenteditable="true", especially when a meaningful name should consist of more than one text string. Authors give unique IDs to different text elements on the page, then list those IDs in the aria-labelledby attribute to create a combined label that screen readers will read as one continuous name. This technique is useful when you want to build labels from multiple pieces of text, like combining table headers with input fields, or when there's no room for traditional visible labels next to form controls.

examples.name: Example 1: A time-out input field with concatenated name
examples.description: A text input allows users to extend the default time before a time-out occurs.
examples.code: minutes

examples.name: Example 2: A simple data table with text inputs
examples.description: A simple data table containing text inputs. The input labels are concatenated through aria-labelledby referencing the respective column and row headers.
examples.code:
Taxpayer Spouse
W2 Gross
Dividends

examples.name: Example 3: A conference workshop booking table
examples.description: A conference workshop booking table with two parallel tracks allows users to select the workshop they want to attend. When tabbing through the checkbox inputs in the table, the track (1 or 2), the title, and the speaker of the workshop followed by the adjacent checkbox label "Attend" are provided as concatenated name for the checkboxes via aria-labelledby.
examples.code:
Dinosaur Conference workshops timetable Thursday, 14 & Friday, 15 March 2013

Dinosaur Conference workshop booking table
Track Thursday Friday
9 to 12 AM 2 to 5 PM 9 to 12 AM 2 to 5 PM
Track 1

The Paleozoic era

2 places left

The Mesozoic era overview

2 places left

The Triassic period, rise of the dinosaurs

1 place left

The Jurassic period

11 places left
Track 2

The Cretaceous period

18 places left

The end of the dinosaurs

2 places left

First discoveries of dinosaurs

2 places left

Emerging scholarship

19 places left

remediations.name: Short desc of elements readable by AT have aria-labelledby attribute
remediations.description: Provide a short desc for elements readable by AT using the aria-labelledby attribute, which associates an element with text that is visible elsewhere on the page by using an ID reference value that matches the id attribute of the labeling element. ATs use the text of the element identified by the value of the aria-labelledby attribute as the text alt for the element with the attribute.

examples.name: Example 1: Providing a short desc for a complex graphic
examples.description: This example shows how to use the aria-labelledby attribute to provide a short text desc for a read-only complex graphic of an star rating pattern; the graphic is composed of several image elements. The text alternative for the graphic is the label, visible on the page beneath the star pattern.
examples.code: 4 of 5

remediations.name: ARIA landmarks are used to identify regions of a page
remediations.description: Use landmark roles through the role attribute to programmatically identify page sections and provide AT users with efficient navigation that allows them to orient themselves and skip repeated content blocks. Insert landmarks using role values on elements that mark sections, label identical roles when multiple instances exist, and include all page content within landmarks so screen readers can navigate sections without losing track of content, supplementing native semantic markup while enabling AT to bypass repetitive elements like navigation menus.

examples.name: Example 1: Simple landmarks
examples.description: The following example shows how landmarks might be added to an HTML document:
examples.code:
site logo and name, etc. here
search functionality here
a list of navigation links here
a sign-up form here
the page's main content here
a sponsor's promotion here
sidebar content here
site contact details, copyright information, etc. here

examples.name: Example 2: Multiple landmarks of the same type and aria-labelledby
examples.description: The following example shows a best practice of how landmarks might be added to an HTML document in situations where there are two or more of the same type of landmark on the same page. For instance, if a navigation role is used multiple times on a page, each instance may have a unique label specified using aria-labelledby:
examples.code:
Site

  • nav link 1
  • nav link 2
  • nav link 3

Related Topics

  • topic link 1
  • topic link 2
  • topic link 3

examples.name: Example 3: Multiple landmarks of the same type and aria-label
examples.description: The following example shows a best practice of how landmarks might be added to an HTML document in situations where there are two or more of the same type of landmark on the same page, and there is no existing text on the page that can be referenced as the label:
examples.code:
• nav link 1
  • nav link 2
  • nav link 3
  • tag link 1
  • tag link 2
  • tag link 3

examples.name: Example 4: Search form
examples.description: The following example shows a search form with a "search" landmark. The search role typically goes on the form element or a div surrounding the form:
examples.code:
<form role="search">
  <label for="product-search" id="search-label">Search</label>
  <input id="product-search" placeholder="title, author, or ISBN" type="text">
  <button type="submit">Find Books</button>
 </form>

remediations.name: Webpage headings are marked with proper attributes
remediations.description: Mark headings for ATs by applying role="heading" to headings and pair it with the aria-level property. When possible, use native heading markup (h1 element rather than <div role="heading" aria-level="1">), which has implicit styling and features that will not necessarily be replicated with ARIA equivalents.

examples.name: Example 1: Simple headings
examples.description: This example demonstrates how to implement headings using role="heading" and aria-level.
examples.code:
Global News Items
... a list of global news with editorial comment....
Politics
... a list of global political news stories ...

examples.name: Example 2: Additional heading levels
examples.description: This example demonstrates how to implement a level 7 heading using role="heading" and the aria-level attribute. Since HTML only supports headings up to level 6, there is no native element to provide these semantics.
examples.code:
Fruit Trees
Apples

Apples grow on trees in areas known as orchards...

...
Jonagold

Jonagold is a cross between the Golden Delicious and Jonathan varieties...

remediations.name: Mark regions and landmarks with aria-labelledby
remediations.description: Provide names for regions of a page that can be read by AT using the aria-labelledby attribute. Landmark roles (or "landmarks") programmatically identify sections of a page, helping AT users orient themselves to a page and help them navigate easily to various sections of a page. Like aria-describedby, aria-labelledby can accept multiple ids to point to other regions of the page using a space separated list. It is also limited to ids for defining these sets.

examples.name: Example 1: Identify a landmark with on-page text
examples.description: Below is an example of aria-labelledby used on a complementary Landmark. The region of the document to which the heading pertains could be marked with the aria-labelledby property containing the value of the id for the header.
examples.code:
Top News Stories

...

examples.name: Example 2: Identification for Application landmarks
examples.description: The following code snippet is for application landmarks with static prose. If you have a regional landmark of the type application and static descriptive text is available, then, on the application landmark, include an aria-describedby reference to associate the application and the static text, as shown here:
examples.code:
Calendar

This calendar shows the game schedule for the Boston Red Sox.

...

remediations.name: Use aria-label wherever visible labels cannot be used
remediations.description: The aria-label attribute provides accessible names for interactive elements when there is no visible text label, such as an 'X' button for closing popups or when using non-standard HTML elements like contentEditable divs instead of regular form inputs. This technique ensures screen reader users understand the purpose of these elements even when visual design choices or custom implementations do not include visible labels.

examples.name: Example 1: A close button in a pop-up box
examples.description: On a page, a link displays a pop-up box (a div) with additional information. The 'close' element is implemented as a button containing merely the letter 'X'. The property aria-label="close" is used to provide an accessible name to the button.
examples.code: This is a pop-up box.

examples.name: Example 2: A phone number with multiple fields
examples.code: Work Phone +

remediations.name: The aria-describedby attribute provides image descs
remediations.description: Images are provided with descs whenever short text alt fails to convey the function or information provided in the object. WAI-ARIA can associate descriptive text with a section, drawing, form element, picture, and so on by using the aria-describedby property, which is separate from the short name provided via the alt attribute in HTML. Like aria-labelledby, aria-describedby can accept multiple IDs to point to other regions of the page using a space separated list, whilst also being limited to IDs for defining these sets.

examples.name: Example 1: Describing an image
examples.description: The following example shows how aria-describedby can be applied to an image to provide a long desc, where that text desc is on the same page as the image.
examples.code: This painting dates back to 1889 and is oil on canvas. It was created by John Singer Sargent, and represents ...

remediations.name: UI controls can be read by AT
remediations.description: UI controls need to be given names so they can be read by AT. WAI-ARIA provides a way to associate text with a section, drawing, form element, picture, and so on, using the aria-labelledby property. Just like aria-describedby, aria-labelledby can accept multiple IDs to point to other elements of the page using a space separated list, making aria-labelledby especially useful for using info from the surrounding context to identify a control.

examples.name: Example 1: Labelling a simple text field
examples.description: The following is an example of aria-labelledby used on a simple text field to provide a label in a situation where there is no text available for a dedicated label but there is other text on the page that can be used to accurately label the control.
examples.code:
<input name="searchtxt" type="text" aria-labelledby="searchbtn">
 <input name="searchbtn" id="searchbtn" type="submit" value="Search">

examples.name: Example 2: Labelling a slider
examples.description: Below is an example of aria-labelledby used to provide a label for a slider control. In this case the label text is selected from within a longer adjacent text string. Please note that this example is simplified to show only the labeling relationship; authors implementing custom controls also need to ensure that controls meet other success criteria.
examples.code: Please select the number of days for your trip

examples.name: Example 3: A label from multiple sources
examples.description: The following example of aria-labelledby with multiple references uses the label element. For additional detail on concatenating multiple sources of information into a label with aria-labelledby, please view the technique Using ARIA labelledby to concatenate a label from several text nodes.
examples.code: days in advance

remediations.name: Form controls are identified using grouping roles
remediations.description: Mark up a set of related controls within a form as a group. Any label associated with the group also serves as a common label (or qualifier) for individual controls in the group. ATs can indicate the start and end of the group and the group's label as one navigates into and out of the group. For a group of radio buttons, use role="radiogroup" instead of role="group". The group can be labeled using aria-labelledby. This technique is not meant for wrapping all controls on a form within a single container with role="group".

examples.name: Example 1: Social Security Number
examples.description: Social security number fields which are nine digits long and broken up into three segments can be grouped using role="group".
examples.code: Social Security Number (required) - -

examples.name: Example 2: Identifying radio groups
examples.description: This example demonstrates use role=radiogroup. Note also that the radio buttons are custom controls with role=radio. One may optionally employ CSS to place a border around groups of such fields to visually reinforce the group relationship. The CSS properties are available below the form.
examples.code:
Set Alerts for your Account

Send an alert when balance exceeds $3,000

Yes
No

Send an alert when a charge exceeds $250

Yes
No

remediations.name: The aria-alertdialog element identifies errors
remediations.description:
Use role="alertdialog" to notify that an input error has occurred using a modal with the following characteristics:
- aria-label or aria-labelledby attribute gives the alertdialog an accessible name.
- The alertdialog contains at least one focusable element, and the focus should move to that element when the alertdialog opens.
- The tab order is constrained within the alertdialog whilst it is open.
- When the alertdialog is dismissed, the focus moves back to the position it had before the alertdialog opened, if possible.
The alertdialog should not be accessed by AT until needed. Do this by not including it in the static HTML, instead insert it into the DOM via script when the error condition is triggered.

examples.name: Example 1: Alert dialog
examples.description: This example shows how a notification using role="alertdialog" can be used to notify someone they have entered invalid information.
examples.code:
Error

Employee's Birth Date is after their hire date. Please verify the birth date and hire date.

remediations.name: The role=alert or live regions identify errors
remediations.description: Use the aria-live attribute to notify ATs when an input error occurs and are injected into a Live Region container. The content within the aria-live region is automatically read by AT, without the AT having to focus on the place where the text is displayed.

examples.name: Example 1: Injecting error messages into a container with role=alert already present in the DOM
examples.description: The following example uses role=alert which is equivalent to using aria-live=assertive.

remediations.name: Generic region role is assigned to section, is programmatically identifiable
remediations.description:
To make UA and ATs able to programmatically identify it, assign a generic region role to a page section so that the section that contains content of significance becomes readily discoverable and navigable. The generic region should be used when the section cannot be marked up using a standard document landmark role (see ARIA11).
It is important to name regions using aria-labelledby, aria-label, or another technique because they are generic grouping elements and users will need some way to tell which region they are in.

examples.name: Example 1: Region on a news website
examples.description: A section on the home page of a news website that contains a poll that changes every week is marked up with role="region". The h3 above the form is referenced as the region's name using aria-labelledby.
examples.code:
This week's Poll

Do you believe the tax code needs to be overhauled?
See Poll Results

examples.name: Example 2: Identifying a region on a banking site
examples.description: A user can expand links on a bank website after logging in to see details of term deposit accounts. The details are within a span marked up with region role. The heading for the region has role=heading and is included in the aria-labelledby that names the region.
examples.code:
1. Certificate Of Deposit
    Account: 25163522
    Start date: February 1, 2014
    Maturity date: February 1, 2016
    Deposit Amount: $ 3,000.00
    Maturity Amount: $ 3,072.43

examples.name: Example 3: Identifying a portlet with a generic region
examples.description: This example shows how a generic region landmark might be added to a weather portlet. There is no existing text on the page that can be referenced as the label, so it is labelled with aria-label.
examples.code: ...

remediations.name: The "aria-invalid" element indicates error fields
remediations.description: Use aria-invalid to specifically identify fields that have failed validation when the error description does not programmatically identify the failed fields, or the failed fields are not identifiable by some users. The aria-invalid="true" attribute tells screen readers that a form field has validation errors when other programmatic error associations are not possible due to design or framework constraints. This attribute must be set dynamically after validation fails (not before), and while it is not strictly required when visible error text is properly associated with the field, it can still provide helpful additional information to AT users.

examples.name: Example 1: Using aria-invalid on required fields
examples.description: The aria-invalid attribute is used on required fields that have no input. A message above the form conveys that form submission has failed due to this.

examples.name: Example 2: Identifying errors in data format
examples.description: Aria-invalid and aria-describedby are used together to indicate an error when the personal identification number (PIN), email address, or start date are not in the expected format. The error message is associated with the field using aria-describedby, and aria-invalid makes it easier to programmatically find fields with errors.
examples.code: Error: Incorrect data

remediations.name: Webpage uses role=status to present application's status message
remediations.description: The role="status" attribute creates a live region that automatically announces status updates to AT users without requiring focus, making it ideal for messages like "Changes have been saved" or form validation feedback. This role has default settings that make announcements politely (not interrupting other content) and atomically (reading the entire container contents), though adding aria-atomic="true" explicitly is recommended for better compatibility across different AT environments.

examples.name: Example 1: Including a search results message
examples.description: After pressing the Search button, the page content is updated to include the results of the search, which are displayed in a section below the Search button. The change to content also includes the message "5 results returned" near the top of this new content. This text is given an appropriate role for a status message. A screen reader will announce "5 results returned".
examples.code: 5 results returned.

examples.name: Example 2: Updating the shopping cart status
examples.description:
After pressing the Add to Shopping Cart button, content near the Shopping Cart icon updates to read "1 items". The container for this text (in this case a

) is marked with the role of status. Because it adds visual context, the shopping cart image with succinct and accurate alt text is also placed in the container. Due to the aria-atomic value, a screen reader will announce "Shopping cart, six items".
examples.code: 0 items

remediations.name: Webpage uses role=log to identify sequential info updates
remediations.description: The role="log" attribute creates a live region that automatically announces new content added to sequential information like chat messages, error logs, or history lists without requiring AT users to navigate to that location. This role has default settings that make announcements politely (not interrupting other content) and only reads the new additions rather than the entire container contents, making it perfect for ongoing streams of information.

examples.name: Example 1: Updating the contents of a chat conversation
examples.description: Comments that users type into a chat input field are appended to the end of the chat history region. The region is marked with the role of log so that new additions are announced by ATs. When each new chat message appears, a screen reader should announce its content (depending on AT/browser compatibility).
examples.code:
Chat History

  • The latest chat message

examples.name: Example 2: Updating the log of a server
examples.description: An application log records time-stamped activities. The log is exposed in the app as a view, with the region marked with the role of log so that the new additions are announced by the ATs. (The default value for the aria-relevant attribute is "additions", so the removal of the old top entries due to log size limitations will not be announced). When each new log entry is added, a screen reader announces it.
examples.code:
Recent activity

  • 08:03 UserX logged off

remediations.name: Icon fonts are differentiated from general font (text) usage
remediations.description: The role="img" attribute on icon fonts helps identify them as meaningful images rather than text, preventing them from disappearing when users override fonts for better readability. This technique allows user stylesheets to exclude icon fonts from font replacements by using CSS selectors like :not([role="img"]), ensuring that important visual icons remain visible while still allowing users to customize text fonts for their needs.

examples.name: Example 1: Star Icon Font used as an indicator (not interactive)
examples.description: In this example, a star icon is used to indicate a favorite. It is not interactive and does not disappear if the user overrides the font family via CSS.

examples.name: Example 2: Two colored / stacked star Icon Font used as an indicator
examples.description: In this example, a two-colored star icon is created by stacking two fonts with different colors on top of each other. This way it is possible to mimic only half the star is filled. It is not interactive and does not disappear if the user overrides the font family via CSS.

examples.name: Example 3: Email Icon Font in a link WITHOUT visible text
examples.description: In this example, an email icon is in a link with no visible text. It does not disappear if a user overrides the font family. The icon font is identified by AT as a "link image" and the name "Email" (keyboard or mouse).

examples.name: Example 4: Multiple Icon Fonts as part of another sematic element WITH visible text
examples.description: This example already has a visible text label in the link to be used as an accessible name, the mail and chevron font icons must stay visible when the font family is changed. This can be done by ensuring the icons are contained in their own element and the attribute aria-hidden="true" is used, so the font icons will be ignored by ATs.

remediations.name: Webpage uses redundant keyboard and mouse events
remediations.description: Create interactive hover and focus effects on decorative images by using device-independent events that work for both mouse and keyboard users. Attach JavaScript event handlers (onmouseover, onmouseout, onfocus, onblur) to elements to change the image source when users interact with them, ensuring that keyboard users experience the same visual feedback as mouse users when navigating through interactive elements.

examples.name: Example 1
examples.code:
Mouse over or tab to the links below and see the image change.

W3C Web Accessibility Initiative & W3C Internationalization

remediations.name: Users can toggle non-essential alerts optional
remediations.description: Users can toggle whether updates are automatically announced by screen readers by switching the aria-live property between "assertive" (for announcements) and "off" (for silence). Toggle buttons use aria-pressed to indicate whether announcements are enabled or disabled, giving users control over potentially disruptive live region updates while maintaining accessibility for those who want the information.

examples.name: Example 1: Updating screen reader settings for stock price update alerts
examples.description: The script below will update a stock value in an aria-live component every 10 seconds. If the user presses the "Turn Announcements Off" button, their screen reader will stop making announcements when the stock value changes; if they press the "Turn Announcements On" button, the announcements will start again.
examples.code:
<script>
 document.addEventListener("DOMContentLoaded", function (e) {
  const stockBox = document.querySelector("#stock-box");
  const stockMovement = document.querySelector("#stock-movement");
  const onBtn = document.querySelector("#live-on");
  const offBtn = document.querySelector("#live-off"); 
  const stocks = new Array("stock went down", "stock stayed the same", "stock went up");
  let loopCount = 0; 
 
  onBtn.addEventListener("click", modifyLive, false);
  offBtn.addEventListener("click", modifyLive, false);
 
  function modifyLive(e){
  let elm = e.currentTarget;
  let liveState = elm.getAttribute("id");
  if (liveState === "live-off"){
  stockBox.setAttribute("aria-live", "off");
  onBtn.setAttribute("aria-pressed", "false");
  offBtn.setAttribute("aria-pressed", "true");
  }
  else{
  stockBox.setAttribute("aria-live", "assertive");
  onBtn.setAttribute("aria-pressed", "true");
  offBtn.setAttribute("aria-pressed", "false");  
  }
  }
 
  setInterval(() => {
  if(loopCount >2){
  loopCount = 0;
  }
  stockMovement.innerHTML = stocks[loopCount];
  loopCount++;
  }, 10000)
  });
 </script>

remediations.name: User is warned when task time limit is about to expire
remediations.description: Session timeouts are displayed at least 20 seconds in advance via a confirm dialog prompting users if they need more time to complete their task. If the user confirms they need more time, the timeout is reset; if they decline or do not respond, the original timeout proceeds, giving users control over time-sensitive interactions while preventing unexpected session losses.

examples.name: Example 1
examples.description: A page of stock market quotes uses script to refresh the page every five minutes in order to ensure the latest statistics remain available. 20 seconds before the five-minute period expires, a confirmation dialog appears, asking if the user needs more time before the page refreshes. This allows the user to be aware of the impending refresh and to avoid it, if desired.
examples.code:
Stock Market Quotes

...

remediations.name: Validations/alerts are client-side (via role="alertdialog")
remediations.description: Use client-side scripting to validate user inputs as values are entered for each field. If errors are found, an alert dialog describes the nature of the error in text. Once the user dismisses the alert dialog, it is helpful if the script positions the keyboard focus on the field where the error occurred.

examples.name: Example 1: Checking a single control with an event handler
examples.description: The following script will check that a valid date has been entered in the form control.
examples.code:
<label for="date">Date:</label>
 <input type="text" name="date" id="date" 
  onchange="if(isNaN(Date.parse(this.value))) 
  alert('This control is not a valid date. 
  Please re-enter the value.');">

examples.name: Example 2: Checking multiple controls when the user submits the form
examples.description: The following sample shows multiple controls in a form. The form element uses the onsubmit attribute, which creates an event handler to execute the validation script when the user attempts to submit the form. If the validation is successful, the event returns true and the form submission proceeds; if the validation finds errors, it displays an error message and returns 'false' to cancel the submit attempt so that the user can fix the problems.

remediations.name: Onchange event with a select element causes no change of context
remediations.description: Use the onchange event on select elements to update other select elements on the same page without causing unexpected context changes or page navigation. The updated select element must appear after the triggering element in the page's reading order, ensuring that AT users will encounter the changes when they navigate to the modified element.

examples.name: Example 1
examples.description: This example contains two select elements. When an item is selected in the first select, the choices in the other select are updated appropriately. The first select element contains a list of continents. The second select element will contain a partial list of countries located in the selected continent. There is an onchange event associated with the continent select. When the continent selection changes, the items in the country select are modified using JavaScript via the Document Object Model (DOM). All of the data required, the list of countries and continents, is included within the web page.
examples.code: Dynamic Select Statements

remediations.name: Webpage supports both keyboard and other device-specific events
remediations.description: Ensure content works with both mouse and keyboard by providing corresponding event handlers for both input methods, such as pairing onmouseover with onfocus or onclick with onkeypress. While some mouse events like onclick work automatically with keyboards on native HTML elements, custom implementations need explicit keyboard handlers, and some mouse-specific functions like double-click may require alternative keyboard-accessible implementations since they have no direct keyboard equivalent.

examples.name: Example 1
examples.description: In this example of an image link, the image is changed when the user positions the pointer over the image. To provide keyboard users with a similar experience, the image is also changed when the user tabs to it.

examples.name: Example 2
examples.description: This example shows a custom link control where both the mouse and the keyboard can be used to activate the function. The mouse onclick event is duplicated by an appropriate keyboard onkeypress event. The tabindex attribute ensures that the keyboard will have a tab stop on the span element. Note that, in this example, the nextPage() function should check that the key pressed was Enter, otherwise it will respond to all keyboard actions while the span has focus, which is not the desired behavior.

remediations.name: Script controls and stops blinking content in 5 sec or less
remediations.description: Users should be able to control blinking with scripts, so that blinking can be set to stop in less than five seconds by the script. The script starts of the blinking effect, controls the toggle between visible and hidden states, and also stops the effect at five seconds or less. The setTimeout() function can be used to toggle blinking content between visible and hidden states, and stop when the number of iterations by the time between them adds up to nearly five seconds.

examples.name: Example 1
examples.description: This example uses JavaScript to control blinking of some HTML and XHTML content. JavaScript creates the blinking effect by changing the visibility status of the content. It controls the start of the effect and stops it within five seconds.

remediations.name: Progressive enhancement is used to open new windows
remediations.description: Prevent user confusion by warning before opening new windows or tabs that they did not explicitly request. The method involves adding event handlers to links that notify users the content will open in a new window, helping orient users and ensuring they understand the upcoming context change before it occurs.

examples.name: Example 1: Using JavaScript to open a new tab / window
examples.description: The script is included in the head of the document, and the link has an ID that can be used as a hook by the script.
examples.code: ... Show Help

remediations.name: Dynamic content inserted into the DOM follows trigger element
remediations.description: Implement proper tab order and reading sequence by inserting new UI elements (like menus or dialogs) directly after the triggering element in the DOM structure. The triggering element must be a focusable link or button with an onclick event, and focus remains on the trigger while the new content becomes the next item in both the tab order and screen reader reading sequence.

examples.name: Example 1
examples.description: This example creates a menu when a link is clicked and inserts it after the link. The onclick event of the link is used to call the ShowHide script, passing in an ID for the new menu as a parameter.
examples.code:
<button aria-expanded="false" type="button" onclick="ShowHide('foo',this)">
  Toggle
 </button>

remediations.name: Page sections are reordered by using the DOM
remediations.description: Provide an accessible alternative to drag-and-drop reordering by offering a menu of links that allow users to rearrange components using any input device. The reordering happens in the DOM structure itself (not just visually), ensuring the new order is accessible to all devices and AT while providing the same in-place, one-at-a-time functionality that makes drag-and-drop usable.

examples.name: Example 1
examples.description: This example does up and down reordering. This approach can also be used for two-dimensional reordering by adding left and right options.
examples.code:
• menu
    • up
    • down
    Text in the black module
    • ...

remediations.name: Content blocks can be bypassed using expandable/collapsable menu
remediations.description: Enable users to skip repeated material by placing that material in a menu that users can expand or collapse. The user can skip the repeated material by collapsing the menu. The user invokes a user interface control to hide or remove the elements of the menu. The resources section lists several techniques for menus, toolbars and trees, any of which can be used to provide a mechanism for skipping navigation.

examples.name: Example 1: Toggling a table of contents
examples.description: The table of contents for a set of web pages is repeated near the beginning of each web page. A button at the beginning of the table of contents lets the user remove or restore it on the page.

remediations.name: Static HTML elements support keyboard actions
remediations.description: Make static HTML elements like div or span keyboard accessible by adding tabindex to make them focusable and providing keyboard event handlers (onkeyup or onkeypress) alongside mouse handlers (onclick). Setting tabindex="0" includes the element in the natural tab order, while tabindex="-1" allows programmatic focus without tab navigation, but this technique should only be used when JavaScript support can be guaranteed since static elements have no fallback functionality.

examples.name: Example 1: Adding a JavaScript action to a div element
examples.description: The div element on the page is given a unique id attribute and a tabindex attribute with value 0. A script uses the Document Object Model (DOM) to find the div element by its ID and add the onclick handler and the onkeyup handler. The onkeyup handler will invoke the action when the Enter key is pressed. Note that the div element must be loaded into the DOM before it can be found and modified. This is usually accomplished by calling the script from the onload event of the body element. The script to add the event handlers will only execute if the user agent supports and has JavaScript enabled.
examples.code:
Here is the link to modify with a javascript action:

Do Something
Hello, world!

remediations.name: Scripts can change link texts
remediations.description: Provide users with the choice to expand link text throughout a page to make links self-contained and understandable without context. A toggle link near the beginning of the page allows users to switch between brief link text and expanded descriptive text, accommodating different user preferences for link verbosity and reducing the need to explore surrounding content to understand link purposes.

examples.name: Example 1
