examples.description: This example uses Javascript to add contextual information directly to the text of a link. The link class is used to determine which additional text to add. When the "Expand Links" link is activated, each link on the page is tested to see whether additional text should be added.

remediations.name: JavaScript in CSS can make the focus indicator more visible
remediations.description: The author can use JavaScript to apply CSS to make the focus indicator more visible than ordinary. When an element receives focus, the background color or border is changed to make it visually distinct. When the element loses focus, it returns to its normal styling. This technique can be used on any HTML UA that supports Script and CSS, regardless of whether it supports the :focus pseudo class.

examples.name: Example 1
examples.description: In this example, when the link receives focus, its background turns yellow. When it loses focus, the yellow is removed. Note that if the link had a background color to begin with, you would use that color rather than "" in the script.
examples.code: ... focus me ...

remediations.name: Form error messages and validations are displayed via DOM
remediations.description: Display client-side validation errors as a list of anchor links positioned above the form, allowing users to focus on error messages and jump directly to the problematic fields via in-page links. Anchor elements ensure that error messages are focusable and provide clear navigation to the specific fields that need correction, though this approach requires JavaScript support and should be combined with server-side validation for complete coverage.

examples.name: Example 1: Listing errors in a block at the top of a form
examples.description: This example validates required fields as well as fields where a specific format is required. When an error is identified, the script inserts a list of error messages into the DOM and moves focus to them.

remediations.name: Users can pause script scrolling
remediations.description: Provide a way for users to stop scrolling content when scrolling is created by a script. Scrolling content can be difficult or impossible to read by users with low vision or with cognitive disabilities and the movement can also be distracting for some people.

examples.name: Example 1
examples.description: In this example, CSS and JavaScript are used to visually present some text in a scrolling format. A link is included to pause the scrolling movement.
examples.code:
...

This text will scroll and a Pause/Scroll link will be present when JavaScript and CSS are supported and active.

...

remediations.name: Text size and position are scalable
remediations.description: Calculate element sizes and positions that scale properly when users change text size by using JavaScript properties offsetHeight, offsetWidth, offsetLeft, and offsetTop. The key is iterating through all parent elements to calculate absolute positions correctly, ensuring that UI elements remain properly positioned and sized when text scaling occurs.

examples.name: Example 1: Calculating the size and position of elements in a way that will scale appropriately as the text size is scaled
examples.description: The following example illustrates using the function above by aligning an object beneath a reference object, the same distance from the left:

remediations.name: Onclick event of anchors and buttons makes actions keyboard accessible
remediations.description: Ensure keyboard accessibility by attaching scripted functions to natively actionable HTML elements like links and buttons using their device-independent onclick events. The onclick event responds to mouse clicks, keyboard activation (Enter/Space), and accessibility API triggers equally, and backup implementations should be provided through href attributes for links or form submissions for buttons when scripting is unavailable.

examples.name: Example 1: Link that runs a script and has no fallback for non-scripted browsers
examples.description: This approach should only be used when script is relied upon as an Accessibility Supported Technology.
examples.code: do stuff

examples.name: Example 2: Link that runs script, but navigates to another page when script is not available
examples.description: This approach can be used to create sites that do not rely on script, if and only if the navigation target provides the same functionality as the script. This example is identical to the example 1, except that its href is now set to a real page, dostuff.html. The dostuff.html page must provide the same functionality as the script. The "return false;" at the end of the doStuff() event handling function tells the browser not to navigate to the URI. Without it, the browser would navigate to dostuff.html after the script ran.
examples.code: do stuff

examples.name: Example 3: Button that runs a script and falls back to a form post for users without script
examples.description: This approach can be used by sites that do not rely on script, if and only if the form post provides the same functionality as the script. The onsubmit="return false;" prevents the form from submitting.
examples.code:
<script>
 function doStuff() {
  //do stuff
 }
 </script>
 <form action="doStuff.aspx" onsubmit="return false;">
  <input type="submit" value="Do Stuff" onclick="doStuff();">
 </form>

examples.name: Example 4: Button that runs a script, implemented with input type="image"
examples.description: Note that an alt attribute must be added to the input to provide a text equivalent for the image. This approach should only be used when script is relied upon.
examples.code:
<script>
 function doStuff() {
  //do stuff
  return false;
 }
 </script>
 <input type="image" src="stuff.gif" alt="Do stuff" onclick="return doStuff();">

examples.name: Example 5: Button that runs a script, implemented with input type="submit", input type="reset" or input type="button"
examples.description: This approach should only be used when script is relied upon.
examples.code: <input type="submit" onclick="return doStuff();" value="Do Stuff">

examples.name: Example 6: Button that runs a script, implemented with button
examples.description: This is valuable when you want more control over the look of your button. In this particular example, the button contains both an icon and some text. This approach should only be used when script is relied upon.

remediations.name: Users can display moving/scrolling/auto-updating text in static window/area
remediations.description:
Some web pages display scrolling text because of limited available space, but scrolling the text in small windows causes problems for users who read more slowly or use AT. Therefore, provides a mechanism to stop the movement and make the entire block of text available statically. The text may be made available in a separate window or in a (larger) section of the page. Users can then read the text at their own speed. 
This technique does not apply when the text that is moving cannot be displayed all at once on the screen (e.g., a long chat conversation).

examples.name: Example 1: Expanding Scrolling Text in Place
examples.description: A large block of text is scrolled through a small marquee area of the page. A button lets the user stop the scrolling and display the entire block of text.

remediations.name: Content is hoverable, dismissible, and persistent
remediations.description: Additional content triggered by hover or focus (like tooltips or pop-ups) must remain visible when users move their pointer from the trigger to the content itself, and must be dismissible without moving focus. This ensures that low vision users who use screen magnification can read the additional content even when it extends beyond their current viewport, and allows all users to access content that might be covered by the pop-up.

examples.name: Example 1: Content preview for links
examples.description: When hovering over or focusing on a link, a content preview for the link appears just above or below that link. Users can move the pointer over the additional content (pop-up) so that they can fully read the additional content. Pressing the Esc key dismisses (closes) the additional content.
examples.code: This is the trigger And this additional text gives additional context on the trigger term . Text and popup are in one link (a) element.

remediations.name: Content is positioned based on CSS structural markup
remediations.description: Visual appearance may be enhanced via style sheets while still maintaining a meaningful presentation when style sheets are not applied. Use the positioning properties of CSS so content can be displayed at any position on the user's viewport. Using structural elements ensures that the meaning of the content can still be determined when styling is not available.

examples.name: Example 1
examples.description: In this example, structural markup (description lists) have been applied to the content. CSS has been used to style the content into columnar form. Each class absolutely positions the content into columns and the margins have been set to 0 to override the default behavior of user agents to display HTML definition lists with the dd element indented.
examples.code:
Products
Telephones
Computers
Portable MP3 Players
Locations
Idaho
Wisconsin

remediations.name: CSS hides portion of the link
remediations.description: Add to links descriptive text that is hidden visually but remains accessible to AT by positioning the additional text in a 1-pixel box with overflow:hidden rather than using visibility:hidden or display:none. This allows screen reader users to understand the complete purpose of links while keeping the visual display uncluttered, particularly useful when surrounding context is needed to interpret brief link text.

examples.name: Example 1: A news site with "full story" links
examples.description: This example describes a news site that has a series of short synopsis of stories followed by a link that says "full story". Hidden link text describes the purpose of the link.
examples.code: Washington has announced plans to stimulate economic growth. Washington stimulates economic growth Full Story

examples.name: Example 2: A list of books in different formats
examples.description: This example describes a resource that has electronic books in different formats. The title of each book is followed by links that say "HTML" and "PDF." Visually-hidden text describes the purpose of each link.
examples.code:
Winnie the Pooh
Winnie the Pooh HTML
Winnie the Pooh PDF
War and Peace
War and Peace HTML
War and Peace PDF

remediations.name: Style sheets enhance text spacing
remediations.description: The visual appearance of spacing in text may be enhanced via style sheets while still maintaining meaningful text sequencing. The CSS letter-spacing property helps developers control the amount of white space between characters. This is recommended over adding blank characters to control the spacing, since the blank characters can change the meaning and pronunciation of the word.

examples.name: Example 1: Increasing the spacing between characters in a word
examples.description: The following CSS would add the equivalent of a space between each character in a level-2 heading:

remediations.name: CSS is used to include decorative images

examples.name: Example 1: Background image for an HTML page
examples.description: The stylesheet for a web page specifies a background image for the whole page.
examples.code:
<style>
  body { background: #ffe url('/images/home-bg.jpg') repeat; }
 </style>

examples.name: Example 2: Background image with CSS for image rollovers
examples.description: The stylesheet for a web page uses the CSS background property to create decorative rollover effects when a user hovers their mouse pointer over a link.

remediations.name: CSS text size value is expressed in %
remediations.description: Text font size should be specified proportionally so that UAs can scale content effectively. If a font-size is specified for the body element, all other elements inherit that value, unless overridden by a more specific selector.

examples.name: Example 1: Percent font sizes in CSS
examples.description: This example defines the font size for the strong element so that its text will always be larger than the surrounding text, in whatever context it is used. Assuming that headings and paragraphs use different font sizes, the emphasized words in this example will each be larger than their surrounding text.
examples.code:
Letting the user control text size

Since only the user can know what size text works for them, it is very important to let them configure the text size.

remediations.name: Font sizes are named, not expressed in digits
remediations.description: The objective of this technique is to specify a named font size that expresses the relative font size desired. These values provide hints so that the UA can choose a font-size relative to the inherited font-size.

examples.name: Example 1: Named font sizes in CSS
examples.description: This example selects a larger font size for strong elements so that their text will always be larger than the surrounding text, in whatever context they are used. Assuming that headings and paragraphs use different font sizes, the emphasized words in this example will each be larger than their surrounding text.
examples.code:
...

Letting the user control text size

Since only the user can know what size text works for them, it is very important to let them configure the text size. ...

remediations.name: Font size is specified in em units
remediations.description: Specify text font size in em units so that UAs can scale content effectively. Since the em is a property of the font, it scales as the font changes size. If a font-size is specified for the body element, all other elements inherit that value, unless overridden by a more specific selector.

examples.name: Example 1: em font sizes in CSS
examples.description: This example defines the font size for strong element, so that its text will always be larger than the surrounding text, in whatever context it is used. Assuming that headings and paragraphs use different font sizes, the strong words in this example will each be larger than their surrounding text.
examples.code:
...

Letting the user control text size

Since only the user can know what size text works for them, it is very important to let them configure the text size.

remediations.name: Via CSS, components change appearance when focused on
remediations.description:
Visual appearance may be enhanced via style sheets to provide visual feedback when an interactive element has focus or when a user hovers over it using a pointing device. Highlighting the element that has focus or is hovered over can provide information such as the fact that the element is interactive or the scope of the interactive element.
 Providing visual feedback may be possible through more than one mode. Usually, it is attained through using a mouse to hover over the element or a keyboard to tab to the element.

examples.name: Example 1: Link elements
examples.description: In this example, mouse and keyboard focus indicators have been applied to the link elements. CSS has been used to apply a background color when the link elements receive focus.
examples.code:
• Home
  • Services
  • Projects
  • Demos
  • About us
  • Contact us
  • Links

examples.name: Example 2: Highlighting elements that receive focus
examples.description: In this example, the :focus pseudo-class is used to change the style applied to input fields when they receive focus by changing the background color.

remediations.name: Text-based form controls resize when text size changes
remediations.description: Text-based form controls should resize when text size is changed in the UA. This will allow users to enter text and read what they have entered in input boxes because the text is displayed at the size required by the user. Text-based form controls include input boxes (text and textarea) as well as buttons.

examples.name: Example 1: A Contact Form
examples.description: A Contact Us form has some introductory information and then form controls for users to enter their first name, last name, telephone number and email address. All of the text and form controls have been implemented in a scalable way.
examples.code:
Contact Us

Please provide us with your details and we will contact you as soon as we can. Note that all of the form fields are required.

remediations.name: CSS text-align property aligns text blocks
remediations.description:
Align blocks of text either left or right by setting the CSS text-align property. For example, to align text left, in the style sheet, define the class p.left {text-align: left}; in the content, call the up the class:

Lorem ipsum dolor sit ...

Ton align text to the right, use p.right {text-align: right}, and in the content call the up the class

Lorem ipsum dolor sit ...

.

examples.name: Example 1: Aligning text to the left
examples.description: In the following example, text is aligned left. In the style sheet, define the class:
examples.code: p.left {text-align: left}

examples.name: Example 2: Aligning text to the right
examples.description: In the following example, text is aligned right.
examples.code: p.right {text-align: right}

remediations.name: Content line length averages 80 characters or less
remediations.description: Use relative CSS measurements to ensure that line length can average 80 characters or less when users adjust their view, helping people with reading or vision disabilities who have trouble tracking long lines of text. The approach allows column widths to scale appropriately with font size increases, preventing text clipping while giving users the flexibility to achieve comfortable line lengths for their needs.

examples.name: Example 1
examples.description: In this example, the div width is set in ems in the stylesheet.
examples.code: #main-content {max-width: 70em}

examples.name: Example 2
examples.description: In this example, the div width is set in percent in the stylesheet
examples.code: #main-content {width: 90%}

remediations.name: CSS specifies line spacing
remediations.description: Empower people with cognitive disabilities to track lines of text when a block of text is single spaced. Provide spacing between 1.5 to 2 to allow them to start a new line more easily once they have finished the previous one.

examples.name: Example 1: Setting the element to 1.5 line height
examples.description: In the style sheet set the characteristics of the element.
examples.code: body { line-height: 1.5; }

remediations.name: CSS controls the visual presentation of text
remediations.description: Use CSS to control text presentation instead of text images, allowing users to modify visual characteristics like size, color, and font through their browser settings. Separating presentation from markup through CSS makes content more accessible by enabling text to be resized, have colors changed, be translated, and work with AT, while proper font selection with fallbacks ensures good visual results without accessibility barriers. The CSS properties useful to style text and avoid the need for text in images are available in the original technique.

examples.name: Example 1: Using CSS font-family to control the font family for text
examples.code: The JavaScript method to convert a string to uppercase is toUpperCase().

examples.name: Example 2: Using CSS text-align to control the placement (alignment) of text
examples.code: This text should be to the right of the viewport.

examples.name: Example 3: Using CSS font-size to control the size of text
examples.code: 09 March 2008

examples.name: Example 4: Using CSS color to control the color of text
examples.description: Note
examples.code: 09 March 2008

examples.name: Example 5: Using CSS font-style to italicize text
examples.description: Note
examples.code: The article is available in the Endocrinology Blog.

examples.name: Example 6: Using CSS font-weight to control the font weight of the text
examples.description: Note
examples.code: This deal is available now!

examples.name: Example 7: Using CSS text-transform to control the case of text
examples.description: Note
examples.code: 09 March 2008

examples.name: Example 8: Using CSS line-height to control spacing between lines of text
examples.description: The CSS line-height property is used to display the line height for the paragraph at twice the height of the font.
examples.code: Concern for man and his fate must always form the chief interest of all technical endeavors. Never forget this in the midst of your diagrams and equations.

examples.name: Example 9: Using CSS letter-spacing to space text
examples.description: The CSS letter-spacing property is used to display the letters farther apart in the heading.
examples.code:
News
today

examples.name: Example 10: Using CSS background-image to layer text and images
examples.description: The CSS font-style property is used to display the textual component of a banner and background-image property is used to display a picture behind the text.
examples.code: Welcome to your local city council

examples.name: Example 11: Using CSS ::first-line to control the presentation of the first line of text
examples.description: The CSS ::first-line pseudo-element is used to display the first line of text in a larger, red font.
examples.code:
Once upon a time...
...in a land far, far away...

examples.name: Example 12: Using CSS ::first-letter to control the presentation of the first letter of text
examples.description: The CSS ::first-letter pseudo-element is used to display the first letter in a larger font size, red and vertically aligned in the middle.
examples.code: Once upon a time...

remediations.name: Text/background color changes do not impact groupings/organization
remediations.description: Enable users to control main content colors through browser settings while preserving visual grouping cues by specifying colors only for secondary content areas. By leaving main content colors unspecified, users can set their preferred text and background colors without overriding the entire page, maintaining the visual organization and groupings that help with navigation and comprehension.

remediations.name: CSS container sizes are expressed in percentage
remediations.description: Enable users to increase the size of text without having to scroll horizontally to read that text. To use this technique, the author specifies the width of text containers using percent values.

remediations.name: Text & background colors follow browser and/or OS settings
remediations.description: Preserve page layout and borders through CSS while allowing users to control text and background colors through their browser settings, preventing conflicts between design structure and color accessibility needs. By specifying borders and layout properties but leaving text and background colors unspecified, users can customize colors for readability while maintaining visual organization, avoiding issues like collapsed layouts, transparent pop-ups, or unreadable dropdown menus that occur when users override all author colors.

remediations.name: Content order in source code matches visual order
remediations.description: Ensure the content order in the source code matches the visual presentation order, preventing confusion when AT users experience content differently than sighted users. When source order differs from visual order, visually-impaired users following source order may encounter information in a different sequence than sighted users following visual order, and keyboard users may have unpredictable focus movement, making collaboration and understanding more difficult.

remediations.name: Size of text containers is specified using em units
remediations.description: Use em units to specify the width and height of text containers so that they scale proportionally when users resize text, preventing text from being cropped or cut off. Containers specified in other units like pixels may not grow when text size increases, causing text to overflow outside the container boundaries and become unreadable.

examples.name: Example 1: em units for sizes for layout container containing text
examples.description: In this example, a div element, with id value of "nav_menu", is used to position the navigation menu along the left-hand side of the main content area of the web page. The navigation menu consists of a list of text links, with id value of "nav_list". The text size for the navigation links and the width of the container are specified in em units.
examples.code:
#nav_menu { width: 20em; height: 100em; }
 #nav_list { font-size: 100%; }

examples.name: Example 2: em units for text-based form controls
examples.description: In this example, input elements that contain text or accept text input by the user have been given the class name "form1". CSS rules are used to define the font size in percent units and width for these elements in em units. This will allow the text within the form control to resize in response to changes in text size settings without being cropped (because the width of the form control itself also resizes according to the font size).
examples.code: input.form1 { font-size: 100%; width: 15em; }

examples.name: Example 3: em units in dropdown boxes
examples.description: In this example, select elements have been given the class name "pick." CSS rules are used to define the font size in percent units and width in em units. This will allow the text within the form control to resize in response to changes in text size settings without being cropped.
examples.code: select.pick { font-size: 100%; width: 10em; }

examples.name: Example 4: em units for non-text-based form controls
examples.description: In this example, input elements that define checkboxes or radio buttons have been given the class name "choose." CSS rules are used to define the width and height for these elements in em units. This will allow the form control to resize in response to changes in text size settings.
examples.code: input.choose { width: 1.2em; height: 1.2em; }

remediations.name: CSS replaces text with images of text, users can switch content view
remediations.description: Use properly structured HTML text and CSS with scripting to provide alternative presentations, where one version uses semantic HTML text and another replaces some text with images through CSS image replacement methods. A user control should allow switching between presentations, ensuring that users can access a text-only version for accessibility while still offering styled image versions for enhanced visual design, with the text-based version ideally set as the default.

examples.name: Example 1: Replacing heading text with images of text
examples.description: A design studio site uses a style switcher to allow users to view two presentations of their home page. For the default version, the heading text is replaced with images of text. A control on the page allows users to switch to a version that presents the headings as text.
examples.code:
Pufferfish Design Studio

Surprising Identity and Design Solutions

remediations.name: CSS Flexbox is used to reflow content
remediations.description: Use flexbox layouts to prevent horizontal scrollbars at 320 CSS pixels width and vertical scrollbars at 256 CSS pixels height by creating flexible regions that adapt to available viewport space. Flexbox properties and media queries allow layout regions to enlarge, shrink, or wrap as needed while maintaining element relationships and reading order, though authors must avoid using order and reverse properties that can disrupt keyboard navigation by changing the logical content sequence.

examples.name: Example 1: Medium complex flexbox layout in HTML and CSS
examples.description: The following medium complex example uses HTML and CSS to create a flexbox layout. The layout regions adjust their size as the viewport is adjusted. When the total viewport width matches the width defined via media queries, columns wrap to be positioned below, rather than beside each other or vice versa.
examples.code:
...
... ...
...
...
...
...

remediations.name: Media queries and grid CSS are used to reflow columns
remediations.description: Use CSS Grid layouts to prevent horizontal scrollbars at 320 CSS pixels width and vertical scrollbars at 256 CSS pixels height by creating layout regions that reflow and adapt to available viewport space. Grid properties and media queries should allow layout regions to resize and reorganize as needed while preserving element relationships and reading order, but authors must avoid using grid placement to reorder content as this can create incorrect focus order for keyboard users.

examples.name: Example 1: Grid layout in HTML and CSS - Medium complexity
examples.description: The following medium complexity example uses HTML and CSS to create a grid layout. The layout regions adjust their size as the viewport is adjusted. When the total viewport width matches the width defined via media queries, columns wrap to be positioned below, rather than beside each other or vice versa.
examples.code:
...
... ...
...
...
...
...

remediations.name: CSS Reflow is used for long URLs and text strings
remediations.description: Prevent long character strings like URLs from causing horizontal scrollbars at 320 CSS pixels width or vertical scrollbars at 256 CSS pixels height by using CSS properties that force text wrapping to adapt to viewport space. While browsers naturally wrap URLs at certain characters, additional CSS techniques may be needed to ensure complete reflow, though using human-readable link text instead of displaying long URLs is preferable for both usability and accessibility.

examples.name: Example 1: Breaking long URLs
examples.description: Using the following CSS will cause long URLs to break at appropriate places (hyphens, forward slashes, etc.) and within words without causing reflow.

remediations.name: Media queries are used for un-fixing sticky headers / footers
remediations.description: Use media queries with min-height, max-height, and min-width properties to conditionally deactivate sticky headers and footers when viewport space is limited. Sticky regions that work well on desktop or mobile portrait mode can block significant screen space in landscape mode or when zoomed, so this approach "un-fixes" these elements when there is insufficient space to ensure adequate content viewing area remains available.

examples.name: Example 1: Un-fix sticky headers / footers in HTML and CSS
examples.description: The following example uses HTML and CSS to un-fix sticky headers / footers. The sticky regions get un-fixed as the height of the viewport is limited or the orientation is changed. When the min-height property matches the viewport space defined via media queries, regions which are not sticky get fixed or vice versa. This particular example uses the CSS min-height, max-height and min-width media query properties.
examples.code:
<!DOCTYPE html>
 <html lang="en">
  <head>
  <meta charset="UTF-8">
  <title>Using media queries to un-fix sticky headers / footers</title>
  <style>
 

  /* Sticky Styling */
 

  header { min-height: 130px; }
 

  @media (min-height: 480px) {
  header {
  position: -webkit-sticky;
  position: sticky;
  top: 0;
  }
  }
 

  @media (min-device-width: 576px) and 
  (max-device-width: 1024px) and 
  (orientation: landscape) {
  header {
  position: static;
  }
  }
 

  footer { min-height: 130px; }
 

  @media (min-height: 480px) {
  footer {
  position: sticky;
  bottom: 0;
  }
  }
 

  @media (min-device-width: 576px) and
  (max-device-width: 1024px) and
  (orientation: landscape) {
  footer {
  position: static;
  }
  }
 

  </style>
 

  </head>
 

  <body class="grid">
 

  <header class="grid-item">
  ...
  </header>
 

  <main class="grid-item">  
  ...
  </main>
 

  <aside class="grid-item">
  ...
  </aside>
 

  <footer class="grid-item">
  ...
  </footer>
 

  </body>
 </html>

remediations.name: User can override text spacing without wrapping
remediations.description: Text containers should expand to accommodate user-customized spacing for paragraphs, lines, words, and characters without losing content or functionality. Text should wrap naturally in flexible containers or 20% extra width should be provided for fixed-width elements to accommodate the expansion that occurs when users increase text spacing through their own stylesheets or browser tools.

examples.name: Example 1: A box sized with space to allow for expansion
examples.description: The containers are sized to a value greater than the default width of the text.
examples.code:
<style>
 /* Links are less than 8ex wide,
 so 10ex width of each li allows for expanded letter and word width */
 nav li { width: 10em; }
 </style>

examples.name: Example 2: A box which expands with the text size
examples.description: In the case of variable-width text containers for each item, the parent item may need to allow for wrapping of the items.
examples.code:
<style>
 /* CSS containers are given a display of inline-block. No negative margins set. */
  nav li { display: inline-block; }
  </style>

remediations.name: User can override text spacing
remediations.description: Containers should expand vertically or horizontally to accommodate user-customized text spacing without losing content or functionality. Authors should avoid setting restrictive CSS height properties to allow paragraphs to expand naturally when users increase spacing, with the direction of expansion depending on whether the language reads horizontally (requiring vertical expansion) or vertically (requiring horizontal expansion).

examples.name: Example 1: A paragraph expands vertically within container
examples.description: None of the paragraphs on this page have a height specified, so all are effectively using this technique.
examples.code:
<style>
 /* CSS: No height property is set.*/
 </style>

remediations.name: The max-width and height parameters are used to fit images
remediations.description: Images should be prevented from causing horizontal scrollbars at 320 CSS pixels width or vertical scrollbars at 256 CSS pixels height by using CSS max-width and height properties to make images scale down while maintaining their aspect ratio. Images should be constrained to fit within their layout containers at all viewport sizes and zoom levels, ensuring they adapt to available space without breaking out of responsive layouts or causing unwanted scrolling.

examples.name: Example 1: Fitting images in HTML and CSS
examples.description: The following simple example uses HTML and CSS to create a fitting image. The layout regions adjust their size as the viewport is adjusted. The images subsequently adjust their size to fit within the layout region containers.
examples.code: ...

remediations.name: CSS width, max-width and Flexbox is used to fit labels and inputs
remediations.description: Form labels and inputs should not cause horizontal scrollbars at 320 CSS pixels width by using CSS width, max-width, and flexbox properties to adapt their layout to available space. When horizontal space is limited, labels and inputs switch from side-by-side positioning to vertical alignment, ensuring they remain within their layout containers at all viewport sizes and zoom levels without breaking out or causing unwanted scrolling.

examples.name: Example 1: Fitting labels, inputs and flexbox layout with HTML and CSS.
examples.description: The following example uses HTML and CSS to fit labels and inputs within various width containers, including the viewport. The layout regions adjust their size as the viewport is adjusted. The labels and inputs subsequently adjust their size to fit within the layout region containers.

remediations.name: Animation can be controlled from CSS
remediations.description: Use the prefers-reduced-motion CSS media query to allow users to deactivate animations that can cause distraction or nausea, particularly for people with vestibular disorders. By wrapping animation CSS in this media query, content like parallax scrolling or other motion effects will be disabled when users have set their system preference to reduce motion, preventing potential vestibular symptoms while maintaining essential movement like normal scrolling.

examples.name: Example 1: 'prefers-reduced-motion' CSS Media Query
examples.description: Users can indicate their motion preference for interfaces in their system and the 'prefers-reduced-motion' CSS Media Query will respect that choice. CSS can then be applied to deactivate that motion for users who request it.

remediations.name: Create a two-color focus indicator for sufficient contrast
remediations.description: Create a two-color focus indicator using highly-contrasting light and dark colors with at least a 9:1 contrast ratio between them to ensure at least one color always meets 3:1 contrast against any solid background. Implement this technique using CSS outline and box-shadow properties with :focus or :focus-visible pseudo-classes, eliminating the need for multiple classes across sites with varied background colors since one of the two indicator colors will always provide sufficient contrast regardless of the background color used.

examples.name: Example 1: A thick two-color indicator
examples.description: In this example, the indicator consists of two solid bands of color. Since each color band is 2 CSS pixels thick, either color band is large enough to meet the minimum indicator size requirement on its own. As long as one of the two colors has a 3:1 change contrast with the pixels behind and around the focus indicator, the indicator will satisfy both the Focus Appearance and Non-Text Contrast success criteria.

remediations.name: Website has highly visible focus indicator
remediations.description: Create a highly visible focus indicator that has sufficient contrast against the internal background color of a component.

examples.name: Example 1: Inner border
examples.description: CSS to provide the indicator. It narrows the scope to buttons within the main element.
examples.code: <button type="button">Example button</button>

remediations.name: Links are spaced within area measuring at least 44  44 CSS pixels
remediations.description: Ensure that links in navigation or pagination menus are spaced so that they fall within an area that measures at least 44  44 CSS pixels if the target area itself is smaller than that. The aim is to provide an adequate target clearance so the offset to adjacent targets is sufficient to prevent accidental pointer activation of adjacent targets.

examples.name: Example 1: Using a display value of inline-block, min-height, and min-width
examples.description: The first example shows a situation where the targets (in this case, the linked numbers in the pagination navigation) are smaller than 44  44 CSS pixels. However, the list items that contain them have a minimum height and width of 44 px set, so that sufficient target spacing is ensured.
examples.code:
1. previous
  2. 1
  3. 2
  4. 3
  5. 4
  6. 5
  7. next

examples.name: Example 2: Using a display value of flex and min-height / width
examples.description: The second example uses min-width and min-height on the targets (the linked numbers in the pagination menu) and not on the parent container, thereby meeting this target spacing success criterion and incidentally also the AAA Success Criterion 2.5.5 Target Size.
examples.code:
1. previous
  2. 1
  3. 2
  4. 3
  5. 4
  6. 5
  7. next

remediations.name: CSS scroll-padding unobscures content
remediations.description: Ensure that UI components (for example: links, buttons, and form fields) initially completely obscured by a fixed-position component can still be accessed by users. For example, this can be achieved using CSS padding and scroll-padding properties to create space underneath the site footer and allow the link in the footer to scroll into view when it is focused with a keyboard.

examples.name: Example 1: Using CSS scroll-padding to un-obscure content
examples.description: This example shows a situation where there is a fixed-position banner at the bottom of the screen that is covering up the site footer, which contains a link. This type of fixed-position banner is a common design for cookie-consent banners.
examples.code:
Fixed-Position Banner

Header Content

Main Content

Sidebar Content

Here's an example link in the sidebar.

Footer Content

Here's an example link in the footer.

remediations.name: Top page link sends user to main content
remediations.description:
Provide a mechanism to bypass blocks of material that are repeated on multiple web pages by skipping directly to the main content of the web page. The first interactive item in the web page is a link to the beginning of the main content. Activating the link sets focus beyond the other content to the main content. 
This technique is most useful when a web page has one main content area, rather than a set of content areas that are equally important, and when there are not multiple navigation sections on the page.

remediations.name: Users can pause movement and scrolling
remediations.description: Provide a way to pause movement or scrolling of content. If the user needs to pause the movement, to reduce distraction or to have time to read it, they can do so, and then restart it as needed. This mechanism can be provided either through interactive controls that conform to WCAG or through keyboard shortcuts. If keyboard shortcuts are used, they should be documented.

remediations.name: Users have all the time required to complete an activity
remediations.description: Provide users with all the time they need to complete an activity. This technique involves providing a specified activity which does not require timed interaction. Users are allowed as much time as they need to interact with the activity.

remediations.name: Video has second audio with extended desc
remediations.description: Provide a second version of video content with extended audio descs that can pause the audio and video to deliver detailed descriptions when natural dialogue pauses are too short. Extended audio descs make video content accessible to visually impaired users who need comprehensive information about visual content that cannot be communicated through dialogue alone, with options to toggle the feature on and off to avoid disrupting viewers who do not need the additional descriptions.

remediations.name: Live, synchronized media has captions
remediations.description: Provide real-time captions for live synchronized media broadcasts to make them accessible to hearing impaired users. Real-time captioning is more challenging than pre-recorded captions because there is limited time for error correction or consultation, requiring specialized techniques like stenographic typing, rapid typing technologies, or re-voicing speech-to-text systems where an operator listens and re-speaks content into speech recognition software.

remediations.name: AT conveys equivalent information to user through alternate UI
remediations.description: Custom UI components created with programming languages should provide equivalent information to AT by implementing proper accessibility API compatibility. While standard components often include built-in accessibility features that authors can utilize by setting properties like names, custom components require authors to manually add accessibility provisions and test them for AT support to ensure they convey the same information through alternate interfaces.

remediations.name: Blinking content stops in less than 5 seconds
remediations.description: Minimize the distraction caused by blinking content and enable users to re-focus on the other content on the page. Blinking content can be created using a variety of technologies, many of which include options to loop blinking content continuously or to otherwise specify the amount of time the blinking content is displayed. Limiting content blinking to five seconds minimizes the distraction, benefitting people with certain types of learning disabilities and/or low vision.

remediations.name: Form control change resulting in context change is announced
remediations.description: Provide information to users about what happens when a change to a form control results in a change of context. Changing the value of a form control does not typically result in a change of context, so it is important that authors provide instructions that make the user aware of the behavior in advance. Where possible, programmatically associate instructions describing the change with the form control itself. See some examples in the original technique.

remediations.name: Color differences that convey information are explained in text
remediations.description: Ensure that when color differences are used to convey information, such as required form fields, the information conveyed by the color differences is also explicitly conveyed in text.

remediations.name: Webpage observes general/red flash threshold
remediations.description: Avoid violations of the general and red flash thresholds to allow photosensitive people to view websites without encountering material that is likely to cause a seizure. Warnings can be provided but people may miss them and children may not be able to read or understand them. With this technique, all material is checked and if it violates flash or red flash thresholds it is either not put on the site or it is modified so that it does not violate the thresholds.

remediations.name: Contrast ratio of text/images of text must extend beyond standard 4.5:1
remediations.description: Ensure that text maintains a 7:1 contrast ratio against its background to enhance readability for people with low vision, going beyond the standard 4.5:1 requirement. When backgrounds are solid colors, the contrast can be maintained directly, but for variable or patterned backgrounds, authors can use techniques like shading areas behind text, adjusting text luminance as the background changes, or adding halos around text to achieve the necessary contrast ratio.

remediations.name: Text/images of text have mininum 4.5:1 contrast ratio
remediations.description: Ensure text maintains a 4.5:1 contrast ratio with its background, with relaxed requirements for large text (18+ point regular or 14+ point bold) under enhanced contrast guidelines. Authors can achieve proper contrast on varied or patterned backgrounds by shading areas behind text, adjusting text luminance as the background changes, adding thin outlines around letters, or providing halos around text when the background alone would not provide sufficient contrast.

remediations.name: Components flash no more than three times in any 1-sec period
remediations.description: Avoid flashing at rates that are known to cause seizures if the flashes are bright and large enough. Since some users may be using screen enlargers, this technique limits the flashing of any size content to no more than three flashes in any 1-second period. See examples in the original technique.

remediations.name: Keyboard navigation does not get stuck in a section
remediations.description: Prevent keyboard users from becoming trapped in plug-in content or other subsets of content by ensuring there is always a keyboard method to exit and return focus to the parent window. Authors must either provide explicit keyboard mechanisms to escape sub-content, avoid using technologies that trap focus, or build escape capabilities into their content, since some plug-ins only allow mouse-based exits that are inaccessible to keyboard users.

remediations.name: Link purpose is explicit due to context
remediations.description: Identify the purpose of a link from the link itself and its sentence context. The sentence enclosing the link provides context for an otherwise unclear link. The description lets a user distinguish this link from links in the web page that lead to other destinations and helps the user determine whether to follow the link. Note that simply providing the URI of the destination is generally not sufficiently descriptive.

remediations.name: Video stream has sign language interpreter
remediations.description: Enable users who cannot hear or read text rapidly to access synced media material. Users who communicate in sign language cannot sometimes read and understand text at caption rates, so provide sign language of the audio information. You can simply embed a video of the sign language interpreter in the video stream, which provides a lower resolution image that cannot be easily enlarged without enlarging the entire image.

remediations.name: Definitions of words/phrases/abbreviations are on same page or linked to
remediations.description: Make the definition of a word, phrase, or abbreviation available by providing the definition, either within the same web page or in a different web page, and establishing a link between the item and its definition. Links are a powerful option for providing access to the definition of a word, phrase, or abbreviation. A user can use the link to find the definition quickly and easily, and then return to their place in the content via the user agent's Back button.

examples.name: Example 6
examples.description: A Japanese idiom is linked to its definition. This example uses a link within the page to navigate to the definition of an idiomatic expression.
examples.code: ......

remediations.name: Non-speech sounds are at least 20 decibels lower than speech content
remediations.description:
Include sound behind speech without making it too hard for people with hearing problems to understand the speech. Making sure that the foreground speech is 20 db louder than the background sound makes the speech 4 times louder than the background audio. 
For information on Decibels (dB), see About Decibels.

remediations.name: Content presented to AT is in meaningful sequence
remediations.description: Ensure the order content is presented to ATs allows users to understand the content, even when visual presentation differs from source code order. Examples include using proper markup to handle bidirectional text instead of moving punctuation in the content stream, avoiding white space characters for visual formatting that can interfere with meaning, and ensuring captions remain associated with their images rather than being separated by layout table structures that break logical relationships.

examples.name: Example 1
examples.description: A web page from a museum exhibition contains a navigation bar containing a long list of links. The page also contains an image of one of the pictures from the exhibition, a heading for the picture, and a detailed description of the picture. The links in the navigation bar form a meaningful sequence. The heading, image, and text of the description also form a meaningful sequence. CSS is used to position the elements on the page.
examples.code:
My Museum Page

  • Link 1
    • ...
  • Link 10

Mona Lisa

...detailed description of the picture...

remediations.name: Document of captions + audio desc is linked next to non-text content
remediations.description: Provide a link to the collated document of captions and audio desc. The collated document could be at another location on the same web page or at another URI. A link to the collated document should be immediately adjacent to the non-text content. The link can be immediately before or after the synced media content. If the collated document is on the same web page as other content, then put "End of document" at the end so that they know when to stop reading and return to their previous place. If a Back button does not return to the starting point, then a link back to the non-text content location should be provided.

examples.name: Example 1: A .MOV Document in an HTML Document
examples.description: Code on a page called "olympic-sports.html"
examples.code: Olympic wrestling movie, Olympic wrestling collated transcript

examples.name: Example 2: The link back to the .MOV document in an HTML document
examples.description: Code on the page olympic-wrestling-transcript.html
examples.code:
Sports announcer 1: This is a great battle tonight between England's "Will Johnson" and "Theodore Derringo" from Argentina.

Scenery: There is a mat set out in the middle of the stadium with 500 people in the stands...

...more dialogue...

...more scenery...

...etc...

Sports announcer 2: And that is all for tonight, thank you for joining us tonight where Will Johnson is the new Gold Medalist. Return to movie page

remediations.name: Focus on interactive elements follows content sequence and relationships
remediations.description: Ensure that interactive elements receive focus in an order that follows sequences and relationships in the content. When designing the content, the interactive elements (links, form controls) are placed in the content to follow the default, logical tab order. The mechanism for placing the controls in the content depends on the technology. For example, in HTML, the default focus order follows the order in which elements appear in the content source.

remediations.name: Webpage sound stops in 3 sec or less
remediations.description: Allow authors to play a sound on their Webpage but allow users to use screen readers and avoid interferences. Avoid controls on the Webpage to manage the sound and make these controls easy to find by users with screen readers. The sound should play for 3 or less seconds and then stop automatically.

remediations.name: Content components are repeated in the same order
remediations.description: Make websites more predictable by maintaining the same relative order of repeated components like navigation menus, headers, or sidebars across web pages. While other elements can be added or removed between existing components, the relative positioning of repeated elements should remain consistent, helping users develop expectations about where to find familiar interface elements and navigation links.

remediations.name: Webpage has glossary
remediations.description: Make the definition of a word, phrase, or abbreviation available by providing a glossary (an alphabetical list of words, phrases, and abbreviations with their definitions), maybe with the correct pronunciation as well, at the end of the web page or via one of the mechanisms for locating content within a set of web pages (see Understanding Success Criterion 2.4.5.). If the glossary contains several definitions for the same term, simply providing the glossary is not sufficient to satisfy this Success Criterion, so use a different technique to find the correct definition.

remediations.name: Webpage has a site map
remediations.description:
Provide a site map with links to different sections of the site, accessible from every page listed in the map through a consistent link. Site maps help users understand site organization and provide an alternative way to locate content, ranging from simple outline formats to more complex expandable structures, but must be kept current with site updates to remain effective. 
See the examples in the original technique.

remediations.name: Webpage has TOC
remediations.description: Provide a table of contents with links to sections and subsections within the same hierarchical document, whether those sections appear on one page or are spread across multiple pages. Unlike site maps or navigation bars that cover the entire website, a table of contents specifically organizes and provides access to parts of a single cohesive document, helping users understand the document structure and navigate directly to relevant sections.

remediations.name: Webpage has breadcrumb navigation
remediations.description: Use a breadcrumb trail (or 'breadcrumb navigation') to help the user visualize content. Users can even identify the current location in the series of web pages, commonly as the last element in the trail and with a variation in its visual style. Breadcrumb trails are implemented using links to the web pages that have been accessed in the process of navigating to the current web page. They are placed in the same location within each web page in the set. It can be helpful to users to separate the items in the breadcrumb trailing with a visible separator. Examples of separators include ">", "|", "/", and "". Alternatively, one could use decorative iconography or create separators with CSS.

examples.name: Example 1: Photographer's portfolio
examples.description: A photographer's portfolio website has been organized into different galleries and each gallery has further been divided into categories. A user who navigates through the website to a particular page containing a photo of a Gentoo penguin would see the following breadcrumb trail at the top of the web page:
examples.code: Home / Galleries / Antarctica / Penguins / Gentoo Penguin

examples.name: Example 2: E-commerce site
examples.description: The information architecture of an e-commerce website is categorized from general to increasingly more specific product subsections.
examples.code:
You are here:

  • Acme Company →
  • Electronics →
  • Computers →
  • Laptops

remediations.name: Short text alt describes the purpose of audio- and video-only content
remediations.description: Provide a short text alt for live audio-only and live video-only content to help users identify what the non-text content is, even when they cannot access it directly. While this brief desc can work alongside full alternatives such as transcripts or audio descs, its primary purpose is to ensure users can recognize and understand the nature of the live content when they encounter it, preventing confusion and helping them connect it with any comprehensive alts.

remediations.name: Synchronized media presentation has accessible alternative
remediations.description: Provide a full text alt that tells the same story as synced media by creating a document (screenplay) including all important dialogue, actions, and background descriptions. The text alt should match the final edited version of the media and include mechanisms like links to replicate any interactive elements, allowing users to access the same information and options available in the original synchronized media presentation.

remediations.name: Webpage links to online dictionary for words/phrases/jargon etc.
remediations.description: Provide the definition of words, phrases, jargon, or abbreviation expansions via mechanism to access an external, online dictionary. By providing access from within the web page, a user can easily locate the desired definition. This technique can only be used if the online dictionary returns the correct definition.

remediations.name: Form on each web page has context sensitive help
remediations.description: Provide context sensitive help for data entry into forms by providing at least one link to the help information on each Webpage or to provide a help link for every interactive control. Positioning this link immediately before or after the control allows users to easily tab to it if they have problems in the control. Displaying the help information in a new browser window ensures that any data that has already been entered into the form will not be lost.

examples.name: Example 1
examples.description: The example shows a label element that includes a help link. Including the help link within the label element allows screen reader users to have access to the help link when interacting with the input form control.

remediations.name: Non-text content has long desc elsewhere, with adjacent link
remediations.description: Provide a link to a detailed description of non-text content that is located elsewhere, either within the same page or at a different location. The link should be placed immediately adjacent to the non-text content, and if the description is mixed with other text, it should end with "End of description" to clearly indicate where users should stop reading and return to the main content.

remediations.name: Non-text content short desc links to long desc in another location
remediations.description: Provide long descs as part of the standard page content so all users can access them, rather than requiring navigation to separate locations. The detailed desc is placed near the non-text content (such as in a following paragraph after a chart), and the short text alt indicates where to find the full description, making it discoverable for users who cannot view the non-text content.

remediations.name: Webpage users can postpone content update
remediations.description: Enable users to postpone automatic updates of content or other non-emergency interruptions either through a preference or by alerting users of an imminent update and allowing them to suppress it. If a preference is provided, automatic content update can be deactivated by default and users can specify the frequency of automatic content updates if they choose to enable the setting.

remediations.name: Users can control if and when the content gets updated
remediations.description: Users should have control over when content updates occur instead of forcing automatic refreshes that can cause confusion or disorientation. Automatic updates can disrupt screen readers and can disorient users of screen magnification or those with reading disabilities, so providing user-initiated update mechanisms allows people to refresh content when they choose rather than having it happen unexpectedly.

examples.name: Example 1: Providing a button to update content
examples.description: In HTML, a developer can provide a button or link that allows the user to update the contentfor example, on a page with news items.
examples.code: <button type="button">Update this page</button>

remediations.name: A second audio track includes audio desc
remediations.description: Provide an audio version of visual information via soundtrack where audio descs are added to the original audio track during pauses in dialogue and sound effects. The audio desc should focus on important visual elements like actions, characters, scene changes, and on-screen text, and can be provided either as an alternative soundtrack users can select, or as the standard soundtrack available to all viewers.

remediations.name: Text content has spoken version
remediations.description: The webpage should provide the text read aloud, using either recorded human speech or synthetic speech. For example, there are a number of products that authors can use to convert text to synthetic speech, then save the spoken version as an audio file. A link to the spoken version can then be provided within the content. Cost depends in part on the quality of the voice used and whether the text is likely to change frequently.

remediations.name: Users can change context using a Submit button
remediations.description: Provide an explicit mechanism for users to request context changes by using Submit buttons, which have the expected purpose of submitting form data and generating HTTP requests. Using Submit buttons for context changes is appropriate because users understand their intended function, preventing confusion that might arise from unexpected or automatic context changes.

remediations.name: Sign language interpreter is synced and displayed in different viewport/overlaid
remediations.description: Provide a separate synced video stream of sign language interpretation for users who may have difficulty reading captions at the presented speed. The sign language video can be overlaid on the original video or displayed separately, with the option to enlarge the interpreter to make hand, body, and facial movements more visible, and authors must choose the appropriate sign language for their intended audience.

remediations.name: Text alt identifies the purpose of non-text content
remediations.description:
Provide useful info via text alt even if the full function of the non-text content cannot be provided. 
Sometimes, a text alt cannot serve the same purpose as the original non-text content (for example an applet meant to develop two-dimensional rapid targeting skills and eye hand coordination.) In these cases, this technique is used. With this technique, a description of the purpose of the non-text content is provided.

remediations.name: User is notified when mandatory field has not been completed
remediations.description: Notify the user when a field that must be completed has not been completed. When failing to complete a mandatory form field, the user should be notified and pointed to which fields were omitted. Use client-side validation and provide an alert dialog box identifying the mandatory fields which were omitted, or use server-side validation to re-display the form (including any previously entered data), with either a text desc at the location of the omitted mandatory field, or a text desc that identifies the omitted mandatory fields.

remediations.name: Form user input errors are described in an accessible manner
remediations.description: Input validation errors should be communicated to users through accessible text descs, either via alert dialogs when errors are detected or by returning the form with descriptive error messages at the top of the page. Visual indicators like asterisks or red labels alone are insufficient; clear text descriptions must explain the nature of problems, and when input must match specific allowed values, the description should indicate this requirement and provide the list of acceptable values or suggest the closest valid option.

remediations.name: Webpage provides assistance in correcting form input errors
remediations.description: Provide text-based assistance for correcting input errors. Describe the nature and location of problems when user data is not accepted during validation. Whether using client-side alerts or server-side redisplay of forms with error descriptions, the text should help users by explaining what the error is, providing examples of correct input, or giving specific instructions on how to fix the problem.

remediations.name: Complex content is summarized, simplified
remediations.description:
Provide a summary of complex content in addition to the original content. Provide short statements of the most important ideas and information in the content. You can follow the following steps:
1. Identify the most important ideas and information in the content.
2. Write one or more paragraphs that use shorter sentences and more common words to express the same ideas and information (the number of paragraphs depends on the length of the original).
3. Measure the readability of the summary.
4. Edit the summary. Consider dividing longer sentences into two or replacing long or unfamiliar words with shorter, more common terms.
5. Repeat steps 3 and 4 as needed.

remediations.name: Time-based media has closed captions
remediations.description: Provide embedded captions for synced media that include all dialogue and important sounds in the same language as the video, but remain hidden unless users specifically request them.

remediations.name: Each webpage has a descriptive title
remediations.description: Provide descriptive titles for web pages that identify the subject matter and make sense when read out of context, helping users find content, orient themselves, and navigate effectively. The title should be short and clear, allowing users to quickly identify content in search results, site maps, or when announced by screen readers, and may also include site identification and be unique within the website for better navigation.

examples.name: Example 1: A title that lists the most important identifying information first
examples.description: A web page is published by a group within a larger organization. The title of the web page first identifies the topic of the page, then shows the group name followed by the name of the parent organization.
examples.code: <title>Working with us: The Small Group: The Big Organization</title>

examples.name: Example 3: A web page with a descriptive title in three parts
examples.description: A web page provides guidelines and suggestions for creating closed captions. The web page is part of a "sub-site" within a larger site. The title is separated into three parts by dashes. The first part of the title identifies the organization. The second part identifies the sub-site to which the web page belongs. The third part identifies the web page itself.
examples.code: <title>Computer Hardware Corporation - Laptop Division - Laptop FAQs</title>

remediations.name: Expected data format is provided as an example
remediations.description: Help users avoid input errors by informing them about restrictions on the format of data that they must enter. This can be done by describing characteristics of the format or providing a sample of the format the data should have.

examples.name: Example 1: Date text input
examples.description: The following HTML form control for a date indicates in the label that the date must be in day-month-year format, not month-day-year as many users in the United States may assume.
examples.code:
<label for="date">Date (dd-mm-yyyy)</label>
 <input type="text" name="date" id="date">

remediations.name: Webpage has keyboard-triggered event handlers
remediations.description: Enable individuals who rely on a keyboard or keyboard interface to access the functionality of the content. To do this, make sure that all event handlers triggered by non-keyboard UI events are also associated with a keyboard-based event, or provide redundant keyboard-based mechanisms to accomplish the functionality provided by other device-specific functions.

remediations.name: The purpose of a link is described in the link text
remediations.description: Describe the purpose of a link in the text of the link. The description should enable users to distinguish this link from the links in the web page that lead to other destinations and helps the user determine whether to follow the link. Make the URI of the destination sufficiently descriptive.

examples.name: Example 1: Describing the purpose of a link in HTML in the text content of the a element
examples.code: Current routes at Boulders Climbing Gym

remediations.name: Long descriptions are meaningful, provide the same information
remediations.description: Provide comprehensive text alts by combining short text alts with detailed long descs that together can fully substitute for non-text content. The short alt identifies what the content is while the long desc provides all the essential information, ensuring that if the non-text content were replaced entirely with these text alts, the page would maintain the same function and convey the same info to users.

remediations.name: Video content has open (always visible) captions
remediations.description:
Provide a way for the hearing impaired to view audio visual material in the same human language. With this technique all of the dialogue and important sounds are embedded as text in the video track. As a result, they are always visible and no special support for captioning is required by the user agent.
NOTE: Captions should not be confused with subtitles. Subtitles provide text of only the dialogue, in a different human language, and do not include important sounds.

remediations.name: Non-text content has short text alternative
remediations.description: Create text alts that serve the same purpose and convey the same info as the original non-text content, completely replacing the non-text content without losing functionality or info. The text alt should not necessarily describe what the content looks like but should accomplish the same goal, and when non-text content contains important words, those words should be included in the alt text or provided through a combination of short and long text alts if the content is too extensive.

remediations.name: Short text alt provides brief description of non-text content
remediations.description: Provide a short text alt that briefly describes non-text content when the full equivalent info is too lengthy for a short alt or cannot be achieved with text alone. The short desc is designed to work in combination with a long text alt provided through another technique, so together they serve the same purpose and present the same info as the original non-text content.

remediations.name: Webpage items are also referenced in non-sensory ways
remediations.description: Ensure items within a web page are referenced in the content not only by shape, size, sound or location, but also in ways that do not depend on sensory perceptions. For example, a reference can also describe the function of the item or its label.

examples.name: Example 3: Button referenced by position and accessible name
examples.description: The following layout places a button in the lower right corner and indicates it by position. An indication of the text label clarifies which button to use for users for which the position is not meaningful.
examples.code:
Sign up to our mailing list

Complete the form and then press the lower-right (sign up) button.

remediations.name: The expanded form of an abbreviation is available on its first occurrence
remediations.description: Provide the expanded form of abbreviations by associating the full form with the abbreviated form at its first occurrence on a web page. Make expansions findable when searching for the first occurrence. The full form should be provided before the abbreviated form to improve readability, though this technique is not suitable for abbreviations that require explanations rather than simple expansions.

remediations.name: Users can review and correct answers before submitting
remediations.description: Users should be able to review and confirm their input before completing irreversible transactions in testing, financial, or legal applications where errors cannot be corrected after submission. For multi-step forms, this can be accomplished by either allowing users to navigate back through previous steps to review data or by providing a summary of all collected info for review before the final commitment step.

remediations.name: Deleted information can be recovered
remediations.description: Provide data recovery mechanisms when web applications allow users to delete info by either marking data for deletion and delaying actual removal for a recovery period, or by maintaining detailed delete transaction records that enable data restoration. The stored info should include whatever would be needed to correct the deletion transaction, similar to trash cans or edit histories in wikis and version control systems.

remediations.name: Non-text content has short text alternative
remediations.description: Allow users to identify non-text content even when it is intended to provide a specific sensory experience that they cannot access. Examples: Enabling deaf users to know what an audio instrumental file contains or blind users to understand what a visual image depicts. The text alt provides identification rather than attempting to replicate the sensory experience itself.

remediations.name: Words used in unusual or restricted ways have definition
remediations.description: Provide definitions for words used in unusual or restricted ways, including terms with meanings that differ from their usual sense, jargon from specific professions or technical fields, and idiomatic expressions understood in particular regions. The goal is to clarify specialized vocabulary that may not be understood by people outside the specific context where these terms are commonly used.

remediations.name: Abbreviations are explained
remediations.description: Explain abbreviations by offering the full word, phrase, or name for most cases. However, providing explanations instead of expansions when abbreviations come from foreign languages or when the original expansion is no longer appropriate. Some abbreviations that have become standard language or whose original expansions have been rejected by organizations may be treated as regular words that do not require explanation.

remediations.name: Text has visual illustrations to explain concepts or processes
remediations.description:
Provide visual illustrations in addition to the text so users with reading disabilities can understand difficult text that describes concepts or processes. 
For example:
- Charts and graphs help users understand complex data.
- Diagrams, flowcharts, videos, and animations help users understand processes.
- Concept maps and other graphic organizers help users understand how ideas are related to each other.
- Photographs, drawings, and videos can help users understand natural or historical events or objects.

remediations.name: Entered data is saved and can be reused after logout
remediations.description: Handle session timeouts during data entry by temporarily caching user data when authentication expires, allowing users to re-authenticate and continue with their saved form data without losing their input. The server maintains this temporary cache for a limited period (such as one day) to ensure successful completion after re-authentication within the same user session.

remediations.name: Changes of context are triggered by "activate" rather than "focus"
remediations.description: Ensure that changes of context are triggered only by predictable user actions like clicking links or pressing Submit buttons, preventing unexpected events that can confuse users with cognitive disabilities or those using screen readers and screen magnifiers. Actions that simply move focus to elements should not cause changes of context, maintaining user control over when significant changes occur.

remediations.name: Alternate UI conveys equivalent information, allows users to operate through AT
remediations.description: Use standard, documented features of technologies to ensure AT can understand web content and provide equivalent info through alternate interfaces while allowing users to operate controls through the AT. While standard controls in browsers typically meet accessibility requirements automatically, authors must still provide essential info like names for controls, even though roles may be built into standard components.

remediations.name: Client-side redirects do not confuse the user
remediations.description: Use client-side redirects only when server-side redirects are not available, and ensure the redirecting page contains only info related to the redirect to avoid confusing users. Server-side redirects are preferable because they do not display new content before sending the content from the new URI, but when authors lack control over server-side technologies, client-side redirects can be implemented through code that instructs the user agent to retrieve content from a different location.

remediations.name: Patterns convey same info as image color differences
remediations.description: Ensure that when color differences are used to convey info within non-text content, patterns are included to convey the same info in a manner that does not depend on color.

remediations.name: Word used in unusual or restricted way have definition
remediations.description: Provide a definition (in context) for any word used in an unusual or restricted way. The definition is provided in the text, either just before or just after the word is used.
