The definition may be included in the same sentence as the word that is being defined, or in a separate sentence.

remediations.name: Semantic elements mark up structure
remediations.description: Use appropriate semantic elements (according to their meaning rather than their visual appearance) to mark up the structure of web content. Mark content roles explicitly (paragraphs, headers, emphasized text, tables) and indicate relationships between content units so UA can make the structure perceivable through different visual presentations or auditory cues, such as using HTML phrase-level elements like em, abbr, and cite or MathML's semantic markup for mathematical concepts.

examples.name: Example 1: Linking to another page
examples.description: A paragraph contains a hyperlink to another page. The hyperlink is marked up using the a element.
examples.code: Do you want to try our new tool yourself? A free demonstration version is available in our download section

examples.name: Example 2: Using cite and blockquote to reference a book and a quotation from it
examples.description: A page about the history of marriage uses a quotation from Jane Austen's novel, Pride and Prejudice, as an example. The reference to the book is marked up using the cite element and the quotation itself is marked up using the blockquote element.
examples.code:
Marriage was considered a logical step for a bachelor, as can be seen in the first chapter of the novel Pride and Prejudice:

It is a truth universally acknowledged, that a single man in possession of a good fortune, must be in want of a wife.

However little known the feelings or views of such a man may be on his first entering a neighbourhood, this truth is so well fixed in the minds of the surrounding families, that he is considered the rightful property of some one or other of their daughters.

examples.name: Example 3: Using the strong element to emphasize important text
examples.description: A car manual explains how to start the engine. The instructions include a warning to make sure the gear is in neutral. The author feels the warning is so important that it should be emphasized so the warning is marked up using the strong element.
examples.code:
How to start the engine

Before starting the engine, make sure the gear is in neutral Next, turn the key in the ignition. The engine should start.

examples.name: Example 4: Using the em and strong elements to emphasize text
examples.code: What the user really meant to say was, This is not ok, it is excellent!

examples.name: Example 5: Using highlighting and background color to visually and semantically identify important information
examples.code:
...

New vocabulary words are emphasized and highlighted with a cyan background.

The scathing review of the play seemed a bit too harsh.

remediations.name: Text explains text formatting info (bold, italics, underlined)
remediations.description: Ensure that info conveyed through formatting variations (font changes, size, underline, strikethrough) is also stated explicitly in the text itself. When visual text variations communicate meaning, provide that same info elsewhere in the content through additional document sections or inline descs where the formatting occurs, so the info remains accessible regardless of how the text appears visually.

examples.name: Example 1: Indicating new content with boldface and a text indicator
examples.description: The following example shows a list of accessibility standards. WCAG 2.2 is new, so is indicated in bold face. To avoid conveying information solely by presentation, the word "(new)" is included after it as well.
examples.code:
Web Accessibility Guidelines

  • WCAG 2.2 (New)
  • WCAG 2.1
  • WCAG 2.0
  • Section 508
  • JIS X 8341-3
    • ...

remediations.name: Webpage provides pronunciation of words locally
remediations.description: Provide pronunciation after the word at least the first time it occurs within a web page. When words with the same spelling have different pronunciations, provide pronunciation for each instance rather than just the first occurrence. When combining multiple resources into a single page, provide pronunciation at the beginning of each resource or consider using different techniques for pronunciation guidance.

examples.name: Example 1
examples.description: In the following example of Japanese text, the information giving the pronunciation in Han characters (Kanji) is rendered in parentheses immediately following the text.

remediations.name: Webpage provides pronunciation of words via link
remediations.description: Make the pronunciation of a word available by providing information about the pronunciation, either within the same web page or in a different web page, and establishing a link between the item and its pronunciation.

remediations.name: Top link enables skipping to end of content block
remediations.description: Provide a mechanism to bypass a block of material by skipping to the end of the block. The first link in the block or the link directly preceding the block moves focus to the content immediately after the block. Activating the link advances the keyboard focus past the block. When there are multiple blocks to be skipped, the user skips from block to block via these links.

examples.name: Example 4: HTML page with several blocks of navigation
examples.description: This example demonstrates both the use of heading elements at the beginning of each section (H69) and links that skip to the end of each section. This allows people to skip blocks of repeated content using keyboard navigation or using heading navigation, depending on the capabilities of their UA.
examples.code:
skip navigation

Main Navigation

  • Sub Navigation
  • Link A
  • Link B
  • Link C

Sub Navigation

  • Ultra Sub Navigation
  • Sub A
  • Sub B
  • Sub C

Content title

Now that I have your attention...

remediations.name: Each webpage area has top link
remediations.description: Provide a mechanism to bypass blocks of material by providing a list of links to the different sections of the content. The links in this list, like a small table of contents at the beginning of the content, set focus to the different sections of the content. This technique is particularly useful for pages with many independent sections, such as portals. It may also be combined with other techniques for skipping blocks within a section.

remediations.name: Users can locate additional info using links to related Web pages
remediations.description: Provide links to related web pages so users can locate additional info, which is sufficient for addressing Success Criterion 2.4.5.

remediations.name: Each Webpage contains a list of links to the other Webpages
remediations.description:
Provide, on each web page, a list of links to all the web pages in the set. 
This is one of the several techniques for locating content that are sufficient for addressing Success Criterion 2.4.5. However, it is only effective for small sets of web pages; if the list of links is longer than the rest of the content in the web page, it may make the web page more difficult for users to understand and use.

remediations.name: Identify a webpage's relationship with other webpages in collection
remediations.description: Enable users to identify the relationship between the current Webpage and other Webpages in the same collection (e.g., on the same website). This can be done programmaticallyfor example, by using the "rel" attribute of the link element in HTML, in other cases the information is provided by including the relevant data in the title of the Webpage.

remediations.name: Current location is indicated within navigation bars
remediations.description: Help orient the user by providing info about the current location by adding an icon or text, or by changing the state of the item. This technique is especially useful when the web pages are steps in a task that must be processed in a certain order. Providing this indication helps the user to better understand their place in the sequence.

remediations.name: Section headings within the Web content are descriptive
remediations.description: Make section headings descriptive, helping users find specific content and orient themselves within the page. Consider placing the most important info at the beginning of each heading to help users skim headings effectively when navigating from heading to heading with browsers or AT.

examples.name: Example 1: An HTML page that describes the range of tasks for disaster preparation
examples.description: Note that the level 2 headings have the distinguishing information at the beginning (i.e., instead of "Preparation for floods", "Preparation for fires", etc.).
examples.code:
Disaster preparation

Flood preparation

Fire preparation

remediations.name: Interface components have meaningful labels
remediations.description: Ensure the label for any interactive component within Web content makes the component's purpose clear. Use the specific techniques for associating labels with interactive controls to allow AT to recognize the label and present its purpose to the user. The label may also include text or a text symbol indicating that input is required.

remediations.name: Users can request additional time to complete multipart forms
remediations.description:
Provide a checkbox to request additional time for users with disabilities when they complete multipart forms. The checkbox can allow the user to request a specific amount of additional time (for example 15 minutes) or an indefinite extension. 
Note that allowing an indefinite extension would be inappropriate if it jeopardized user privacy or network security.

remediations.name: AT understands and conveys equivalent info through alternate UI
remediations.description: Use UI components that are already programmed to interface with accessibility APIs when creating content with programming languages or tools. Fill in the required properties (such as names) to ensure the resulting UI components are accessible to AT. This allows AT to understand the web content and convey equivalent info to users through alternate user interfaces.

remediations.name: Color and semantic markup combine to convey information
remediations.description: Combine color and semantic markup to convey info. This ensures that users who cannot see color access the same info through semantic cues that UAs can present through visual or auditory methods. Use proper semantic markup that most UAs will visually distinguish and that ATs can identify, allowing users to quickly scan content for info conveyed by color while providing alternative access methods for those who need them.

remediations.name: Users can easily find input errors
remediations.description: Help users find input errors by providing links to fields with missing info or incorrect data when validation detects problems. Use server-side validation to redisplay the form with previously entered data and place a text desc at the top of the page that indicates input errors occurred, describes the problem nature, and includes links to the problematic fields so users do not have to search for errors.

remediations.name: Structural encoding is separated from presentational encoding
remediations.description: Separate structural encoding from presentational encoding to facilitate AT interaction with content by using structural features (headings, paragraphs, lists, tables) rather than relying on visual formatting alone. While presentational features like typeface, color, and positioning visually imply structure, they do not provide unambiguous encoding for AT. Therefore, maintaining separate structure, functionality, and presentation layers makes the semantics PD rather than just visually apparent.

remediations.name: Webpage is structured using headings
remediations.description: Ensure section headings are marked so they can be programmatically identified. In HTML, this can be done using the HTML heading elements (h1, h2, h3, h4, h5, and h6), which allow UAs to automatically identify section headings. Other technologies use other techniques for identifying headers. Authors should use headings that are properly nested (e.g., h1 followed by h2, h2 followed by h2 or h3, h3 followed by h3 or h4, etc.).

examples.name: Example 1: Headings used to organize an HTML page
examples.description: A page on cooking techniques uses an h1 element for the overall title, and h2 elements for major sections on cooking with oil vs cooking with butter, and h3 elements for sub-sections on oil-cooking techniques.
examples.code:
Cooking techniques

... some text here ...

Cooking with oil

... text of the section ...

Sauteing

...

Deep frying

Cooking with butter

... text of the section ...

remediations.name: Webpage content supports user agent zoom
remediations.description: Ensure content scales uniformly using a technology supported by UAs, which changes text size via a Zoom tool. Content should be authored in technologies supported by UAs that can scale content (zoom into content) uniformly. We recommend that you test with a wide variety of UAs, making sure the zoom function preserve all spatial relationships on the page and that all functionality continues to be available.

remediations.name: CAPTCHA purpose is explained by text alt
remediations.description: Provide info via the text alt that identifies the non-text content as a CAPTCHA. Such tests often involve asking the user to type in text that is presented in an obscured image or audio file. From the text alt, the user can tell that the CAPTCHA requires completing a task and what type of task it is. When an alternate version of a CAPTCHA is available, the text alt should include instructions about how to find the alternate version.

remediations.name: A CAPTCHA alternative is provided
remediations.description: Use an alternate CAPTCHA to reduce the occasions in which a user with a disability cannot complete a CAPTCHA task. Because there are alternate CAPTCHA tasks that use different modalities, a user is more likely to be able to complete one of the tasks successfully.

remediations.name: Text/images of text have min 3:1 contrast ratio
remediations.description: Ensure large-scale text (18+ point regular or 14+ point bold) maintains a 3:1 contrast ratio with its background, which is a relaxed requirement compared to the standard 4.5:1 ratio for smaller text. For solid backgrounds, maintain the contrast directly, but for varied/patterned backgrounds, use techniques like shading areas behind letters, adjusting text luminance as background changes, or adding halos around text to achieve the necessary contrast ratio.

remediations.name: Webpage layout is "liquid"
remediations.description: Use liquid layouts that adapt to available horizontal space to present content without introducing horizontal scroll bars by defining layout regions that resize with text and reflow as needed. Apply basic principles of liquid layouts where regions resize proportionally and elements reflow while maintaining element relationships and reading order. Designs should work well across different devices and user font size preferences.

examples.name: Example 1: Simple liquid layout in HTML and CSS
examples.description: The following fairly simple example uses HTML and CSS to create a liquid layout. The three columns adjust their size as text size is adjusted. When the total horizontal width exceeds the available width of the columns, the last column wraps to be positioned below, rather than beside, the previous column. The font size can be increased without either clipping or introducing horizontal scrolling until the longest word no longer fits in a column. This particular example uses percent sizes for the columns and defines them as floating regions using the "float" property.
examples.code:
WCAG Example

Text in Three Columns

Block 1

The objective of this technique is to be able to present content without introducing horizontal scroll bars by using layout techniques that adapt to the available horizontal space.

Block 2

This is a very simple example of a page layout that adapts as the text size changes.

Block 3

For techniques that support more complex page layouts, see the Resources listed below.

Footer text

remediations.name: Webpage background & text color is not specified
remediations.description: Avoid specifying text color and background color so that both are completely determined by the UA, eliminating the need for contrast measurements and preventing conflicts with user-set colors. This approach helps users with vision disabilities who override certain colors in their user agent or AT by ensuring the website does not conflict with user preferences, keeping content visible.

remediations.name: Focusable components can be visually identified using UA support
remediations.description: Ensure that the focused component can be visually identified by the user by relying on UA support. UA commonly highlight standard controls when they receive focus. UAAG-conformant UAs do so when they satisfy checkpoint 10.2 "Highlight selection, content focus, enabled elements, visited links". Standard controls supported by the UA informs users of the focus location in a standard, predictable way.

remediations.name: Real-time transcript is provided to live audio
remediations.description: Hearing-impaired users should be able to access real-time audio broadcasts via real-time typing techniques (stenographic and rapid typing). Re-voicing speech-to-text (where a person listens to speech and then carefully re-voices it into a computer trained to their speech) is used today for telephone relay services and may be used in the future for captioning.

remediations.name: A transcript/script is provided
remediations.description: Provide a transcript or script for live audio content that follows a set script, since pre-written materials can be more accurate and complete than live transcription. Include a conforming link to the transcript (located elsewhere on the same page or at another URI), but ensure the live audio does not deviate from the script since the transcript will not be synced with the audio as it plays.

remediations.name: Animated gif images stop blinking within five seconds
remediations.description: Ensure animated gif images stop blinking within five seconds by adjusting the number of frames, frame rate, or repetitions using the calculation: duration = frames  frame rate  repetitions (or sum of individual frame rates  repetitions for variable timing). Calculate the maximum repetitions by dividing five seconds by the animation cycle duration and truncating down to the nearest integer, or if one cycle exceeds five seconds, reduce frames or increase frame rate while ensuring faster rates do not violate general flash or red flash thresholds, especially for large images.

remediations.name: The text of the Webpage is not difficult to read
remediations.description:
Ensure text does not require reading ability beyond lower secondary education level by developing single topics per paragraph, using simple sentence forms (Subject-Verb-Object), and limiting sentences to 25 words or fewer with no more than two conjunctions. Replace professional jargon and complex words with common terms, remove redundant words, use active voice and consistent verb tenses, indicate logical relationships clearly, and consider using bulleted lists instead of long comma-separated series.
See more recommendations in the original technique.

remediations.name: A checkbox ensures users can review input
remediations.description: Provide a checkbox labelled "I confirm that the input is correct and am ready to submit" (or similar) before committing irreversible transactions or data deletions. Place the checkbox near the Submit button and reject submissions when it remains unselected, prompting users to review and resubmit. This technique provides a mechanism for reviewing, confirming, and correcting info before finalizing submissions.

remediations.name: Users can change the foreground and background of blocks of text
remediations.description: Design web pages to work with browser color controls that allow users to override foreground and background colors, and avoid overriding these user-controlled settings. Some users with cognitive disabilities require specific color combinations to understand content, but overriding all text colors may hide visual grouping cues and make pages harder to understand. Consider alternative techniques like specifying colors only for secondary content areas while leaving main content colors user-controllable to maintain both accessibility and visual structure.

remediations.name: Web page provides live audio captioning service
remediations.description: Use a real-time caption service to provide a text version of live audio content. Such services use a trained human operator who listens in to what is being said and uses a special keyboard to enter the text with only a small delay. They are able to capture a live event with a high degree of fidelity, and also to insert notes on any non-spoken audio, essential to understanding the event. The viewport containing the caption text is available on the same web page as the live audio content.

remediations.name: Audio content has accurate alternative
remediations.description: Provide an accessible alternative way of presenting the info in audio-only presentations. Create a document that tells the same story and presents the same info in the same human language as the prerecorded audio-only content. The document serves as long desc for the content and includes all of the important dialogue and as well as descriptions of background sounds etc. that are part of the story.

remediations.name: Video content has accurate alternative
remediations.description: Provide an accessible alternative way of presenting the info in a video-only presentation. Create a document that tells the same story and presents the same info as the prerecorded video-only content. The document serves as a long desc for the content and includes all of the important information as well as descriptions of scenery, actions, expressions, etc. that are part of the presentation.

remediations.name: Sign language version explains difficult content
remediations.description: Provide sign language versions of content to help signing hearing impaired/cognitively disabled users understand difficult text about concepts or processes, offering this as supplemental content in addition to written text. Embed the sign language video directly in the Webpage or provide links to video players or separate pages, ensuring the video captures the complete three-dimensional visual language by recording the signer as close to the camera as possible without cut-offs of hands or other essential signing elements.

remediations.name: Webpage has search functionality
remediations.description: Provide a search function so users can find content without navigating through the website, which can be quicker and easier especially on large sites. Include an accessible search form (text field and trigger button) or link to a search page, and consider implementing features like spell-checking, stemming, and synonym support to increase accessibility. Use search optimization techniques like keywords, META tags, and accessible navigation structure to make internal searches more effective.

remediations.name: Form fields labels are positioned where visually expected
remediations.description: Position labels where users expect them visually to make complex forms easier to understand and help users locate specific fields. Place labels immediately before input fields (to the left or above for LtR languages, to the right or above for RtL languages). Position labels after radio buttons and checkboxes since these controls have uniform width while their labels vary, allowing both buttons and labels to align vertically.

remediations.name: Users can turn standard diacritical marks on or off
remediations.description: Provide a mechanism for turning standard diacritical marks on/off. Many languages use diacritical marks to indicate pronunciation or to help distinguish between words. Some languages may use diacritics to denote vowels, to indicate consonant doubling, to indicate the absence of a vowel or a consonant, or for other purposes. Although text without such diacritics can still be readable, diacritics can improve readability.

remediations.name: User can change/cancel an order by using a grace period
remediations.description: Provide users with a cancellation period after submitting orders to allow recovery from errors, clearly informing them of the cancellation timeframe and procedure immediately after submitting. Offer the cancellation procedure on the same website where the transaction was submitted when possible to maintain equivalent accessibility. If alternative mechanisms are necessary, warn users before form submission that online cancellation will not be available and ensure any alternative procedures have equivalent cross-disability accessibility.

remediations.name: Users can customize and enhance the rendering of the focus indicator
remediations.description: Use the native focus indicator provided by operating systems and UAs since it allows users to customize its appearance and enables AT to locate and modify it as needed. Avoid creating custom focus indicators, as these will not inherit user customization settings and AT will not be able to find or modify them effectively.

remediations.name: Accurate audio description is provided to important video content
remediations.description: Provide video-only content with audio alt. You can provide an audio track describing the info in the video in the human language of the page. The audio should be a common format used on the internet, such as MP3.

examples.name: Example 1
examples.description: A web page has a link to a video-only presentation of a spaceship landing on Mars. The link to the video is a picture of a spaceship. Near the video is a link to an audio file of a person describing the video. This would look something like the following code example in HTML.
examples.code: Audio description of "Mars Landing"

remediations.name: The purpose of a field is labeled using an adjacent button
remediations.description: When a button invokes a function on an input field, has a clear text label or name, and is rendered adjacent to the input field, the button also acts as a label for the input field. This label helps users understand the purpose of the field without introducing repetitive text on the web page. Buttons that label single text fields typically follow the input field.

remediations.name: Requesting confirmation to continue with selected action
remediations.description: Seek confirmation from users before irreversible actions. This helps them avoid submitting forms or deleting data by mistake, especially when actions cannot be undone after completion. Present a confirmation request that clearly informs users of the selected action and consequences of continuing.

remediations.name: Text is aligned on one side
remediations.description: Avoid blocks of text that are justified (aligned to both the left and the right margins) as the spaces between words create "rivers of white" running down the page, which can make the text difficult for some people to read.

examples.name: Example 1
examples.description:
For most technologies, simply leave out any alignment declarations. 
For example, the following text will be justified to the left by default in HTML where the language of the page is left to right.
examples.code: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, ...

remediations.name: Sound control is located near the beginning of the webpage
remediations.description: Provide a control near the beginning of the page to turn off sounds that start automatically when the page loads. Make the control easily and quickly discoverable for users of AT and those with cognitive, learning, and language disabilities. Ensure the control is keyboard operable, located early in the tab and reading order, and clearly labeled to indicate it will stop the automatically playing sounds.

remediations.name: Sound is played only on user request
remediations.description: Provide a way to play sounds only upon user request to give users control over audio content that may interfere with screen reader output.

remediations.name: Webpage has non-justified text version
remediations.description: Provide a version of the page that does not have full justification (both left and right). If unable to do so, provide a feature that removes the justification of text. The control should be easy to find and access and near the beginning of the page.

remediations.name: Movie has audio desc
remediations.description: Provide a second version of video content, where audio descs are combined with the original soundtrack in a single track to make audio-visual material accessible to the visually impaired. Insert the additional audio info during pauses in dialogue and sound effects to avoid obscuring key audio, focusing on actions, characters, scene changes, and on-screen text that are important for understanding content that dialogue alone cannot communicate.

remediations.name: Webpage has contrast controls
remediations.description: Provide a link or control prominently placed on the page that either changes the current page to meet contrast requirements or takes users to an alternate version that conforms to Success Criterion 1.4.3 (4.5:1 for text, 3:1 for large text) or 1.4.6 (7:1 for text, 4.5:1 for large text). Ensure the link or control itself meets contrast requirements, is easy to find, and that the resulting alternate version fully conforms at the claimed level to successfully use this technique.

remediations.name: Webpage has multi color selection tool for foreground/background
remediations.description: Include a color picker control to select and save preferred foreground and background color preferences across the site, helping users who have difficulty reading black text on white backgrounds. Design pages to detect and apply these saved color preferences automatically, providing an easier alternative for users who find it difficult to change colors through browser or operating system settings and may need very specific color combinations like brown on blue.

remediations.name: The webpage's flashing area is small enough
remediations.description: Ensure flashing content that occurs more than 3 times per second occupies less than 25% of a 10-degree visual field (central vision area) to automatically pass flash thresholds without needing to measure the actual flashing rate. For typical 1024x768 displays at standard viewing distances, any single flashing event smaller than 21,824 square pixels in a contiguous area would pass the requirements. However, use alternative techniques with lower resolution displays or closer viewing distances where this calculation may not provide adequate protection.

remediations.name: Incorrect user input triggers correct suggestion
remediations.description: Suggest text when user input is not accepted and possible corrections are known - such as providing correct spelling or similar text from known options. Place suggestions close to the associated form fields (at the top of the form, preceding fields, or next to requiring correction). Make corrections easy to select through mechanisms like checkboxes or radio buttons, or provide search functionality where results are listed on another page when direct field placement is not possible.

remediations.name: Webpage has controls that support 200% text size increase
remediations.description: Provide controls on the Webpage to incrementally increase text size up to 200%. Make these controls easy to find by positioning them prominently on the page with larger text size and high contrast, offering an alternative for older users experiencing age-related vision loss or people with cognitive disabilities who require increased font size but find browser controls difficult to use.

remediations.name: Text resize by up to 200% does not affect content and functionalities
remediations.description: Define layout properties so that text containers can accommodate 200% text resize without loss of content or functionality by ensuring blocks are wide enough to prevent overflow, tall enough to allow text wrapping, or provide scrollbars when resized text no longer fits. Use layout techniques that allow text to wrap within containers or enable scrolling mechanisms to maintain access to all content when users increase text size through their UA.

remediations.name: User can increase task time limit tenfold
remediations.description: Give special needs users enough time to complete tasks which may take them longer than someone without those challenges. Include mechanisms such as a preference setting or a control on the page, letting users change the time limits at the beginning of their session, before any activity that has a time limit. Changes should consist of at least 10 times the default time limit or variable adjustments to change to any value in its range, or ways to change the time limit by discrete increments.

remediations.name: Entered data saved and reused after logout is not stored on the server
remediations.description: Pass user-submitted form data as hidden data to the re-authentication page when sessions time out, allowing the server to either submit the form directly after re-authentication or present the data for review without storing any user info temporarily. Use this technique when storing user data on the server is illegal, poses security risks, or when you want to avoid maintaining stored info and reconnecting it with newly authenticated sessions.

remediations.name: Additional visual cues explain text color differences
remediations.description: Provide redundant visual cues in addition to color when using color alone to convey info such as the status of words or to identify hypertext links within text blocks. Incorporate visual cues like changes to font style, underlining, bold, italics, or font size changes to help users who have difficulty perceiving color differences or have low vision identify important elements that would otherwise rely solely on color for identification.

remediations.name: Webpage text uses 3:1 text contrast ratio + additional visual cues
remediations.description:
Provide a relative luminance difference of 3:1 or greater between link text and surrounding text when relying on color to identify links, and add visual highlights on hover such as underlines, bold, italics, or increased font size. 
However, using only luminance differences may not be obvious to people with low vision, so consider using underlines for links in text blocks when there are not many links present.

remediations.name: Form/fields have text instructions on required input
remediations.description:
Inform users about data format restrictions by providing instructions at the top of forms to help them avoid input errors before entering data. 
Use this technique for forms with few fields or where many fields require the same format, making it more efficient to describe format requirements once rather than repeating the same info for each field with identical restrictions.

remediations.name: Website's Home page links to all webpages
remediations.description: Provide links to all web pages directly from the home page when the website is small enough, making the home page serve as both standard navigation and a site map. Include links to the home page from all other pages, and consider providing links to all other pages from every page to create consistent navigation that helps users locate any content within the small website structure.

remediations.name: Users can stop moving or blinking content
remediations.description: Provide the user with a control that manages moving or blinking content. The control should observe the appropriate level of WCAG conformance (appropriate contrast, meaningful name) is keyboard accessible. The control is positioned either at the top of the page or adjacent to the moving content. A single control may stop all moving or blinking content on the page, or there may be separate controls for separate parts of the content.

remediations.name: Website button increases text space to 1.5 or double spacing
remediations.description: A button that increases the line height from single spacing can help with reading the content. To retain the separation of paragraphs, the space between paragraphs should also increase so that it is at least 1.5 times as high as the line spacing.

examples.name: Example 1
examples.description: Use standard style page switching and have a button or link on the page that switches the stylesheet. The new stylesheet contains a rule to increase the line height and a class to increase the paragraph spacing.

remediations.name: Control at the beginning of webpage changes the link text
remediations.description: Provide a control near the beginning of the page that takes users to a conforming alternate version wherever the link text alone is sufficient to determine each link's purpose out of context. Ensure users can understand the control's purpose directly from its text if it is a link, and consider saving this preference in cookies or user profiles so users only need to make the selection once per site and automatically access their preferred version on future visits.

examples.name: Example 1: Providing a Link to another Version
examples.description: A web page lists books for download in different formats. Alternate versions of the web page use just the book format as the link text or the book title and format type.
examples.code:
Books for download

Full link Version

  • The History of the Web: Word, PDF, HTML

remediations.name: Users can turn blinking content off
remediations.description: Provide a conforming alternate version of the page without blinking content for users who cannot use pages with blinking elements, following the conformance requirement approach for meeting success criteria 2.2.2. Ensure the alternate page contains all the same info that was present on the original page with blinking content, allowing users to access complete functionality without the problematic blinking elements.

remediations.name: Multimedia avatar provides assistance (help) in using the Web page
remediations.description: Provide help using a multimedia avatar that provides assistance in using the web page. An avatar can be particularly helpful to people with cognitive disabilities who may have trouble reading text. The use of visuals will help some people to focus on the material presented.

remediations.name: Webpage provides spell checking and suggestions for text input
remediations.description: Provide spell checking and text suggestions to help users who need assistance with exact spelling, saving them time-consuming research. Include a simple mechanism to select suggested words and input them into text fields, which also benefits blind and low vision users, as well as dexterity disabled users who use head pointers or scanning software that makes typing slow and difficult.

remediations.name: An author-supplied, visible focus indicator is used
remediations.description: Enhance the browser's default focus indicator by creating a more visible one in the content when users focus on elements using the keyboard. Use a combination of highly contrasting colors, thick lines, and visual indicators like glows to make focus more apparent, addressing the limitations of default thin, dotted lines or pale blue outlines that can be difficult to see against certain backgrounds, in table cells, around outlined form elements, or on small elements.

remediations.name: Image text alt applies to all images in the same group
remediations.description: Provide a text alt that serves the entire group of adjacent non-text content rather than individual alts for each item, to avoid unnecessary duplication and confusion. Associate the group's text alt with one item in the group and mark the other items so they can be ignored by AT, helping users efficiently understand the purpose of grouped content - such as star ratings where individual images work together to convey a single piece of info.

examples.name: Example 1: A rating system in HTML
examples.description: In the following example, a rating is shown as three filled stars and two empty stars. While a text alt could have been provided for each of the five images, the author has instead provided the rating in the form "3 out of 5 stars" for the first image and has marked the others using null alt text.
examples.code: Rating:

examples.name: Example 2: Buttons created with groups of images in HTML
examples.description: In this example, each button has a set of images to indicate the level of conformance to WCAG being claimed. This approach makes it possible for AT to avoid announcing things like, "Image A, Image A, Image A" etc.
examples.code: Conformance Level:

remediations.name: Labels/names/text alternatives are consistent
remediations.description: Use consistent labels for UI components that have the same function to help users with cognitive disabilities and visual impairments understand what happens when interacting with elements. Consistent labeling prevents confusion and unnecessary errors.

remediations.name: User can turn off task time limit
remediations.description: Provide a mechanism to turn off time limits when users cannot complete tasks within the specified timeframe, ensuring the mechanism itself has no time limit and can be accessed before the page's time limit expires. Position the mechanism at or near the top of the page so users with a wide range of disabilities can find and activate it quickly before encountering timing constraints.

remediations.name: Correct form input receives success feedback
remediations.description: Provide consistent feedback that indicates successful completion of actions like form submissions instead of requiring users to navigate through content to discover if the action succeeded. Reduce effort for users who cannot easily scan through info to confirm their actions were successful, such as verifying that data was entered into a database, sent to a person, or added to content being edited.

remediations.name: Users are warned before automatically opening new window/tab
remediations.description: Warn the user before links automatically open new windows/tabs, to prevent disorientation for people who have difficulty perceiving visual content and those with cognitive disabilities. Include advance warning so users can decide whether to leave the current window and help them understand that the back button will not work, requiring them to return to their previous window to find their last location.

examples.name: Example 1: Including the warning in the text describing a control
examples.description: The name or label that describes a control can include the warning about opening in a new window.
examples.code: All about Knitting (opens in new window)

examples.name: Example 2: Using CSS to provide a warning before opening a new window
examples.description: The code below uses CSS to provide a warning before opening a new window.
examples.code:
Link opens in new window notification

This is an example of an external link

remediations.name: Webpage provides all-keyboard navigation
remediations.description: Ensure users can operate any functionality of the page through keyboard/keyboard interface to make content accessible to users with no vision and those using alternate input devices like speech input software or on-screen keyboards. Determine all available functionality including mouse and keyboard actions (links, menus, drag and drop, text selection, context menus, shopping cart operations), then ensure each function can be performed using only the keyboard (external or simulated).

remediations.name: "Talking Head" has alt text
remediations.description:
Provide static text alts instead of audio descs for synced media with no important time-based visual info, such as "talking head" videos where a person speaks against an unchanging background (press conferences, company announcements). Include a general desc of the environment context, opening/closing credits, speaker name text, and other basic info seen on screen but not heard in audio. 
This technique does not apply when multiple speakers are visually identified on screen but not clearly identified in the audio track.

remediations.name: Resizing the window does not impact UA reflow of text
remediations.description: Avoid horizontal scrolling by defining text block container widths in percentages rather than absolute measurements like pixels or points, allowing HTML UAs to automatically reflow text as browser windows are narrowed. This helps people with cognitive disabilities and low vision users who do not use AT and have difficulty with text blocks that require horizontal scrolling.

remediations.name: Character cues (in combination with color and text) convey information
remediations.description: Combine color and text or character cues to convey information. Most users can quickly scan the content to locate information conveyed by using color differences. Users who cannot see color can look or listen for text cues; people using Braille displays or other tactile interfaces can detect text cues by touch. The text cue must be included as part of the programmatically determinable name for the control.

examples.name: Example 1: Required fields in an HTML form
examples.description: The instructions for an online form say, "Required fields are shown in red and marked with (required)." The cue "(required)" is included within the label element.
examples.code:
<style>
  .required {
  color:#ec0000;
  }
 </style>
 <label for="lastname" class="required">Last name (required):</label>
 <input autocomplete="family-name" id="lastname" type="text" value="">

remediations.name: Layout change does not require horizontal scrolling
remediations.description: Provide options within content that switch to layouts without horizontal scrolling when the main layout requires horizontal scrolling, using standard style switching technology. Alternatively, design content where horizontal scrolling may be required to access different content areas but not to read individual lines of text, such as spreadsheets where each column can be read without scrolling even though scrolling is needed to see additional columns.

remediations.name: Icons have a 3:1 contrast ratio
remediations.description: Ensure relevant graphical icons have a contrast ratio of at least 3:1 against adjacent colors. When choosing colors for solid color icons on solid or gradient backgrounds, test the contrast ratio between the icon and its adjacent colors to meet the non-text contrast requirements for graphical objects.

remediations.name: Visible label text is part of the accessible name
remediations.description: Ensure visible label text appears entirely within the accessible name of controls so that speech input users can operate content. When users speak commands like "click search," speech recognition software matches against the accessible name, so include the complete visible label text within the accessible name and position it at the beginning when additional context is needed to ensure speech input is correctly interpreted.

remediations.name: Boundaries between adjoining colors have sufficient contrast
remediations.description: Ensure people with moderately low vision can distinguish boundaries between meaningful adjoining color segments by testing that adjoining colors have a contrast ratio of at least 3:1. When adjoining colors have less than 3:1 contrast ratio, add a border that has at least 3:1 contrast with each adjoining color to create clear boundaries between meaningful color segments in graphics.

remediations.name: Drag-and-drop actions can be cancelled after target picking
remediations.description:
Ensure users can renounce path-based drag-and-drop actions after picking up a target by allowing them to release the item outside drop areas, move it back to the original position, or provide confirmation dialogs or undo commands after dropping. 
Sometimes, on touch screen devices with AT (like built-in screen readers, path-based gestures) are consumed by the OS and may not reach authored content, making these gestures unreliable for users who depend on AT.

remediations.name: Accessible name matches the visible label
remediations.description: Ensure accessible names match the visible text labels, enabling speech input users to operate content when speaking commands like "click search" for button activation. Treat only the text string adjacent to or in close proximity to an input as the label for meeting 2.5.3 Label in Name, distinguishing this from group labels like headings or fieldset legends that serve different purposes and should not be considered the control's primary label.

examples.name: Example 2: Text in label element provides name for input via for attribute
examples.description: The text between the label tags also serves as the checkbox input's accessible name "Notify me of delays" by using the for attribute which references the id of the input.
examples.code:
<input type="checkbox" id="notification" name="notify" value="delays">
 <label for="notification">Notify me of delays</label>

examples.name: Example 7: Range of inputs with few labels
examples.description: A less common disparity between labels and inputs can occur when a group of radio buttons is set up to elicit a choice across a range. The labels may only be located at each end of the range or may be interspersed at various points in the range.
examples.code:
<fieldset>
  <legend>Rate your response</legend>
  <label for="hated">Hated it</label>
  <input type="radio" name="meal" id="hated" value="hated">
  <input type="radio" name="meal" id="poor" value="poor" title="Disliked">
  <input type="radio" name="meal" id="neutral" value="neutral" title="So-so">
  <input type="radio" name="meal" id="okay" value="okay" title="Liked">
  <input type="radio" name="meal" id="loved" value="loved">
  <label for="loved">Loved it</label>
 </fieldset>

examples.name: Example 8: Text in parentheses and punctuation
examples.description: Technique G211 is not intended to complicate existing conventions for the construction of accessible form inputs. As described in the Punctuation and capitalization and Text in parentheses subsections of the Understanding document, information does not always need to be included in the accessible name in an attempt to meet the Label in Name requirement, especially where the text would not normally be spoken when using speech recognition to navigate to controls. Where there are established ways of ensuring information and relationships conveyed visually are present programmatically, it is acceptable to leave text in parentheses and punctuation out of the accessible name.
examples.code: * (YYYY-MM-DD)

remediations.name: Control interaction does not accidentally trigger action
remediations.description: Use the default up-event behavior (onclick or mouseup) for controls rather than overriding with explicit down-event triggers. This prevents users from accidentally triggering actions when attempting to interact with controls. Rely on standard control behavior since the up-event is default for almost all controls, and when down-events are used for good reasons (like cursor entry in text fields), ensure they are easily recoverable by allowing users to move the pointer away from the hit area before release.

remediations.name: Motion activated input has conventional controls & application setting
remediations.description: Provide conventional UI components (buttons, links) that do not rely on sensor input alongside device sensor functionality and include a setting to deactivate sensor data when using accelerometers or gyroscopes for input. This ensures people who use mounted devices or cannot precisely manipulate devices can provide input through conventional controls, while people with tremors or motor impairments can prevent accidental activation by turning off motion actuation.

remediations.name: Users can access content in any orientation (portrait/landscape)
remediations.description:
Provide a control that allows users to rotate content whenever automatic rotation is deactivated. 
This helps users who cannot hold devices and have them mounted to wheelchairs or beds, allowing them to access content in their preferred orientation despite the provider's expectation that content should be viewed in a specific device orientation.

remediations.name: Controls replicate path-based or multipoint gestures
remediations.description: Provide controls like arrow buttons as alternative means of input for content sliders to ensure users who have difficulties performing path-based gestures can operate them with single pointer input instead of swiping. This allows users to advance through slider content using single taps or clicks rather than requiring horizontal swipe gestures that bring hidden content chunks into view.

remediations.name: Control slider has single point of activation
remediations.description: Provide alternative input methods for control sliders that set values in ranges (volume, color hue, loan amounts) to ensure users who have difficulties with path-based gestures can operate them without swiping or dragging. Make the slider track clickable for single tap or click value specification, and provide controls like arrow buttons for incrementing or decrementing values with single pointer actions for more fine-grained adjustments.

remediations.name: Users can remap/turn off character key shortcuts
remediations.description: Allow users to turn off or reconfigure keyboard shortcuts that use only character keys (letters, numbers, punctuation, symbols) without modifiers. This prevents accidental activation for speech input users and keyboard users who lack typing accuracy. Provide mechanisms to add modifier keys like Ctrl or change assigned character keys, ensuring shortcuts can be disabled or reassigned to ensure successful interaction with applications.

remediations.name: Link sent to email enables authentication without password
remediations.description: Facilitate user authenticaton without needing a password by providing a mechanism where users can enter their email address and they are sent an email with a link to click. When users click the link in the email, they are directed back to the website and automatically logged in.

remediations.name: Dragging movements have alternatives
remediations.description: Provide alternative single pointer interactions for dragging functionality so that users can operate interfaces like priority lists or Kanban boards. Offer alternatives such as single taps that reveal arrow controls for stepwise movement, dropdown menus for selecting drop positions, or simple swipe gestures for adjacent position changes instead of requiring complex dragging movements.

remediations.name: Contact-us link is placed in consistent location
remediations.description: Provide a Contact us link in a consistent programmatic and visual location across all pages to make it easier for users to find contact info. Ensure the interactive link maintains the same position when viewed within the same size viewport and leads to a page with contact details like phone numbers and email addresses.

remediations.name: Input forms must retain previously entered information
remediations.description: Retain information previously provided by the user or by the system, do not  require the user to remember and re-enter the information from previous steps. This improves success for individuals with cognitive and learning disabilities and memory impairments.

remediations.name: Link is made more accessible by using both text and icons
remediations.description: Use text and icons to make links more accessible. Give null alt text on the image to avoid confusing, redundant links for keyboard and AT users, eliminating tedious navigation through duplicate links and preventing repeated descriptions while maintaining both text and visual representations.

examples.name: Example 1
examples.description: The icon and text are contained in the same a element.
examples.code: Products page

examples.name: Example 2
examples.description: A link contains an icon and text, and the site help refers to the icon. The img has a text alt which is the name used for the icon in the site help, which describes clicking the home page icon.
examples.code: Go to the home page

remediations.name: Webpage has text alt for area elements of image map
remediations.description: Provide text alts for each area element in an image map that serve the same purpose as the selectable regions they represent. Ensure the alt attribute of each area element serves the same purpose as the selectable region it defines, whether linking to other web pages or parts of the current page, so users can understand and access the same functionality through the text alts.

examples.name: Example 1
examples.description: This example uses the alt attribute of the area element to provide text that describes the purpose of the image map areas.

remediations.name: The title is marked by title element
remediations.description: Include a title element in the head section of all HTML documents that defines the document's purpose in a simple phrase to help users orient themselves within the site quickly without searching for orientation info in the page body. Ensure this mandatory title element (which appears once per document) is distinguished from the title attribute that can be applied to individual HTML elements throughout the page.

examples.name: Example 1
examples.description: This example defines a document's title.
examples.code:
<!doctype html>
 <html lang="en">
  <head>
  <title>The World Wide Web Consortium</title> 
  </head>
  <body>
  ... 
  </body> 
 </html>

remediations.name: Abbreviations are explained by using the abbr element
remediations.description: Use the abbr element for any abbreviation (including acronyms and initialisms) to provide expansions or definitions. Combine with the title attribute on the abbr element to provide the expansion needed for a complete implementation, recognizing that this approach has limitations noted in relevant specifications.

examples.name: Example 1: Using abbr element to expand abbreviations
examples.code:
Sugar is commonly sold in 5 lb. bags.

Welcome to the WWW!

examples.name: Example 2: Using dfn and abbr element to define abbreviations
examples.code: Tasini et al. v. The New York Times et al. is the landmark lawsuit brought by members of the National Writers Union against ...

examples.name: Example 3: Using the abbr element to expand an acronym
examples.code: Recent updates to the CSS color module ...

examples.name: Example 4: Using the abbr element to expand an initialism
examples.code: BBC

remediations.name: Non-text content link text alt describes purpose of anchor elements
remediations.description: Provide descriptive text in the a element to describe a link's purpose and help users distinguish it from other links and determine whether to follow it, rather than relying on the destination URI alone. When images are the only link content, use text alts that describe the unique function; when links contain both text and images, provide empty alt text for images if the text sufficiently describes the purpose, or appropriate alt text for images that convey additional info beyond the link's purpose.

examples.name: Example 1
examples.description: Describing the purpose of a link in HTML in the text content of the a element.
examples.code: Current routes at Boulders Climbing Gym

examples.name: Example 2
examples.description: Using the alt attribute for the img element to describe the purpose of a graphical link.

examples.name: Example 3
examples.description: Using an empty alt attribute when the anchor (a) element contains text that describes the purpose of the link in addition to the img element. Note that the link text will appear on the page next to the image.
examples.code: Current routes at Boulders Climbing Gym

examples.name: Example 4
examples.description: A site allows users to provide feedback on products by clicking on the "Feedback" link in a product detail page. Other users are able to provide a response to any feedback. When a response to the user's feedback is available, the feedback link displays an icon, with "response received" as its text alt, after the "Feedback" text. The site's help document describes this icon as a speech bubble containing quotation marks and includes the icon, with its text alt, as an example. The same text alt is used in the product detail pages (when a response is available) to help ensure that users following the documentation can identify the image correctly as documented.
examples.code: Feedback

examples.name: Example 5
examples.description: A link contains text and an icon, and the icon provides additional information about the target.
examples.code: Woodend Music Festival Program

examples.name: Example 6
examples.description: The "MyCorp" company's annual report is made available on the corporate website as a PDF, and the annual corporate budget is made available as an Excel file on the website.
examples.code:
• MyCorp 2009 Annual Report (PDF)
  • MyCorp 2009 Annual Budget (Excel)

remediations.name: Forms have Submit button
remediations.description: Use Submit buttons to provide an explicit mechanism for users to request changes of context. Submit buttons are the appropriate controls for causing context changes because users understand their expected function and can make deliberate decisions about when to trigger them.

examples.name: Example 1: A basic example of a form with a Submit button
examples.code: Enter your email address to subscribe to our mailing list.

remediations.name: The title attribute provides additional info to link purpose
remediations.description: Use the title attribute on anchor elements to provide additional info that clarifies or further describes the link's purpose. Reserve the title attribute for supplementary info rather than essential details like warnings that users need before following the link, and prefer techniques like CSS to hide link text portions or providing complete descriptive link text instead.

examples.name: Example 1: Clarifying the purpose of a link
examples.code: Evacuation Crumbles Under Jumbo Load

remediations.name: RLM/LRM are used to override the text reading direction
remediations.description: Use Unicode right-to-left marks and left-to-right marks to override the HTML bidirectional algorithm when it produces undesirable results, particularly when placing neutral characters like spaces or punctuation between different directional text runs. Enter these marks directly or through character entities and numeric character references, recognizing that source code editors may not display these references as expected due to the bidirectional algorithm.

remediations.name: Images used as Submit buttons have alt attributes
remediations.description: Use the alt attribute on "image" elements to label the button's function rather than describing the image itself. Ensure the label clearly identifies the button's purpose, especially important when multiple Submit buttons lead to different results.

examples.name: Example 1: An input element with an alt attribute
examples.code:
<form action="/find" method="post" role="search">
  <label for="look-up">Find books<label>
  <input id="look-up" type="text">
  <input alt="Search" src="button.gif" type="image">
 </form>

remediations.name: The img element has a short text alt with the alt attribute
remediations.description: Specify short text alts using the alt attribute on img elements, including any important words from the image that are necessary for understanding the content. Ensure the alt text serves the same function as the image and conveys the same meaning rather than necessarily describing the visual characteristics of the image itself.

examples.name: Example 1
examples.description: An image on a Website provides a link to a free newsletter. The image contains the text "Free newsletter. Get free recipes, news, and more. Learn more." The alt text matches the text in the image.

remediations.name: Data tables captions are programmatically associated to data tables
remediations.description: Use the caption element to programmatically associate captions with data tables, ensuring the table identifier acts as a title or heading and remains associated with the table both visually and programmatically. This markup allows screen reading software to navigate directly to the table caption when present, providing proper identification for data tables.

examples.name: Example 1: An appointment calendar with a caption
examples.code:
...
Schedule for the week of March 6

remediations.name: Names/terms are explained in description list
remediations.description: Use description lists (dl element) to provide descs of names or terms by placing each term in a dt element followed by its desc in a dd element, maintaining semantic relationships even as presentation changes. Support multiple terms with single descs or single terms with multiple descs while preserving semantic sequence, and consider using the title attribute for additional info about the list, which works particularly well for alphabetically ordered descs like glossaries.

examples.name: Example 1
examples.description: A list of descriptions of nautical terms used on a website about sailing.
examples.code:
Knot
A knot is a unit of speed equaling 1 nautical mile per hour (1.15 miles per hour or 1.852 kilometers per hour).
Port
Port is the nautical term (used on boats and ships) that refers to the left side of a ship, as perceived by a person facing towards the bow (the front of the vessel).
Starboard
Starboard is the nautical term (used on boats and ships) that refers to the right side of a vessel, as perceived by a person facing towards the bow (the front of the vessel).

remediations.name: HTML markup provides semantic code for headings 1-6
remediations.description: Use HTML heading markup (h1-h6) for semantic code that allows ATs to present the heading status through announcements, beeps, or other auditory indicators. Enable screen reader navigation through heading markup for efficient content location and allow AT that modifies visual display to provide appropriate alternate visual presentations for semantically identified headings.

examples.name: Example 1: Hierarchical Heading Organization
examples.description: In the following example, headings are used in a hierarchical layout with h3 as a subsection of h2, which is a subsection of h1.
examples.code:
Plant Foods that Humans Eat

There are an abundant number of plants that humans eat ...

Fruit

A fruit is a structure of a plant that contains its seeds ...

Apple

The apple is the pomaceous fruit of the apple tree ...

Orange

The orange is a hybrid of ancient cultivated origin ...

Banana

Banana is the common name for herbaceous plants ...

Vegetables

A vegetable is an edible plant or part of a plant other than a sweet fruit ...

Broccoli

Broccoli is a plant of the mustard/cabbage family ...

Brussels sprouts

The Brussels sprout of the Brassicaceae family, is a Cultivar group of wild cabbage ...

Green beans

Green beans have been bred for the fleshiness, flavor, or sweetness of their pods ...

examples.name: Example 2: Headings in a three-column layout
examples.description: In this example, the main content of the page is in the middle column of a three-column page. The title of the main content matches the title of the page, and is marked as h1, even though it is not the first thing on the page. The content in the first and third columns is less important, and marked with h2.
examples.code:
Site Navigation

Stock Market up today

Related links

remediations.name: Each table data cell is associated to the appropriate headers
remediations.description:
Add headers attributes to data cells (td elements) containing space-separated lists of id attributes from associated header cells. Add id attributes to header cells to associate each data cell with appropriate headers in complex data tables. 
Use this technique when data cells relate to multiple row and column headers where the th element alone or with scope attribute cannot identify relationships, enabling screen readers to speak associated headers and making relationships perceivable across presentation changes. 
Avoid this technique for layout tables where it implies meaningless relationships.

examples.name: Example 1: A table with multiple rows of headers
examples.code:
Homework Exams Projects
1 2 Final 1 2 Final
15% 15% 15% 20% 10% 10% 15%

remediations.name: The label element explicitly associates a form control to a label
remediations.description: Use the label element with a for attribute that matches the id attribute of the form control to explicitly associate labels with form controls. Ensure the ID is unique on the page and may match the name attribute, positioning labels after checkbox and radio inputs but before other input types. This technique provides a larger clickable area for users with motor impairments and meets multiple success criteria whether the label is visible or hidden with CSS, though visible labels are required for Success Criterion 3.3.2.

examples.name: Example 1: A text input field
examples.description: The text field in this example has the explicit label of "First name:". The label element's for attribute matches the id attribute of the input element.
examples.code:
<label for="firstname">First name:</label> 
 <input id="firstname" name="firstname" type="text">

examples.name: Example 2: A checkbox
examples.code:
<input checked id="markuplang" name="computerskills" type="checkbox">
 <label for="markuplang">HTML</label>

examples.name: Example 3: A group of radio buttons
examples.description: A small, related group of radio buttons with a clear desc and labels for each individual element.
examples.code:
Doughnut Selection

Pick the doughnut you would like

remediations.name: Use ol for ordered lists, ul for unordered lists
remediations.description: Use appropriate list elements: ol (ordered lists), ul (unordered lists), dl (name-value pairs like terms and definitions). Avoid visual formatting that appears as lists without proper markup (like asterisks with br elements) since this creates navigation difficulties for users. Consider using list structures to group hyperlinks, enabling screen reader users to navigate efficiently between lists and bypass link groups when desired.

examples.name: Example 1: A list showing steps in a sequence
examples.description: This example uses an ordered list to show the sequence of steps in a process.
examples.code:
1. Mix flour, eggs, milk, and seasoning in a bowl.
  2. Whisk until the batter is smooth.
  3. Rest the batter for at least 30 minutes before cooking.

examples.name: Example 2: A grocery list
examples.description: This example shows an unordered list of items to buy at the store.
examples.code:
• Milk
  • Eggs
  • Butter

examples.name: Example 3: A word and its definition
examples.description: This example uses a desc list to group a definition with the term that is being defined.
examples.code:
<dl>
  <dt>blink</dt>
  <dd>turn on and off between 0.5 and 3 times per second</dd>
 </dl>

examples.name: Example 4: Contact information using a description list
examples.description: This example uses a description list to mark up pairs of related items. The pairs themselves are a logically related list.
examples.code:
Name:
Taisha Silveri
Tel:
503-123-4567
Email:
taisha-silveri@example.com

examples.name: Example 5: Using lists to group links
examples.description: In this example, the links are grouped using the ul and li elements.
examples.code:
Product Categories

  • Kitchen
  • Bed & Bath
  • Fine Dining
  • Lighting
  • Storage

remediations.name: Table markup presents tabular info
remediations.description: Use the table element with tr, th, and td child elements to present tabular info while preserving logical relationships in two dimensions that must remain perceivable when visual presentation changes. Ensure simple tables with one level of headers use row 1 for column headings that describe entire columns and column 1 for row headings that describe entire rows, avoiding purely visual techniques like tabs or pre elements that lose logical relationships when users cannot see the table.

examples.name: Example 1: A schedule marked up as a simple data table with column and row headers
examples.description: This example uses markup for a simple data table. The first row shows the days of the week. Time intervals are shown in the first column. These cells are marked with the th element. This identifies the days of the week as column headers and the time intervals as row headers.
examples.code:
Time Monday Tuesday Wednesday Thursday Friday
8:00-9:00 Meet with Sam
9:00-10:00 Doctor Williams Sam again Leave for San Antonio

remediations.name: Content rendered using the object element has text alt
remediations.description: Provide complete text alts for content rendered using the object element by including fallback content in the body of the element, which may contain additional non-text content with text alts. Recognize that fallback content is only available when the media cannot be rendered due to unsupported technology or user settings, so only rely on this technique when not depending on the direct accessibility of the media technology and when users can reasonably access the fallback content.

examples.name: Example 1: An object includes a long desc that describes it
Example 2: An object includes non-text content with a text alternative
Example 3: The image object has content that provides a brief desc of the function of the image
Example 4
examples.description: This example takes advantage of the fact the object elements may be nested to provide for alternative representations of information.
examples.code:
<object classid="java:Press.class" width="500" height="500">
  <object data="pressure.mpeg" type="video/mpeg">
  <object data="pressure.gif" type="image/gif">
  As temperature increases, the molecules in the balloon...
  </object>
  </object>
 </object>

remediations.name: The dfn element marks word/phrase definition
remediations.description: Use the dfn element to mark the use of a word or phrase where it is defined, enclosing the term itself rather than the definition. Combine this technique with inline definitions to provide the actual definition, since dfn indicates the occurrence where the term is being defined rather than containing the definition text.

examples.name: Example 1
examples.code: The Web Content Accessibility Guidelines require that non-text content has a text alternative. Non-text content is content that is not a sequence of characters that can be programmatically determined or where the sequence is not expressing something in human language; this includes ASCII Art (which is a pattern of characters), emoticons, leetspeak (which is character substitution), and images representing text.

remediations.name: RLM/LRM are used to address text direction changes
remediations.description: Use the dir attribute on inline elements (like span) to identify changes in text direction whenever directional text is mixed, such as English paragraphs with Hebrew quotes that include English phrases. Apply this technique when the Unicode bidirectional algorithm produces undesirable results with mixed directional text containing spaces or punctuation, ensuring proper text direction handling for complex multilingual content.

examples.name: Example 1: Defining the text direction of a nested, mixed-direction phrase, in Hebrew and English, to be right-to-left
examples.description: Because the whole quote is in Hebrew, and therefore runs right to left, the text "W3C" and the comma should appear to the left of (i.e., after) the Hebrew text, like this:
examples.code: The title says " , W3C" in Hebrew.

remediations.name: The lang attribute on the html element defines language
remediations.description: Identify the default language of a document by providing the lang attribute on the html element.

examples.name: Example 1: Defining the content of an HTML document to be in French
examples.code:
<!doctype html>
 <html lang="fr"> 
 <head>
  <meta charset="utf-8">
  <title>document crit en franais</title>
 </head>  
 <body> 
  ... document crit en franais ...
 </body>
 </html>

remediations.name: Changes in language are identified via the lang attribute
remediations.description: Identify any changes in language on a page by using the lang attribute. Language tags use a primary code to indicate the language, and optional sub-codes (separated by hyphen characters) to indicate variants of the language. For instance, English is indicated with the primary code "en"; British English and American English can be distinguished by using "en-GB" and "en-US", respectively. Use of the primary code is important for this technique. Use of sub-codes is optional but may be helpful in certain circumstances.

examples.name: Example 1: The use of the lang attribute to define a quote written in German
examples.code: Da dachte der Herr daran, ihn aus dem Futter zu schaffen, aber der Esel merkte, da kein guter Wind wehte, lief fort und machte sich auf den Weg nach Bremen: dort, meinte er, knnte er ja Stadtmusikant werden.

remediations.name: Webpage uses ruby annotations for pronunciation/meaning
remediations.description: Use ruby annotation to provide pronunciation and meaning where meaning depends on pronunciation, applying rb elements for base text and rt elements for pronunciation guides typically rendered above/beside base text. Choose simple ruby markup for complete words or phrases with fallback support for non-ruby UAs. Use complex ruby markup for dividing base text into smaller units with separate annotations.

examples.name: Example 1: Ruby markup providing pronunciation information for an initialism
examples.description: This example uses Ruby annotation to give the pronunciation of the initialism (acronym) formed by the first letters of the words Web Content Accessibility Guidelines. The letters WCAG are the base (the rb element), and the pronunciation info is shown by the Ruby text (the rt element). The Ruby parenthesis element rp is used for UAs that do not support Ruby annotations to indicate that the text in the rt element provides the pronunciation info. The pronunciation info is rendered in parentheses immediately following the base text. (UAs that support Ruby do not show the parentheses.)
examples.code: When we talk about these guidelines, we often just call them WCAG ( Wuh-KAG ) .

examples.name: Example 2: Ruby annotation for Japanese
examples.description: The following is an example in Japanese. For Japanese, Ruby is used to give the reading of Han characters (Kanji). The Ruby parenthesis element rp is used for UAs that do not support Ruby annotations to indicate that the text in the rt element provides the pronunciation information. The pronunciation info is rendered in parentheses immediately following the base text. (UAs that support Ruby do not show the parentheses.)
examples.code: ( )
