remediations.name: Header cells are associated to data cells using the scope attribute
remediations.description: Use the scope attribute on header cells to associate them with data cells in complex tables by clarifying whether each header cell applies to a row, column, rowgroup, or colgroup. Apply this technique for simple data tables where headers are not in the first row or column, using the values row, col, rowgroup, and colgroup to identify the appropriate scope relationships.

examples.name: Example 1: A simple schedule
examples.description: In the following example, the first column contains serial numbers for rows in the table, and the second column contains the key value for the row. The cells in the second column may then use scope="row". The cells in the first row too are marked up with td and use scope="col".
examples.code:
Contact Information
Name Phone Number City
1. Charlotte Smith 412-212-5421 Pittsburgh
2. Joetta Frere 410-306-5400 Baltimore
3. David Walls 281-511-6600 New York

remediations.name: The title of iframe elements describes their content
remediations.description: Use of the title attribute of the iframe element to describe its contents. Thus, users can determine which frame to enter and explore in detail. The title attribute (which labels the frame for users) is not interchangeable with the name attribute (used for scripting and window targeting). The name is not presented to the user, only the title is.

examples.name: Example 1: Using the title attribute with an iframe to describe the iframe's content
examples.code:
<!doctype html>
 <html lang="en">
 <head>
  <title>A document using an iframe</title>
 </head>
 ...
 <iframe src="banner-ad.html" name="ad-iframe" title="Advertisement"></iframe>
 ...
 </html>

remediations.name: The title attribute provides accessible name for form controls
remediations.description: Use the title attribute to provide an accessible name for form controls when the visual design does not include text on the screen that can be associated with the control as a label. UAs, including AT, can speak the title attribute.

examples.name: Example 1: A pulldown menu that limits the scope of a search
examples.description: A search form uses a pulldown menu to limit the scope of the search. The pulldown menu is immediately adjacent to the text field used to enter the search term. The relationship between the search field and the pulldown menu is clear to users who can see the visual design, which does not have room for a separate visible label. The title attribute is used to identify the select menu. The title attribute can be spoken by screen readers or displayed as a tool tip for people using screen magnifiers. There must be visual info on the page which allows sighted users to understand the purpose of the form controls and UA.
examples.code:
<label for="search-term">Search for:</label>
 <input id="search-term" name="search-term" type="text" value="">
 <select title="Search in" id="scope">
  ...
 </select>

examples.name: Example 2: Input fields for a phone number
examples.description: A web page contains controls for entering a phone number in the United States, with three fields for area code, exchange, and last four digits.
examples.code:
<fieldset>
  <legend>Phone number</legend>
  <input id="area-code" name="area-code" title="Area Code" 
  type="text" size="3" value="">
  <input id="exchange" name="exchange" title="First three digits of phone number" 
  type="text" size="3" value="">
  <input id="last-digits" name="last-digits" title="Last four digits of phone number" 
  type="text" size="4" value="">
 </fieldset>

examples.name: Example 3: A Search Function
examples.description: A web page contains a text field where the user can enter search terms and a button labeled "Search" for performing the search. The title attribute is used to identify the form control and the button is positioned right after the text field so that it is clear to the user that the text field is where the search term should be entered.
examples.code: <input type="text" title="Type search term here"> <input type="submit" value="Search">

remediations.name: Images AT should ignore are marked with null alt text+no title attributes
remediations.description: Show how images can be marked so that they can be ignored by AT. If no title attribute is used, and the alt text is set to null (i.e., alt="") it indicates to assistive technology that the image can be safely ignored.

examples.name: Example 1: Inserting a decorative image on a web page

remediations.name: Webpage sections are marked with heading elements
remediations.description: Use section headings to convey content structure by nesting them hierarchically with the most important info at the highest logical level (h1) and subsections at subsequent levels (h2, h3, etc.). Provide logical heading structure that allows ATs to jump directly to appropriate sections and begin reading content, significantly speeding interaction for special needs users.

examples.name: Example 1: Organizing the sections of a search page
examples.description: This example marks up each section heading using h2 elements.
examples.code:
Search Technical Periodicals

Search

Available Periodicals

  • Professional Coder
  • Algorithms
  • Journal of Software Engineering

Search Results

... search results are returned in this section ...

examples.name: Example 2: Headings show the overall organization of the content
examples.description: In this example, heading markup is used to make the navigation and main content sections perceivable.
examples.code:
Why Monday Monkey Lives For The Weekend

... text, images, and other material making up the main content ...

More About Monday Monkey, Ltd.

  • About us
  • Contact us
    • ...

examples.name: Example 3: Headings show the organization of material within the main content
examples.code:
Cooking techniques

... some text here ...

Cooking with oil

... text of the section ...

Cooking with butter

... text of the section ...

remediations.name: Form controls groups have fieldset and legend elements
remediations.description: Try to group form controls using the fieldset element with a legend element, providing a label or desc for the group. Use this technique particularly for related radio buttons and checkboxes that submit values for a single named field. Consider grouping other controls like address fields when they require additional group-level headings, while avoiding unnecessary nesting that can cause confusion and retaining visual grouping through CSS modifications rather than removing default browser styling.

examples.name: Example 1: A multiple choice test
examples.description: This example shows a test item with one question and five possible answers. Each answer is represented by a radio button (input type="radio"). The radio buttons are contained within a fieldset. The test question is tagged with the legend element. Each field has the same name attribute, indicating these radio buttons are related, and should be grouped as shown. Also note that while the name attributes have the same value, the id attributes' values must be unique.
examples.code: The play Hamlet was written by:

examples.name: Example 2: A set of checkboxes
examples.description: The User Profile page for a website allows users to indicate their interests by selecting multiple checkboxes. Each checkbox (input type="checkbox") has a label. The checkboxes are contained within a fieldset, and the legend element contains the prompt for the entire group of checkboxes.
examples.code: I am interested in the following (check all that apply):

examples.name: Example 3: Logically related controls
examples.description: In this example, form fields for residential and postal addresses are distinguished by the value of the legend in each fieldset grouping.
examples.code:
Your Residential Address
Your Postal Address

remediations.name: Meta refresh is used for instant client-side redirect
remediations.description: Use the meta element with http-equiv="refresh" and content="0" followed by the target URI to implement client-side redirects when server-side redirects are not available, ensuring the timeout is set to zero to prevent content display before the new page loads. Include only redirect-related info on the redirecting page and prefer server-side redirects when possible since they provide better user experience without temporary content display.

examples.name: Example 1: Instantly redirecting a page
examples.code: This page has moved to Planet Express.

remediations.name: Meta refresh is used for instant client-side redirect
remediations.description: Identify the purpose of a link using the link text combined with its list item context when the list item is the nearest enclosing block-level ancestor element. Use the list item context to provide additional meaning for otherwise unclear links, helping users distinguish this link from others and determine whether to follow it, recognizing that simply providing the destination URI is generally not sufficiently descriptive.

examples.name: Example 1
examples.code:
• Check out the video report for last year's National Folk Festival.
  • Listen to the instruments
  • Guitar Man: George Golden talks about making guitars.

examples.name: Example 2: A list of video games for download
examples.code:
• Legend Of Zelda: Tears Of The Kingdom See Images Download Demo
  • Metroid Prime See Images Download Demo
  • Grand Theft Auto See Images Download Demo

remediations.name: Link purpose is identified from link + enclosing list item
remediations.description: Identify the purpose of a link using the link text combined with its paragraph context. Use the paragraph to clarify otherwise unclear links, helping users distinguish this link from others on the page and determine whether to follow it, recognizing that simply providing the destination URI is generally not sufficiently descriptive.

examples.name: Example 1: Announcements content on a folk festival web page
examples.code:
The final 15

Coming soon to a town near you: the final 15 in the National Folk Festival lineup. Read more

Folk artists get awards

Performers from the upcoming National Folk Festival receive National Heritage Fellowships. Read more

remediations.name: Link purpose is identified from the link in its table context
remediations.description: Identify the purpose of a link using the link text combined with its data table context, which includes the table cell enclosing the link and the cell's associated table header cells. Use this table context to clarify otherwise unclear links when the table cell is the nearest enclosing block-level ancestor element, helping users distinguish this link from others and determine whether to follow it.

examples.name: Example 1: A table of rental car choices
examples.code:
Available rental cars with cost per day
Type of car Alamo Budget National Avis Hertz
Economy $67 $68 $72 $74 $74
Compact $68 $69 $74 $76 $76
Mid-sized $79 $80 $83 $85 $85
Full-sized $82 $83 $89 $91 $91

remediations.name: Link purpose is described by context + its heading element
remediations.description: Identify the purpose of a link using the context provided by the preceding heading when the link would otherwise be unclear. Use the heading context to help users distinguish this link from others on the page that lead to different destinations, enabling them to determine whether to follow the link based on the additional meaning provided by the heading.

examples.name: Example 1: Blocks of information on hotels
examples.description: The info for each hotel consists of the hotel name, a description, and a series of links to a map, photos, directions, guest reviews, and a booking form.
examples.code:
Royal Palm Hotel

  • Map
  • Photos
  • Directions
  • Guest reviews
  • Book now

Hotel Three Rivers

  • Map
  • Photos
  • Directions
  • Guest reviews
  • Book now

examples.name: Example 2: A document provided in three formats
examples.code:
Annual Report 2006-2007

HTML PDF RTF

examples.name: Example 3: Newspaper website
examples.description: A script is used to find each element with a class of card-link and append an additional paragraph with a "Read more" link at the end of the div with the class .card-link that goes to the same location as the link in the heading.
examples.code:
Stock market soars as bullishness prevails

This week was a stellar week for the stock market as investing in gold rose 2%.

remediations.name: Nested link purpose is identified from list parent
remediations.description: Identify the purpose of a link in a nested list using the context provided by the parent list item under which the nested list appears. Use this parent list item context to clarify otherwise unclear links and help users distinguish them from other page links, though recognize this technique requires users to navigate lists item by item since current AT lacks commands to query parent list item context, making it potentially inappropriate for very long or deeply nested lists.

examples.name: Example 1: A document provided in three formats
examples.code:
• Annual Report 2021
    • HTML
    • PDF
    • RTF
  • Annual Report 2022
    • HTML
    • PDF
    • RTF

examples.name: Example 2: Blocks of information about hotels
examples.description: The info for each hotel consists of the hotel name, a description, and a series of links to a map, photos, directions, guest reviews, and a booking form.
examples.code:
• Royal Palm Hotel
    • Map
    • Photos
    • Directions
    • Guest reviews
    • Book now
  • Hotel Three Rivers
    • Map
    • Photos
    • Directions
    • Guest reviews
    • Book now

remediations.name: Target attribute explicitly helps opening new window
remediations.description: Use the target attribute to provide a machine-readable indication that a new window will open, preventing confusion from unexpected new windows that can disorient users or be missed entirely. Ensure the target attribute allows user agents to inform users and be configured not to open new windows, while also providing indication through link text for users not using AT.

examples.name: Example 1: Using the target attribute in a link to indicate it will open in a new window
examples.code: Show Help (opens new window)

remediations.name: Webpage provides button with Select element to perform action
remediations.description: Allow users to control when actions are performed by providing a separate button rather than triggering actions as side effects of selecting values from select elements. Enable users to inspect different values or accidentally choose wrong values without causing unintended actions, which is particularly important for keyboard users since navigating through select options changes the control value before they can make deliberate choices.

examples.name: Example 1: A calendar
examples.description: A web page lets the user choose a quarter of any year and display the calendar for those months. After the user has set the quarter and year, they display the calendar by pressing the "Show" button. This example relies on client-side scripting to implement the action.
examples.code:
<label for="quarter">Quarter:</label>
 <select id="quarter" name="quarter">
  <option value="1">Quarter 1 (January - March)</option>
  <option value="2">Quarter 2 (April - June)</option>
  <option value="3">Quarter 3 (July - September)</option>
  <option value="4">Quarter 4 (October - December)</option>
 </select> 
 <label for="year">Year:</label>
 <input name="year" type="text" id="year">
 <button name="show" type="button">Show</button>

examples.name: Example 2: Choosing an action
examples.description: A select element contains a list of possible actions. The action is not performed until the user presses the "Update" button.
examples.code:
<form action="/process-form" method="post">
  <label for="action">Options:</label>
  <select name="action" id="action">
  <option value="add">Add</option>
  <option value="remove">Remove</option>
  <option value="cancel">Cancel</option>
  <option value="order">Order</option>
  </select> 
  <button name="submit" type="submit">Update</button>
 </form>

remediations.name: Items are grouped in a selection list
remediations.description: Group related options in selection lists using the optgroup element with a descriptive label attribute rather than using dummy entries like dashes to create visual separation. Place optgroup elements directly inside select elements with option elements directly inside optgroups to help users locate desired options more easily in long lists. Consider defining option labels that remain understandable even when screen readers do not present the optgroup info, as only one level of grouping is possible since optgroup elements cannot be nested.

examples.name: Example 1
examples.description: The following combo box collects data about favorite foods. Grouping by type allows users to select their preference more quickly.
examples.code:
<form action="/favorite-food/" method="post">
  <label for="food">What is your favorite food?</label>
  <select id="food" name="food">
  <optgroup label="Fruits">
  <option value="1">Apples</option>
  <option value="2">Bananas</option>
  <option value="3">Peaches</option>
  </optgroup>
  <optgroup label="Vegetables">
  <option value="4">Broccoli</option>
  <option value="5">Carrots</option>
  <option value="6">Cucumbers</option>
  </optgroup>
  <optgroup label="Baked Goods">
  <option value="7">Apple Pie</option>
  <option value="8">Bagels</option>
  <option value="9">Chocolate Cake</option>
  </optgroup>
  </select>
 </form>

examples.name: Example 2
examples.description: The following example shows how a multi-select box can make use of the optgroup element.
examples.code:
<form action="/animals/" method="post">
  <label for="animals">Pick your favorite animals:</label>
  <select id="animals" multiple name="animals" size="10">
  <optgroup label="Dinosaurs">
  <option value="brontosaurus">Brontosaurus</option>
  <option value="pterodactyl">Pterodactyl</option>
  <option value="trex">Tyrannosaurus Rex</option>
  <option value="velociraptor">Velociraptor</option>
  </optgroup>
  <optgroup label="Ungulates">
  <option value="camel">Camel</option>
  <option value="giraffe">Giraffe</option>
  <option value="hippo">Hippo</option>
  <option value="horse">Horse</option>
  <option value="zebra">Zebra</option>
  </optgroup>
  <optgroup label="Household Pets">
  <option value="cat">Cat</option>
  <option value="dog">Dog</option>
  <option value="fish">Fish</option>
  <option value="rabbit">Rabbit</option>
  </optgroup>
  </select>
 </form>

remediations.name: Emojis, emoticons, ASCII art, and leetspeak have text alt
remediations.description: Provide appropriate text alts for emojis when their default names do not match the intended meaning, such as using a black triangle emoji for a play button where the default "black right-pointing pointer" would be confusing. Replace emoticons with words like "smile" or suitable emojis when possible, or provide text alts for emoticons since multiple ASCII characters can confuse screen reader users. Ind include text explanations for ASCII art along with optional skip links, while providing text alts for leetspeak since character substitutions are incomprehensible to screen readers.

examples.name: Example 1: Marking up emojis in a sentence
examples.description: This shows a technique to mark up emojis with accessible names that differ from their default. Because you can't use an alt attribute on a span element and the ARIA recommendation disallows accessible names on generic elements, to give the emojis accessible names they are defined as images with the ARIA role="img" property which then allows the creation of an accessible name using the aria-label property.
examples.code: I smiled at my friend and gestured !

examples.name: Example 2: Four options for providing alternatives for an emoticon representing "smile"
examples.description: The following shows four options for providing alternatives for an emoticon representing "smile", which is consists of a colon followed by a closing parenthesis.
examples.code: :) (smile) :) :)

examples.name: Example 3: Using the aria-label and role="img" properties
examples.description: Adding the role="img" property to the ASCII content's containing element defines it as an image, and the aria-label property gives it the required text alternative. Skip to the next ASCII example.

examples.name: Example 4: ASCII art with an explanation of the picture preceding it
examples.description: This example includes a link to skip over the ASCII art. Skip to the Leetspeak example.
examples.code: New content after the ASCII image.

examples.name: Example 5: Marking up Leetspeak
examples.description: The following is Leetspeak for "Austin Rocks".
examples.code: <abbr title="Austin Rocks">Au5t1N r0xx0rz</abbr>

remediations.name: UA and AT can accurately represent features
remediations.description: Use HTML accordingly to ensure UAs including ATs can present features that match the author's intent and achieve interoperability. Follow technology specifications that define the meaning and proper handling of HTML features, recognizing that proper implementation enables AT to function correctly and provides consistent behavior across different user agents.

remediations.name: The title attribute provides context-sensitive help
remediations.description: Provide context sensitive help for users as they enter data in forms by providing the help information in a title attribute. The help may include format information or examples of input.

examples.name: Example 1
examples.description: A mapping application provides a form consisting of a label "Address:", an input component and a Submit button with value "Find map". The input component has a title attribute value with an example of the address format the user should enter.
examples.code:
<label for="search-address">Address:</label>
 <input id="search-address" name="search-address" size="30"
  title="Address example: 101 Collins St, Melbourne, Australia" type="text" value="">

examples.name: Example 2
examples.description: A form that allows users to pay their bill online requires the user to enter their account number. The input component associated with the "Account number" label has a title attribute providing info on locating the account number.
examples.code:
<label for="acc-num1">Account number:</label>
 <input id="acc-num1" size="10"
  title="Your account number can be found in the top right-hand corner of your bill"
  type="text" value="">

remediations.name: Mandatory form controls are labeled with label or legend
remediations.description: Mark mandatory fields by programmatically associating symbols or text with fields using the label element or legend for grouped controls in fieldset elements. Advise users of symbol meanings before first use to ensure they understand which fields are mandatory for form completion.

examples.name: Example 1: Using text to indicate required state
examples.description: The text field in the example below has the explicit label of "First name (required):". The label element's for attribute matches the id attribute of the input element and the label text indicates that the control is required.
examples.code:
<label for="firstname">First name (required):</label> 
 <input id="firstname" name="firstname" type="text">

examples.name: Example 2: Using an asterisk to indicate required state
examples.description: The text field in the example below has an explicit label that includes an asterisk to indicate the control is required. It is important that the asterisk meaning is defined at the start of the form. In this example, the asterisk is contained within an abbr element to allow for the asterisk character to be styled so that it is larger than the default asterisk character, since the asterisk character can be difficult to see for those with impaired vision.
examples.code: .req {font-size: 150%}

examples.name: Example 3: Using an image to indicate required state
examples.description: The text field in the example below has an explicit label that includes an image to indicate the control is required. It is important that the image meaning is defined at the start of the form.
examples.code:
indicates that the information is required

...

examples.name: Example 4: Indicating required state for groups of radio buttons or check box controls
examples.description: Radio buttons and checkboxes are treated differently than other interactive controls since individual radio buttons and checkboxes are not required, but indicate that a response for the group is required. The methods used in examples 1-3 apply to radio buttons and checkboxes, but the indication of the required state should be placed in the legend element instead of the label element.
examples.code:
I am interested in the following (Required):
...

remediations.name: Webpage uses HTML form controls and link elements
remediations.description: Use standard HTML form controls and link elements to provide keyboard operation and AT interoperability since UAs provide built-in keyboard functionality and map these elements to accessibility APIs. Ensure AT can extract appropriate accessibility info including role (provided by the HTML element), name (provided by associated text through required attributes, label elements, aria-label, aria-labelledby, or title), and values and states that are exposed through multiple mechanisms for proper interaction.

examples.name: Example 1: Links
examples.description: UAs provide mechanisms to navigate to and select links. In each of the following examples, the role is "link" because the a element has an href attribute. An a element without an href is not a link. The link's value is the URI in the href attribute.
examples.code: Example Site

examples.name: Example 2: Buttons
examples.description: There are several ways to create a button in HTML.
examples.code: <button type="button">Save</button>

examples.name: Example 3: Text Input
examples.description: In example A, the input field has a role of "editable text". The label element is associated to the input element via the for attribute which references the id attribute of the input element. The name comes from the label element, in this case, "Type of fruit". Its value comes from its value attribute, in this case "bananas".
examples.code:
<label for="text-1">Type of fruit</label>
 <input id="text-1" type="text" value="bananas">

examples.name: Example 4: Checkbox
examples.description: This example has a role of checkbox, from the type attribute of the input element. The label element is associated with the input element via the for attribute which refers to the id attribute of the input element. The name comes from the label element, in this case "cheese". Its state can be checked or unchecked and comes from the checked attribute. The state can be changed by the user's interaction with the control.
examples.code:
<label for="cb-1">Cheese</label> 
 <input checked id="cb-1" type="checkbox">

examples.name: Example 5: Radio Buttons
examples.description: This example has a role of "radio button" from the type attribute on the input element. Its name comes from the label element. Its state can be checked or unchecked and comes from the checked attribute. The state can be changed by the user's interaction with the control.
examples.code:
<input checked id="r1" name="color" type="radio"><label for="r1">Red</label>
 <input id="r2" name="color" type="radio"><label for="r2">Blue</label>
 <input id="r3" name="color" type="radio"><label for="r3">Green</label>

examples.name: Example 6: Radio Fieldset
examples.description: The radio fieldset has a role of "grouping". The name comes from the legend element.
examples.code: Choose a Color:

examples.name: Example 7: Select Element
examples.description: Example A has a role of "list box" from the select element. Its name is "Numbers" from the label element. Forgetting to give a name to the select is a common error. The value is the option element that has the selected attribute present. In this case, the default value is "Two".
examples.code:
<label for="s1">Numbers</label>
 <select id="s1">
  <option>One</option>
  <option selected>Two</option>
  <option>Three</option>
 </select>

remediations.name: The track element provides captions
remediations.description: Use the HTML track element with kind="captions" to specify a captions-timed text track for video elements (that includes transcription or translation of dialogue, sound effects, musical cues, and other relevant audio info). Set the src attribute to the URL of the text track data and ensure captions tracks contain all important audio info since subtitles contain only dialogue and will not be sufficient if other audio elements are important for understanding the video.

examples.name: Example 1: Captions in one language
examples.description: A video element for a video in the English language with an English caption track. The captions are provided in the WebVTT format.
examples.code:
<video poster="myvideo.png" controls>
  <source src="myvideo.mp4" srclang="en" type="video/mp4">
  <track kind="captions" label="English" src="myvideo_en.vtt" srclang="en">
 </video>

examples.name: Example 2: Captions in multiple languages
examples.description: A video element for a video in the English language with an English caption track. The captions are provided in the WebVTT format.
examples.code:
<video poster="myvideo.png" controls>
  <source src="myvideo.mp4" srclang="en" type="video/mp4">
  <source src="myvideo.webm" srclang="fr" type="video/webm">
  <track kind="captions" label="English" src="myvideo-en.vtt" srclang="en">
  <track kind="captions" label="Franais" src="myvideo-fr.ttml" srclang="fr">
 </video>

remediations.name: The track element provides video description
remediations.description: Use the HTML track element with kind="descriptions" to specify audio desc timed text tracks for video elements that contain textual descs of visual components intended for audio synthesis, when visuals are unavailable or unusable. Set the src attribute to the URL containing text track data, ensuring desc cues fit into available audio gaps since UAs may truncate speech if insufficient time exists. Some UAs however support extended audio descs by pausing video until synthesis completes.

examples.name: Example 1: Audio desc in one language
examples.description: A video element for a video in the English language. The audio descs are provided in the WebVTT format.
examples.code:
<video poster="myvideo.png" controls>
  <source src="myvideo.mp4" srclang="en" type="video/mp4">
  <track kind="descriptions" label="English" src="myvideo-en.vtt" srclang="en">
 </video>

examples.name: Example 2: Audio description in multiple languages
examples.description: A video element for a video with both an English and French language source element, and with an English and a French audio desc track using the WebVTT file format.
examples.code:
<video poster="myvideo.png" controls>
  <source src="myvideo.mp4" srclang="en" type="video/mp4">
  <source src="myvideo.webm" srclang="fr" type="video/webm">
  <track kind="descriptions" label="English" src="myvideo-en.vtt" srclang="en">
  <track kind="descriptions" label="Franais" src="myvideo-fr.vtt" srclang="fr">
 </video>

remediations.name: Navigation links are grouped using the HTML nav element
remediations.description: Use the HTML nav element to group navigation links and make them easier to locate and skip for ATs, enabling custom stylesheets to change presentation while preserving relationships. Distinguish multiple nav elements on a page using aria-labelledby or aria-label attributes, recognizing that not all link groups require nav markup since they may be grouped in other structures like lists or use ARIA markup when they do not represent discrete page sections.

examples.name: Example 1: Navigation links enclosed in a nav element
examples.description: This example uses a nav element to group navigation links in an accessibility curriculum.
examples.code:
• Web Accessibility
  • Document Accessibility
  • Mobile Accessibility

examples.name: Example 2: Multiple nav elements and aria-labelledby
examples.description: The following example shows a best practice of how landmarks might be added to an HTML document in situations where there are two or more of the same type of landmark on the same page. For instance, if a nav element is used multiple times on a page, each instance may have a unique label specified using aria-labelledby:
examples.code:
Site

  • nav link 1
  • nav link 2
  • nav link 3

Related Topics

  • topic link 1
  • topic link 2
  • topic link 3

examples.name: Example 3: Multiple nav elements and aria-label
examples.description: The following example shows a best practice of how landmarks might be added to an HTML document in situations where there are two or more of the same type of landmark on the same page, and there is no existing text on the page that can be referenced as the label:
examples.code:
• < href="...">nav link 1
  • < href="...">nav link 2
  • < href="...">nav link 3
  • tag link 1
  • tag link 2
  • tag link 3

remediations.name: Webpage uses HTML 5.2 autocomplete attributes
remediations.description: Add appropriate autocomplete tokens to form fields to programmatically link them to predefined taxonomic terms, making inputs machine-interpretable and helping users identify unfamiliar field labels. Use the autocomplete attribute to enable third-party plugins to add helpful icons or swap labels for more familiar terms like changing "Given Name" to "First Name," while also improving browser auto-population capabilities.

examples.name: Example 1: A user's credit card information
examples.description: This is a simple form that collects contact and credit card info from the user.

remediations.name: Email and password inputs are properly marked up
remediations.description: Provide properly marked up email and password inputs for login forms by ensuring that accessible names allow browsers and password managers to determine correct field population. Avoid blocking UAs, including password managers, from populating fields, and do not prevent users from pasting into these form fields.

examples.name: Example 1: properly marked up email and password inputs
examples.description: A secure website has an email and password based login form.

remediations.name: Modal dialogs are created using the HTML dialog element
remediations.description: Use the HTML dialog element rather than custom ARIA implementations to create accessible modal dialogs since the browser automatically handles important accessibility features like focus management, aria-hidden states, and keyboard behavior. Take advantage of the dialog element's built-in accessibility support to reduce implementation effort while ensuring proper modal dialog functionality.

examples.name: Example 1: A dialog to sign up to a mailing list
examples.description: This is an example of using a modal dialog element to show a mailing-list sign-up form to a user. The main part of the page contains a button element that, when activated, invokes the modal dialog. The button uses the type attribute to tell the browser that this is not a Submit button.
examples.code:
All The News About Turbo Encabulators

Sign up to our mailing list

All form fields are required.

remediations.name: Images with the Alt entry in PDF documents have text alt
remediations.description: Provide text alts for images in PDF documents via /Alt entries in property lists for tags. Use PDF authoring tools to ensure content is accessible to the visually impaired. Include important words from images in the text alt to accurately represent the image's meaning rather than necessarily describing visual characteristics, ensuring the alt conveys the same info as the image for formulas and other non-text items.

examples.name: Example 4: Adding a text alternative to an image in a PDF document using an /Alt entry
examples.description: The /Alt property used on an image of mountains with a moon and trees typically would be used like this (typically accomplished by an authoring tool):
examples.code: /Figure <</Alt (Sketch of Mountains with moon rising over trees)>>

remediations.name: PDF documents have bookmarks
remediations.description: Provide bookmarks (outline entries in an Outline dictionary) in long PDF documents to enable users to locate content through hierarchical navigation. Use conventional document navigation to facilitate understanding document organization and to jump directly to relevant sections.

examples.name: Example 4: Creating bookmarks with the outline hierarchy
examples.description: The following code fragment illustrates part of an outline hierarchy used to create bookmarks. This is typically accomplished by an authoring tool.
examples.code:
121 0 obj
  << /Type /Outlines
  /First 22 0 R
  /Last 29 0 R
  /Count 6
  >>
 endobj
 22 0 obj
  << /Title (Applying Guerrilla Tactics to Usability Testing by People with Disabilities)
  /Parent 21 0 R
  /Next 29 0 R
  /First 25 0 R
  /Last 28 0 R
  /Count 4
  /Dest [3 0 R /XYZ 0 792 0]
  >>
 endobj
 25 0 obj
  << /Title (Getting started)
  /Parent 22 0 R
  /Next 26 0 R
  /Dest [3 0 R /XYZ null 701 null]
  >>
 endobj

remediations.name: PDF tab navigation is in correct order
remediations.description: Ensure logical reading and tab order in PDF documents that matches the meaning of content by creating proper document structure in authoring tools before converting to tagged PDF and using repair tools for complex layouts. Establish tab order through elements such as interactive elements, with content order within tags determined by the PDF's content tree structure and reading prevent issues.

remediations.name: Decorative images in PDF documents are hidden with the Artifact tag
remediations.description: Mark purely decorative images in PDF documents using the /Artifact tag so they can be ignored by AT, typically accomplished through PDF authoring tools. Apply this technique to graphics, objects or markings that are not part of authored content: page headers, footers, section separators, decorative images etc.

examples.name: Example 2: Marking an image as an artifact in a PDF document using an /Artifact tag or property list
examples.description: The PDF specification allows images to be marked as "artifacts". An artifact is explicitly distinguished from real content by enclosing it in a marked-content sequence with the /Artifact tag.
examples.code: BMC ... EMC

remediations.name: PDF form informs user of empty mandatory field
remediations.description: Set required fields in PDF forms using the /Ff entry in form field dictionaries and provide alert dialogs that describe validation errors in text when mandatory fields are not completed. Use PDF authoring tools to implement required field validation and ensure UAs like Adobe Acrobat Pro provide automatic alerts, pointing out to what went wrong and to errors corrections.

examples.name: Example 2: Adding a required text field in a PDF form using the /Tx field type and Ff flag
examples.description: The following code fragment illustrates code that is typical for the object definitions for a typical text field. Note that the text field is required, using the Ff flag. This is typically accomplished by an authoring tool.
examples.code:
<< /AP -dict- 
  /DA /Helv 0 Tf 0 g
  /DR -dict-
  /F 0x4
  /FT Tx % FT key set to Tx for Text Field
  /Ff 0x2  % Ff integer 0x2 value indicates required
  /P -dict-
  /Rect -array-
  /StructParent 0x1
  /Subtype Widget
  /T First % Partial field name First
  /TU First name (required) % TU tool tip value serves as short description
  /Type Annot
  /V Pat Jones
 >>
 ...
 <Start Stream>

remediations.name: Tables in PDF documents are recognizable by AT
remediations.description: Mark up tables in PDF documents using proper structure types (table, table row, table header, table data elements) so they are recognized by AT and preserve logical relationships in two dimensions. Use PDF authoring tools, Adobe Acrobat's Add Tags feature, Adobe LiveCycle's Object Library, or convert from applications like Microsoft Word, but verify and correct any table tagging issues to ensure columns and rows are recognizable and maintain their logical relationships for users who cannot see the table or when presentation format changes.

examples.name: Example 4: Marking up a table using table structure elements
examples.description: The following code fragment illustrates code that is typical for a simple table (header row and data row):
examples.code:
95 0 obj %Structure element for a table
  << 
  /A 39 0 R
  /K[96 0 R 101 0 R 106 0 R 111 0 R]
  /P 93 0 R
  /S/Table %standard structure type is table
  >> 
  endobj
 96 0 obj %Structure element for a table row
  << 
  /K[97 0 R 98 0 R 99 0 R 100 0 R]
  /P 95 0 R
  /S/TR  %standard structure type is table row
  >> 
  endobj
  97 0 obj %Structure element for a table header
  <<
  /A[23 0 R 120 0 R]
  /K 1
  /P 96 0 R
  /S/TH  %standard structure type is table head
  /Pg 8 0 R
  >> 
  endobj
  104 0 obj %Structure element for table data (cell contents)
  << 
  /A 29 0 R
  /K 7
  /P 101 0 R
  /S/TD %standard structure type is table data
  /Pg 8 0 R
  >> 
 endobj

remediations.name: Visual presentation of text does not interfere with readability
remediations.description: Use actual text rather than scanned images of text in PDF documents since image-based text cannot be read by AT, searched, selected, edited, resized, reflowed, or have colors changed by users. Author content using tools like Microsoft Word or Oracle Open Office and convert to PDF, or if source files are unavailable, convert scanned images using optical character recognition (OCR) with tools like Adobe Acrobat Pro to create accessible text that AT can process.

remediations.name: Abbreviations have definition via /E entry
remediations.description: Provide expansion or definition of abbreviations on their first occurrence in PDF documents by setting expansion text using the /E entry for structure elements, typically with Span elements but valid with any structure element. Include both the abbreviation and expansion text on first use (for example, "Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG)") to help recognition in later occurrences.

examples.name: Example 2: Using a /Span structure element with an /E entry to define an abbreviation
examples.description: The following code fragment illustrates code that is typical for using the /Span structure element to define an abbreviation.
examples.code:
1 0 obj % structure element
  << /Type /StructElemen
  /S /Span % element type
  /P ... % Parent in structure hierarchy
  /K << /Type /MCR
  /Page 2 0 R % Page containing marked-content sequence
  /MCID 0  % Marked content identifier for "lb"
  >>
  /E (pound, lb)
  >>
 endobj

examples.name: Example 3: Using a /TH structure element with an /E entry to define an abbreviation
examples.description: As noted in the Description, the /E entry is valid with any structure element.
examples.code:
1 0 obj % structure element
  << /Type /StructElemen
  /S /TH % element type
  /P ... % Parent in structure hierarchy
  /K << /Type /MCR
  /Page 2 0 R  % Page containing marked-content sequence
  /MCID 0  % Marked content identifier for "Dec"
  >>
  /E (December, Dec)
  >>
 endobj

remediations.name: PDF headings are recognized by assistive technologies
remediations.description: Mark headings in PDF documents using heading elements (H, H1, H2...H6) in the structure tree to help AT users access heading lists and jump directly to content of interest. Use PDF authoring tools to create heading markup that indicates important content sections and enables efficient content skimming, significantly speeding interaction for users who would otherwise access content slowly by allowing them to navigate directly to relevant sections.

remediations.name: PDF form control labels are accessible
remediations.description: Ensure PDF form controls have programmatically associated labels conveying their purpose by adding tooltips to each field using the TU entry in the field dictionary, which AT can interpret as programmatic label. Use tools like Adobe Acrobat Pro to create accessible forms where users can recognize form fields, understand how to complete them, and submit forms successfully, providing understandable labels so AT users can interact with forms.

examples.name: Example 2: Adding a tooltip to interactive form controls
examples.description: The following code fragment illustrates the use of the TU entry to provide a tooltip (or programmatically associated text label) for a form field. This is typically accomplished by an authoring tool.
examples.code:
<< /AP -dict- 
  /DA /Helv 0 Tf 0 g
  /DR -dict-
  /F 0x4
  /FT Tx % FT key set to Tx for Text Field
  /P -dict-
  /Rect -array-
  /StructParent 0x1
  /Subtype Widget
  /T Date you are available  % Partial field name Date
  /TU Date you are available: use MM/DD/YYYY format % TU tool tip serves as description
  /Type Annot
  /V Pat Jones
 >>
 ...
 <Start Stream>
  BT
  /P <</MCID 0 >>BDC
  /CS0 cs 0 scn 
  /TT0 1 Tf
  -0.001 Tc 0.003 Tw 11.04 0 0 11.04 72 709.56 Tm
  [(P)-6(le)-3(as)10(e)-3( )11(P)-6(rin)2(t)-3( Y)8(o)-7(u)2(r N)4(a)11(m)-6(e)]TJ

remediations.name: PDF links are recognizable by keyboard and AT
remediations.description: Mark up link text in PDF documents using Link tags with text objects in their sub-tree so links are programmatically available to UAs and recognizable to keyboard and AT users. Create links during document authoring before PDF conversion when possible, or use Adobe Acrobat Pro while ensuring link text or context makes the purpose clear since tooltips created in Acrobat Pro are not accessible to screen readers.

examples.name: Example 4: Marking up link text using a /Link structure element
examples.description: Link annotations in PDF documents are associated with a geometric region of a page rather than a particular object in a content stream. For this reason, link annotations alone are not useful for users with visual impairments, or to applications that must determine which content can be activated to invoke a hypertext link.
examples.code: Here is some text with a link inside.

remediations.name: AT can gather information and interact with PDF form controls
remediations.description: Ensure AT can gather info about and interact with PDF form controls (text input, checkbox, radio button, combo box, list box, button) by providing name, role, state, and value info that enables compatibility with screen readers, screen magnifiers, and speech recognition software. Use tools like Adobe Acrobat Pro or Adobe LiveCycle Designer to properly define these properties for form components.

examples.name: Example 2: Adding a checkbox in a PDF document using the /Btn field type
examples.description: The following code fragment illustrates code that is typical for a simple check box field such as shown in Examples 1 and 2. This is typically accomplished by an authoring tool.
examples.code:
1 0 obj
  << /FT /Btn  % Role
  /TU Retiree % Name
  /V /Yes % Value
  /AS /Yes
  /AP << /N << /Yes 2 0 R /Off 3 0 R>>
  >>
 endobj

remediations.name: Replacement text is provided using the /Alt entry in PDF links
remediations.description: Provide replacement link text via the /Alt entry in the Link tag property list when additional info is needed to make links more accessible, particularly for screen reader users who will use the Alt entry value instead of visible text objects. Create context-independent link text before PDF conversion, or use Adobe Acrobat Pro's Create Link command when editing PDF documents, ensuring alt text makes sense in the given context.

examples.name: Example 2: Adding alternate link text in a PDF document using the /Alt entry
examples.description: The following code fragment illustrates code that is typical for alternative text for a link. This is typically accomplished by an authoring tool.
examples.code:
32 0 obj
 <<
  /S/URI  %Action type (required), must be URI for a URI action
  /URI(http://www.boston.com/business/technology/) %Uniform resource identifier(required), the URI to be resolved
 >>
 endobj

remediations.name: PDF headers and footers indicate navigation location
remediations.description: Provide running headers and footers via pagination artifacts using PDF authoring tools to help users locate themselves within documents by including location information like page numbers, chapter titles, or section headings. Implement this technique either during authoring the document or later using repair tools like Adobe Acrobat Pro's Header & Footer tools.

remediations.name: PDF form has Submit button
remediations.description: Use Submit buttons in PDF forms so users can request context changes, since the intended purpose of Submit buttons is to generate HTTP requests that submit form data.

remediations.name: PDF file's default language is defined by the /Lang entry
remediations.description: Set the document's default language using the /Lang entry in the document catalog, typically accomplished with PDF authoring tools, so AT and user agents can render text more accurately. Enable screen readers to load correct pronunciation rules, visual browsers to display characters and scripts correctly, and media players to show captions properly, helping users with disabilities better understand content.

examples.name: Example 2: Specifying the default document language in a PDF document using a /Lang entry
examples.description: The natural language used for text in a document is determined in a hierarchical fashion, based on whether an optional /Lang entry is present in any of several possible locations. At the highest level, the document's default language may be specified by a /Lang entry in the document catalog.
examples.code:
1 0 obj
  << /Type /Catalog
  ...
  /Lang (en)
  ...
  >> 
  endobj

remediations.name: PDF files have consistent numbering
remediations.description: Set page numbering in PDF viewer controls to match the document's actual page numbering using the /PageLabels entry in the Document Catalog so users can locate themselves accurately within documents. Ensure consistency between document page numbers (including front matter with Roman numerals, main content starting at 1, appendices with letter prefixes) and page number displays in UAs like Adobe Acrobat Pro and Reader.

examples.name: Example 3: Specifying page numbers using the /PageLabels entry
examples.description: The following code fragment illustrates code that is typical for specifying multiple page numbering schemes in a document.
examples.code:
1 0 obj
  << /Type /Catalog
  /PageLabels << /Nums [ 0 << /S /r >> % lowercase Roman numerals
  4 << /S /D >> % Arabic numerals
  7 << /S /D  % Arabic numerals with ...
  /P (A-) % the prefix "A-"...
  /St 8 % starting at page 8
  >>
  ]
  >>
  ...
  >>
  endobj

remediations.name: PDF title is marked with the Title entry
remediations.description: Provide descriptive titles for PDF documents by setting the /Title entry in the document information dictionary and setting the DisplayDocTitle flag to True in the viewer preferences dictionary using PDF authoring tools. Enable user agents to make document titles easily available for identification without requiring users to read page content, allowing titles to appear in window title bars or tab names for location identification.

examples.name: Example 2: A /Title entry in the document information dictionary of a PDF document
examples.description: The following code fragment illustrates code that is typical for providing a /Title entry in a document information dictionary that contains a document title.
examples.code:
1 0 obj 
  << /Title (Applying Guerrilla Tactics to Usability Testing by People with Disabilities)  
  /Author (Mary Smith) 
  /CreationDate (D:19970915110347-08'00')  
  >> 
 endobj

remediations.name: PDF Passage/phrase/word language is specified using /Lang
remediations.description: Specify the language of passages, phrases, or words using the /Lang entry so UAs can present content correctly, typically accomplished using PDF authoring tools. Enable AT and conventional UAs to render text more accurately by allowing screen readers to load correct pronunciation rules.

examples.name: Example 3: Specifying the language for a word or phrase in a PDF document using a /Lang entry
examples.description: Below the level of the default document language, the language for a passage may be specified for the following items:
examples.code:
/P % Start of marked-content sequence
  BDC
  (See you later, or in Spanish you would say, ) Tj
  /Span << /Lang (es-MX) >>% Start of nested marked-content sequence
  BDC
  (Hasta la vista.) Tj
  EMC% End of nested marked-content sequence
  EMC% End of marked-content sequence

remediations.name: PDF tables are properly tagged
remediations.description: Mark up table cells in PDF documents to preserve logical relationships among rows and columns that AT can recognize, typically using PDF authoring tools but verifying structure since conversion may incorrectly merge or split cells. Use Adobe Acrobat Pro's Reading Order tool and Table Editor to ensure table cells are properly structured even when original markup was correct in the authoring tool but conversion introduced errors.

examples.name: Example 2: Marking up a table using table structure elements
examples.description: The following code fragment illustrates code that is typical for a simple table (header row and data row) such as shown in Examples 1-3:
examples.code:
95 0 obj %Structure element for a table
  << 
  /A 39 0 R
  /K[96 0 R 101 0 R 106 0 R 111 0 R]
  /P 93 0 R
  /S/Table %standard structure type is table
  >> 
  endobj
 96 0 obj %Structure element for a table row
  << 
  /K[97 0 R 98 0 R 99 0 R 100 0 R]
  /P 95 0 R
  /S/TR  %standard structure type is table row
  >> 
  endobj
 97 0 obj %Structure element for a table header
  <</A[23 0 R 120 0 R]
  /K 1
  /P 96 0 R
  /S/TH  %standard structure type is table head
  /Pg 8 0 R
  >> 
 endobj
 104 0 obj %Structure element for table data (cell contents)
  << 
  /A 29 0 R
  /K 7
  /P 101 0 R
  /S/TD %standard structure type is table data
  /Pg 8 0 R
  >> 
 endobj

remediations.name: PDF lists are marked with appropriate tags
remediations.description:
Create lists of related items using appropriate list elements (List for containers, List Item for items, Label for bullets or numbers, List Body for content) to indicate list relationships rather than using visual formatting like line breaks. Format lists properly during authoring or use Adobe Acrobat Pro's Reading Order tool and Tags panel when source files are unavailable.
See the structure types for lists in PDF documents in the original technique.

remediations.name: User is notified of format error in PDF form input
remediations.description: Notify users when input to fields requiring specific formats (like date fields) is not submitted correctly via alert dialogs that describe the error nature in text. Use author-created scripting or automatic UA alerts to ensure users are aware errors occurred, can determine what went wrong, and can correct mistakes.

examples.name: Example 2: Validating a required date format in a PDF form using JavaScript using Adobe Acrobat Pro
examples.description: This example is shown with Adobe Acrobat Pro. There are other software tools that perform similar functions.

remediations.name: PDFs support keyboard navigation
remediations.description: Ensure interactive PDF form controls (text input, checkbox, radio button, combo box, list box, button) allow keyboard operation by creating them with PDF authoring tools and verifying accessibility after conversion. Use Adobe Acrobat Pro to check that form fields are keyboard accessible and usable, especially for complex forms or those converted from scanned documents or authoring applications where form fields and labels may not properly convert.

examples.name: Example 3: Adding a text field in a PDF document using the /Tx field type
examples.description: The following code fragment illustrates code that is typical for a simple text field such as shown in Examples 1 and 2. This is typically accomplished by an authoring tool.
examples.code:
<< /AP -dict- 
  /DA /Helv 0 Tf 0 g
  /DR -dict-
  /F 0x4
  /FT Tx % FT key set to Tx for Text Field
  /P -dict-
  /Rect -array-
  /StructParent 0x1
  /Subtype Widget
  /T Date you are available  % Partial field name Date
  /TU Date you are available: use mm/dd/yyyy format % TU tool tip value serves as short description
  /Type Annot
  /V Pat Jones
 >>
 ...

  BT

  /CS0 cs 0 scn 
  /TT0 1 Tf

remediations.name: Automatic redirects are implemented server-, not client-side
remediations.description: Use server-side redirects with HTTP status codes in the 3xx range and Location headers instead of HTML meta element redirects to avoid confusion when pages load in quick succession. Implement redirects using server-side scripts or configuration files that send appropriate HTTP responses, allowing the browser to update the location bar and make requests with new URLs without making pages inaccessible to screen reader users.

examples.name: Example 1: JSP/Servlets
examples.description:
In Java Servlets or JavaServer Pages (JSP), developers can use
 HttpServletResponse.sendRedirect(String url).

examples.name: Example 2: ASP
examples.description: In Active Server Page (ASP) with VBScript, developers can use Response.Redirect.
examples.code: Response.Redirect "newUserLogin.asp"

examples.name: Example 3: PHP
examples.description: In PHP, developers can send a raw HTTP header with the header method. The code below sends a 301 status code and a new location. If the status is not explicitly set, the redirect response sends an HTTP status code 302.
examples.code:
<?php
 header("HTTP/1.1 301 Moved Permanently");
 header("Location: https://www.example.com/newUserLogin.php");
 ?>

examples.name: Example 4: Apache
examples.description: Developers can configure the Apache Web server to handle redirects, as in the following example.
examples.code: redirect 301 /oldUserLogin.jsp http://www.example.com/newUserLogin.do

remediations.name: Primary language of Webpage is specified in HTTP header
remediations.description: Set the Content-Language HTTP header with language codes to identify the primary language so users can find the desired content versions. Ensure the primary document language specified in attributes like lang or xml:lang is listed in the Content-Language header, recognizing this header identifies content audience rather than processing language and enables proper language negotiation when user agent preferences are configured correctly.

examples.name: Example 1: Setting content language in Java Servlet and JSP
examples.description: In Java Servlet or JavaServer Pages (JSP), developers can use response.setHeader("Content-Language", lang), in which "lang" stands for a language tag (for example, "en" for English):

examples.name: Example 2: Setting content language in PHP
examples.description: In PHP, developers can send a raw HTTP header with the header method. The following example sets the language to French:
examples.code: <?php header('Content-language: fr'); ... ?>

remediations.name: Additional audio desc fit into audio-visual dialog gaps
remediations.description: Provide extended audio desc using SMIL 1.0 by breaking audio and video files into sequential segments that freeze on the last video frame while longer audio descs play, creating the effect of continuous video playback with pauses for detailed descs. Use scripting to switch between SMIL versions with and without extended descs or add/remove desc lines dynamically, or provide two video versions when scripting is unavailable, allowing more audio desc content than fits in natural dialogue gaps.

examples.name: Example 1: SMIL 1.0 Video with audio descs that pause the main media in 4 locations to allow extended audio desc
examples.description: The markup above is broken into five par segments. In each, there is a video and an audio tag (the last par has no <audio> tag intentionally). The convention with extended audio descs is that the main media pauses during the desc. The way to make this happen in SMIL 1.0 is to set a clip-begin and clip-end which dictate the start and end of the video clip, and to set a duration for the clip that is longer than what is defined by the clip-begin and clip-end. The fill="freeze" holds the last frame of the video during the extended desc. The audio tag has a begin attribute with a value that is equal to the clip-end value of the preceding video tag.
examples.code:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
 <smil xmlns:qt="http://www.apple.com/quicktime/resources/smilextensions" 
  xmlns="https://www.w3.org/TR/REC-smil" qt:time-slider="true">
  <head>
  <layout>
  <root-layout background-color="black" height="266" width="320"/>
  <region id="videoregion" background-color="black" top="26" left="0" 
  height="144" width="320"/>
  </layout>
  </head>
  <body>
  <par>
  <seq>
  <par>
  <video src="video.rm" region="videoregion" clip-begin="0s" clip-end="5.4" 
  dur="8.7" fill="freeze" alt="videoalt"/> 
  <audio src="no1.wav" begin="5.4" alt="audio alt"/>
  </par>
  <par>
  <video src="video.rm" region="videoregion" clip-begin="5.4" clip-end="24.1" 
  dur="20.3" fill="freeze" alt="videoalt"/>
  <audio src="no2.wav" begin="18.7" alt="audio alt"/>
  </par>
  <par>
  <video src="video.rm" region="videoregion" clip-begin="24.1" clip-end="29.6" 
  dur="7.7" fill="freeze" alt="videoalt"/>
  <audio src="no3.wav" begin="5.5" alt="audio alt"/>
  </par>
  <par>
  <video src="video.rm" region="videoregion" clip-begin="29.6" clip-end="34.5" 
  dur="5.7" fill="freeze" alt="videoalt"/>
  <audio src="no4.wav" begin="4.9" alt="audio alt"/>
  </par>
  <par>
  <video src="video.rm" region="videoregion" clip-begin="77.4" alt="video alt"/>
  </par>
  </seq>
  </par>
  </body>
 </smil>

remediations.name: More audio desc fits gaps in audio-visual dialogs
remediations.description: Use SMIL 2.0 to specify timing for audio files and freeze the video program during playback to provide extended audio desc that exceeds natural dialogue gaps. Create the effect of continuous video playback with automatic pauses for longer audio descs, using scripting to switch between SMIL versions with and without extended desc lines or dynamically add/remove desc content, or provide two SMIL file versions when scripting is unavailable.

examples.name: Example 1: Video with extended audio desc
examples.code:
<smil xmlns="https://www.w3.org/2001/SMIL20/Language"> 
 <head>
  <layout> 
  <root-layout backgroundColor="black" height="266" width="320"/> 
  <region id="video" backgroundColor="black" top="26" left="0" 
  height="144" width="320"/> 
  </layout> 
 </head> 
 <body>  
  <excl> 
  <priorityClass peers="pause"> 
  <video src="movie.rm" region="video" title="video" alt="video" /> 
  <audio src="desc1.rm" begin="12.85s" alt="Description 1" /> 
  <audio src="desc2.rm" begin="33.71s" alt="Description 2" /> 
  <audio src="desc3.rm" begin="42.65s" alt="Description 3" /> 
  <audio src="desc4.rm" begin="59.80s" alt="Description 4" /> 
  </priorityClass> 
  </excl> 
 </body> 
 </smil>

remediations.name: Video has audio desc that fits in the dialog gaps
remediations.description: Provide audio desc by including descs of visual content via audio that fits into the gaps in the dialogue. Enable access to visual info through timed audio desc that describes important visual elements without interfering with the original audio track.

examples.name: Example 1: SMIL 1.0 audio desc sample for QuickTime player
examples.code:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
 <smil xmlns:qt="http://www.apple.com/quicktime/resources/smilextensions" 
  xmlns="https://www.w3.org/TR/REC-smil" qt:time-slider="true">
 <head>
  <layout>
  <root-layout background-color="black" height="266" width="320"/>
  <region id="videoregion" background-color="black" top="26" left="0" 
  height="144" width="320"/>
  </layout>
 </head>
 <body>
  <par>
  <video dur="0:01:20.00" region="videoregion" src="salesdemo.mov" 
  alt="Sales Demo"/>
  <audio dur="0:01:20.00" src="salesdemo_ad.mp3" 
  alt="Sales Demo Audio Description"/>
  </par>
 </body>
 </smil>

remediations.name: Video audio desc fits in the dialog gaps (in audio-visual file)
remediations.description: Provide a way for visually impaired users in audio-visual material to access the material. Provide a description of the video via audio description that will fit into the gaps in the dialogue in the audio-visual material.

examples.name: Example 1: SMIL 2.0 audio desc sample for RealMedia player
examples.description: The example shows a par segment containing an audio and a video tag. The audio stream is not started immediately.
examples.code:
<smil xmlns="https://www.w3.org/2001/SMIL20/Language">
 <head>
  <layout>
  <root-layout backgroundColor="black" height="266" width="320"/>
  <region id="video" backgroundColor="black" top="26" left="0" 
  height="144" width="320"/>
  </layout>
  </head>
  <body>
  <par>
  <video src="salesdemo.mpg" region="video" title="Sales Demo" 
  alt="Sales Demo"/>
  <audio src="salesdemo_ad.mp3" begin="33.71s" title="audio description" 
  alt="Sales Demo Audio Description"/>
  </par>
  </body>
 </smil>

remediations.name: Captions are provided through synced text streams in SMIL 1.0
remediations.description: Provide captions for hearing impaired users in audio visual material by making all dialogue and important sounds available in a text stream displayed in a caption area. Use SMIL 1.0 to define separate regions for video and captions with synchronized playback, displaying caption text in one screen region while corresponding video plays in another region.

examples.name: Example 1: SMIL 1.0 caption sample for QuickTime player
examples.code:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
 <smil xmlns:qt="http://www.apple.com/quicktime/resources/smilextensions" 
  xmlns="https://www.w3.org/TR/REC-smil" qt:time-slider="true">
 <head>
  <layout>
  <root-layout width="320" height="300" background-color="black"/>
  <region top="0" width="320" height="240" left="0" background-color="black" 
  id="videoregion"/>
  <region top="240" width="320" height="60" left="0" background-color="black" 
  id="textregion"/>
  </layout>
 </head>
 <body>
  <par>
  <video dur="0:01:20.00" region="videoregion" src="salesdemo.mov" 
  alt="Sales Demo"/>
  <textstream dur="0:01:20.00" region="textregion" src="salesdemo_cc.txt" 
  alt="Sales Demo Captions"/>
  </par>
 </body>
 </smil>

examples.name: Example 2: SMIL 1.0 caption sample with internal text streams
examples.description: This example shows a text element that includes synchronized text streams within the SMIL file.
examples.code:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
 <smil xmlns="https://www.w3.org/TR/REC-smil">
 <head>
  <layout>
  <root-layout background-color="black" height="310" width="330"/>
  <region id="video" background-color="black" top="5" left="5" 
  height="240" width="320"/>
  <region id="captions" background-color="black" top="250" 
  height="60" left="5" width="320"/>
  </layout>
 </head>
 <body>
  <par>
  <video src="salesdemo.mpg" region="video" title="Sales Demo" 
  alt="Sales Demo"/>
  <text src="data:,This%20is%20inline%20text." region="captions" begin="0s" 
  dur="3" alt="Sales Demo Captions">
  <param name="charset" value="iso-8859-1"/>
  <param name="fontFace" value="System"/>
  <param name="fontColor" value="yellow"/>
  <param name="backgroundColor" value="blue"/>
  </text>
  </par>
 </body>
 </smil>

remediations.name: Captions are provided through synced text streams in SMIL 2.0
remediations.description: Provide captions for hearing impaired users in audio visual material by making all dialogue and important sounds available in a text stream displayed in a caption area. Use SMIL 2.0 to define separate regions for video and captions with synchronized playback, displaying caption text in one screen region while corresponding video plays in another region.

examples.name: Example 1: SMIL 2.0 caption sample with internal text streams for RealMedia player
examples.description: This example shows a text element that includes synchronized text streams within the SMIL file.
examples.code:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
 <smil xmlns="https://www.w3.org/2001/SMIL20/Language">
 <head>
  <layout>
  <root-layout backgroundColor="black" height="310" width="330"/>
  <region id="video" backgroundColor="black" top="5" left="5" 
  height="240" width="320"/>
  <region id="captions" backgroundColor="black" top="250" 
  height="60" left="5" width="320"/>
  </layout>
 </head>
 <body>
  <par>
  <video src="salesdemo.mpg" region="video" title="Sales Demo" 
  alt="Sales Demo"/>
  <text src="data:,This%20is%20inline%20text." region="captions" 
  begin="0s" dur="3">
  <param name="charset" value="iso-8859-1"/>
  <param name="fontFace" value="System"/>
  <param name="fontColor" value="yellow"/>
  <param name="backgroundColor" value="blue"/>
  </text>
  <text src="data:,This%20is%20a%20second%20text." 
  region="captions" begin="3s" dur="3">
  <param name="charset" value="iso-8859-1"/>
  <param name="fontFace" value="System"/>
  <param name="fontColor" value="yellow"/>
  <param name="backgroundColor" value="blue"/>
  </text>
  </par>
 </body>
 </smil>

remediations.name: SMIL 1.0 sign language interpretation is provided
remediations.description: Provide sign-language interpretation for hearing impaired users in audio visual material by displaying a sign-language interpretation video in a caption area that includes all dialogue and important sounds. Use SMIL 1.0 to define separate regions for synchronized playback of both the content video and corresponding sign-language interpretation video in different screen regions.

examples.name:
Example 1: SMIL 1.0 sign-language interpretation sample for QuickTime
  player
examples.code:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
 <smil xmlns:qt="http://www.apple.com/quicktime/resources/smilextensions" 
  xmlns="https://www.w3.org/TR/REC-smil" qt:time-slider="true">
 <head>
  <layout>
  <root-layout width="320" height="300" background-color="black"/>
  <region top="0" width="320" height="240" left="0" background-color="black" 
  id="videoregion"/>
  <region top="240" width="320" height="60" left="0" background-color="black" 
  id="signingregion"/>
  </layout>
 </head>
 <body>
  <par>
  <video dur="0:01:20.00" region="videoregion" src="salesdemo.mov" 
  alt="Sales Demo"/>
  <video dur="0:01:20.00" region="signingregion" system-captions="on" 
  src="salesdemo_si.mov" alt="Sales Demo Sign Language Interpretation"/>
  </par>
 </body>
 </smil>

remediations.name: SMIL 2.0 sign language interpretation is provided
remediations.description: Provide sign-language interpretation for people hearing impaired users in audio visual material by displaying a sign-language interpretation video in a caption area that includes all dialogue and important sounds. Use SMIL 2.0 to define separate regions for synchronized playback of both the content video and corresponding sign-language interpretation video in different screen regions.

examples.name: Example 1: SMIL 2.0 sign-language video sample for RealMedia player
examples.description: The example shows a par segment containing two video tags. The systemCaptions attribute indicates that the sign language video should be displayed when the user's player setting for captions indicates the preference for captions to be displayed. The layout section defines the regions used for the main video and the sign language interpretation video.
examples.code:
<smil xmlns="https://www.w3.org/2001/SMIL20/Language">
 <head>
  <layout>
  <root-layout backgroundColor="black" height="310" width="330"/>
  <region id="video" backgroundColor="black" top="5" left="5" 
  height="240" width="320"/>
  <region id="signing" backgroundColor="black" top="250" 
  height="60" left="5" width="320"/>
  </layout>
 </head>
 <body>
  <par>
  <video src="salesdemo.mpg" region="video" title="Sales Demo" 
  alt="Sales Demo"/>
  <video src="salesdemo_signing.mpg" 
  region="signing" systemCaptions="on" 
  title="sign language interpretation" 
  alt="Sales Demo Sign Language Interpretation"/>
  </par>
 </body>
 </smil>

remediations.name: Paragraphs are correctly formatted
remediations.description: Recognize paragraphs in plain text documents as coherent blocks of text that develop single topics or parts of larger topics by identifying paragraph boundaries through formatting conventions. Mark paragraph beginnings with new lines and indentation or blank line separation, and end paragraphs with line breaks, using blank lines containing zero or more non-printing characters (spaces, tabs) followed by new lines to separate paragraph blocks.

examples.name: Example 1
examples.description: Two paragraphs. Each starts and ends with a blank line.
examples.code:
This is the first sentence in this paragraph. Paragraphs may be long or short.
  
In this paragraph the first line is indented. Indented and non-indented sentences are allowed. White space within the paragraph lines is ignored in defining paragraphs. Only completely blank lines are significant.

remediations.name: Lists are formatted using standard conventions
remediations.description: Use text formatting conventions to create simple lists of related items by beginning each list item paragraph with a consistent label character or sequence. For unordered lists, use the same label characters (asterisks, dashes, bullets) throughout the list. For ordered lists, use alphabetic or numeric labels in ascending order (numeric sequence for numbers, alphabetical order for letters, or numeric order for Roman numerals) that may be terminated by periods or right parentheses, recognizing this technique cannot represent hierarchical or nested lists which require different technologies.

examples.name: Example 1: Unordered list
examples.code:
- unordered list item
  
 - unordered list item
  
 - unordered list item

examples.name: Example 2: Numeric ordered list
examples.code:
1. Ordered list item
  
 2. Ordered list item
  
 3. Ordered list item

examples.name: Example 3: Roman numeral ordered list
examples.code:
i.  Ordered list item
  
 ii. Ordered list item
  
 iii. Ordered list item
  
 iv. Ordered list item

examples.name: Example 4: Alphabetic ordered list
examples.code:
A) Ordered list item
  
 B) Ordered list item
  
 C) Ordered list item

remediations.name: Text formatting conventions are used for content structure
remediations.description: Use text formatting conventions to convey document structure by marking headings with two blank lines before and one blank line after the heading text. Create programmatic identification of headings through this spacing pattern since plain text documents lack underlying structure, enabling screen readers to voice blank lines twice before heading text and allowing screen magnifier users to visually identify headings through the distinctive spacing or through screen reader capabilities that recognize the blank line patterns.

examples.name: Example 1
examples.description: A paragraph is followed by two blank lines, then a heading, then one blank line, then another paragraph:
examples.code:
...this is the end of paragraph 1.
 

 

 The Text of the Heading
 

 This is the beginning of paragraph 2.

axeRules.help: Elements must only use supported ARIA attributes

axeRules.help: aria-braille attributes must have a non-braille equivalent
